Tanah Lot is one of Bali�s most iconic and breathtaking attractions, known for its stunning seaside temple set on a rocky outcrop surrounded by the ocean. The view during sunset is especially mesmerizing, with golden hues reflecting over the waves and creating a peaceful, spiritual atmosphere. The area is well maintained, with neatly arranged walkways, local shops, and food stalls offering a pleasant experience for visitors. The sound of the waves, cool sea breeze, and scenic surroundings make it a perfect spot for photography and relaxation. Tanah Lot beautifully combines natural beauty, cultural heritage, and a calming ambience, making it a must-visit destination in Bali.
A must visit temple.

Tiket masuk turis lokal dewasa 30K parkir motor 3K, tp puas disuguhi pemandangan alam yg dahsyat. Ada pura di atas karang seperti jembatan alam menuju laut. Ombak yg menderu, menciptakan tirai air menuju angkasa saat membentur karang. Pasar seni yang menawarkan pernak-pernik keindahan karsa dan cipta manusia. Pokoknya seru, ga afdol klo ke Bali belum ke Tanah Lot.
One of great place to visit in Bali.

With all due respect, while this is a nice first introduction to Hinduism in Bali, I found it to be a bit of a tourist trap. I understand that many people come here for the sunset, but aside from that, the experience felt fairly average. That said, the statues and the people here are still truly beautiful. However, even if you cleanse yourself with holy water, you still can�t enter the temple itself, which was a bit of a bummer. I wouldn�t recommend this place if you�re mainly visiting for the temple itself.

Pura Tanah Lot is extremely well-managed. The area is spacious, clean, and the layout is very neat. The view of the ocean and the temple standing majestically is the main attraction. However, the best time to visit is late afternoon leading up to sunset�the view is simply breathtaking! The courtyards around the temple are also beautifully arranged.

Tanah Lot Temple is one of Bali�s most famous landmarks. This stunning sea temple sits on a rocky outcrop, surrounded by crashing waves. It�s a must-visit spot for breathtaking views, cultural insights, and one of the best sunsets on the island. Tanah Lot Temple is located in Tabanan Regency, on Bali�s southwest coast. It sits on a rocky offshore island, around 20 km from Denpasar and 15 km from Canggu. The temple is part of the Beraban village, making it an important cultural and religious site in the region.

Another most visited place in Bali. The temple is beautiful. The location is even better. Though a bit far from Kuta; the visit is worthwhile.

Now it is entirely on the tide timings whether you can reach the main temple or not. If you happen to be there during low tide then just walk across the flat rocks and you can reach the main temple stairs. Though there is nothing much to see.
The entire temple compound is beautifully landscaped. You may walk around to see the other photogenic spots. There are many stores and shops selling snacks and souvenirs. You may visit them while returning back.
The main issue is transportation. If you are on a scooter then no worries. But if you are taking a Grab or Gojek cab from Kuta then it will be wise to ask the driver to wait for you over there and come back in the same car. Local taxis might charge a lot if taken from the temple area.

Pura Tanah Lot is a Hindu temple located on the southwest coast of Bali. It sits on an offshore rock formation and it�s therefore reachable only when there�s low tide: part of the rock is artificial because it replaced the original damaged one during restoration works in the 80s. The temple itself is not accessible, so the only two attractions there are the blessing with the holy water in the cave below the temple and the water snake in the cave on the opposite side: both require a money offer and to be honest they are not worth it.

Really a great place to visit they have many puras and have one pura at the middle of sea, when the tide is low we can visit at there and take a picture at the below of pura, if u want to pray at the pura you can request to the people and donate some money.

Tanah Lot Temple Indonesia Bali is pure magic, a sacred jewel perched on a rock in the heart of the ocean.
At sunset, the sky paints it in gold, creating a breathtaking silhouette against fiery hues.
Waves crash rhythmically below, as if the sea itself is chanting prayers.
Intricate stone carvings on black volcanic rock tell ancient stories of devotion and beauty.
The gentle chime of temple bells blends with the salty ocean breeze, soothing the soul.
Walking across the beach at low tide feels like stepping into a divine painting.
The sacred sea snake in the cave adds a touch of mystery and reverence.
Clifftop views offer postcard-perfect panoramas that steal your breath away.
Every corner radiates peace, spirituality, and timeless Balinese charm.
Sunset crowds gather in awe, yet the atmosphere remains serene and sacred.
Frangipani flowers and incense fill the air with sweet, holy fragrance.
The multi-tiered meru towers stand proud, guardians of the coast.
Watching the sun dip into the sea behind the temple is a memory for a lifetime.
Even the journey through lush rice fields to reach it feels enchanting.
Tanah Lot isn�t just a temple�it�s a love letter from nature to the divine.
The reflection in tidal pools at golden hour is pure photographic poetry.
Spiritual energy flows strong; you leave calmer, lighter, and deeply touched.
No filter needed�the beauty here is raw, real, and soul-stirring.
A must-visit masterpiece where earth, sea, and sky unite in harmony.
Tanah Lot Temple: where beauty meets eternity, and your heart finds peace.

Tanah Lot is not just a temple; it is a spiritual and scenic masterpiece that defines the soul of Bali. Perched dramatically on a rocky offshore island, Pura Tanah Lot�meaning "Land in the Sea"�offers a pilgrimage site and a travel experience that easily merits five stars. Its unique location alone creates one of the world's most breathtaking natural vistas.
?The sheer majesty of the temple, with its tiered meru roof silhouetted against the Indian Ocean, is unforgettable. The highlight of any visit is undoubtedly the late afternoon, as travelers gather on the nearby cliffs and terraces to witness the legendary sunset. As the sun dips below the horizon, the sky explodes in shades of orange, pink, and purple, turning the ancient rock formation into a mystical silhouette�a moment of pure, dramatic beauty that belongs on every traveler's bucket list.
?Beyond the views, the site is rich with spiritual and cultural significance. At low tide, you can walk across the wet sands to the base of the rock where you can receive a blessing from the temple priests using water from a sacred freshwater spring�an incredible experience in the middle of the salty sea. Furthermore, the area surrounding the temple is impeccably managed, offering a pleasant cultural park experience, complete with art shops, cafes, and easy access to other shrines like Batu Bolong.
?A visit to Tanah Lot is a profound encounter with Balinese heritage and natural wonder. It's a place where you truly feel the harmony between the island's culture, its legends of sea snakes and priests, and the powerful, beautiful ocean. An absolute must-see that encapsulates the magic of Bali!

Not terrible but also not great... Everyone recommended me to go here, especially during sunset. So that's what I did. First of all you pay 75000 entrance which is fine. At the temple itself there seemed to be a pathway that goes around which I was curious to see, but you need to be blessed before you're allowed. Of course they ask for a donation... But to my surprise I could literally only walk along the side of the rock for about 20m or so ... Ridiculous they suggest people to donate and receive this blessing to walk that little bit further. Besides this it is quite beautiful but I've seen way nicer temples and also the view.. yeah it's alright but again not that nice. But the thing that annoyed me the most is that gojek and grab drivers cannot pick people up in the area. Some group of people apparently have a monopoly over the area and it seems like it could be dangerous if gojek or grab drivers do go into the area. While walking out the area (which is really big) I did see so many people along the road with radios talking to each other and offering rides. This is unfair both for tourists and for fellow Balinese drivers

Tanah lot temple is located in the sea side, one of the famous sea temples in Bali.

Tanah Lot translates to "Land in the sea". The temple is built on a rock formation off the cost making it appear to float on the sea during high tide.

It is famous for the stunning sunset views. Plan your trip to make sure that you will be able to witness the sunset from there.

At the base of the temple, there is holy water which is guarded by snakes. We can enter here and seek blessings as well.

There is lot of shops available for shopping near the entry and exit gates.
Also, the famous traditional Balinese gate is there for photo shoots.

Worth visiting

Tanah Lot Temple, Bali � A Majestic Sea Temple on the Rocks
Tanah Lot Temple is one of Bali�s most iconic landmarks, renowned for its stunning offshore setting and mesmerizing sunset views. Perched on a rocky outcrop surrounded by the sea, the temple appears to float during high tide, creating a truly magical sight. Located in Tabanan Regency, around 20 km from Denpasar, Tanah Lot is a must-visit destination for travelers seeking a mix of spirituality, culture, and natural beauty.
The name Tanah Lot means �Land in the Sea� in Balinese, perfectly describing its dramatic position. The temple is dedicated to the sea gods and plays an important role in Balinese mythology. Legend says that it was established by the 16th-century priest Dang Hyang Nirartha, who built it after being inspired by the beauty of the coastline.
Visitors can enjoy breathtaking ocean views, especially during sunset when the sky glows in shades of orange and gold, creating one of Bali�s most photographed moments. During low tide, tourists can walk across to the base of the temple, explore small caves with sea snakes believed to be sacred protectors, and witness local rituals performed by Balinese priests.
The area around Tanah Lot features beautifully landscaped gardens, souvenir markets, and several cliffside restaurants offering panoramic views. It is also a popular spot for cultural performances and traditional dance shows held in the evenings.
Tanah Lot is open daily, with the best time to visit being late afternoon to witness the sunset spectacle. Visitors are encouraged to dress modestly as it remains an active place of worship.
In short: Tanah Lot Temple is not just a tourist attraction � it�s a symbol of Bali�s spiritual harmony, where nature and faith blend into an unforgettable experience.

Tanah Lot Beach is one of the most iconic and beautiful tourist destinations in Bali. Located in Tabanan, about 20 kilometers from Denpasar, this beach is famous for its unique sea temple built on top of a large rock formation in the middle of the ocean. The temple, known as Pura tanah lot is an important spiritual site for Balinese Hindus and a stunning place to watch the sunset.

The view of Tanah Lot during sunrise is truly breathtaking. Visitors can walk closer to the temple when the tide is low, but when the tide is high, the temple looks like it is floating on the sea, a sight that makes it even more special.

Besides the natural beauty, the area around Tanah Lot also offers local markets, restaurants, and traditional performances that showcase Balinese culture. The facilities are well maintained, making it a comfortable place for tourists.

Overall, Tanah Lot Beach is a must-visit destination in Bali. It combines natural beauty, cultural heritage, and spiritual charm, making every visitor feel the unique essence of the Island of the Gods.

Tanah Lot is one of Bali's most famous and iconic landmarks. It is a spectacular Hindu temple set on a dramatic offshore rock formation.

The name "Tanah Lot" itself means "Land in the Sea" in Balinese, which perfectly describes its unique location.

Here is a guide to this magnificent sea temple:

Location: Tanah Lot is on the southwest coast of Bali, in the Tabanan Regency, approximately an hour's drive from popular areas like Seminyak or Canggu.

The Temple: The main temple, Pura Tanah Lot, is an ancient Hindu shrine dedicated to the sea god, Dewa Baruna. It is one of the seven sea temples that form a spiritual chain along the Balinese coast, believed to protect the island.

Tides & Access:
High Tide:The rock is completely surrounded by water, making the temple look like it is floating on the ocean.

Low Tide: You can walk across a narrow coral path to the base of the rock. Non-Hindu visitors are generally not permitted to enter the inner sanctuary of the temple itself.

The View:The temple's most famous feature is the incredible sunset view. The silhouette of the temple against the fiery orange and purple sky is one of the most photographed sights in all of Indonesia.

History and Legend

Founding: The temple is believed to have been founded in the 16th century by the revered Hindu priest, Dang Hyang Nirartha, who was traveling along the coast spreading Hinduism.

The Legend: Local legend states that the local village chief was hostile to his teachings. Using his spiritual power, Nirartha moved the rock on which he was meditating away from the mainland and out to sea.

Guardian Snakes:To protect the sacred site from evil spirits and intruders, Nirartha is said to have created a venomous sea snake from his sash, which is believed to still guard the temple base today.

Best Time to Visit Late Afternoon (Around 4:00 PM - 6:00 PM)** to secure a good spot for the famous sunset view.

Dress Code It is a sacred place, so modest attire is encouraged. While **sarongs** are not mandatory for the outer area, always dress respectfully by covering your shoulders and knees.

Entrance Fee There is an admission fee for international and domestic visitors. You will also have to pay a small parking fee.
Nearby Attractions Pura Batu Bolong is a smaller sea temple built on a unique archway rock formation just a short walk north of Tanah Lot.

Tanah Lot Temple, an ancient Hindu temple dedicated to the gods of the sea, was built in the 15th and 16th centuries following the sacred journey (tirtha yatra) of the religious figure Dang Hyang Nirartha to Bali. Situated on a large coral reef, separated from the mainland by erosion, the temple has remained a well-maintained site of religious significance to the Balinese people. In 1986, one hundred concrete pillars were installed along its shoreline to combat erosion, but these tetrapods have compromised the aesthetic integrity of the temple and caused environmental problems, including erosion by redirected waves, sand accumulation on the seabed, and disruption of coral reef biodiversity. In addition, increased tourism has placed significant pressure on the site's architecture and surrounding landscape.

The temple itself is stunning and absolutely worth seeing, especially at sunset! But getting out afterwards was a nightmare. Locals block drivers from picking you up, even though the Grab app shows plenty available. They operate in groups, on scooters and on foot with walkie-talkies, and will follow and intimidate both passengers and drivers to force you to use their taxi instead of Grab. We didn�t want to go with them because they demand very high prices, and their aggressive attitude didn�t make us feel safe.

As a family of four, we had to walk a long distance in the dark before finally meeting our driver. It felt really unsafe and I can only imagine how frightening it would be for a woman travelling alone. For safety reasons, I much prefer using verified taxis through apps like Grab, where the trip is tracked.

It�s a shame because this ruined the overall experience and left us with a bad impression, even though the temple and the sunset were truly incredible. If you go, I think the best option is to drive yourself there.

We were forced to �donate� money in order to get entry to the temple which was actually closed when we climbed a few stairs. The priests sitting there are rude and want your money, definitely not what a priest stands for. No one tells you that the actual temple is inaccessible. When I came down and asked the priest that why did he fool us into donating money even when the temple is closed, he got agitated and all the priests there formed a group, shouting and pushing us to leave the place. Very bad experience, not what I expect from a temple.

Tanah Lot is truly an amazing place with stunning views and a unique atmosphere. There are many temples here, though most are restricted for tourists. One of the main temples has a ship-like shape, and you need to pay an entry fee to go inside, where rituals are still maintained. The black rocks and cliffs against the ocean waves create an incredible scene � especially when the waves splash onto the rocks.
The entry ticket is around IDR 35,000. Be aware of a small �holy snake� attraction � they charge extra, but honestly, there isn�t much to see there. Walking around the area is very nice, and the sunset view is simply breathtaking � one of the best experiences in Bali.
Getting here from Kuta can take time because of heavy traffic, especially near the Finns Beach Club area, so plan your journey accordingly.
Overall, highly recommended for anyone visiting Bali!

Tanah Lot Temple � A Must-Visit Icon of Bali

Tanah Lot Temple is one of Bali�s most iconic landmarks, perched dramatically on a rocky outcrop along the western coast. Dedicated to the sea god Baruna, this sacred site offers a captivating blend of natural beauty, cultural heritage, and spiritual significance.

? Scenic Beauty & Gardens

The temple is surrounded by lush gardens and well-maintained pathways, providing visitors with a serene environment to explore. The landscape is dotted with traditional Balinese architecture, enhancing the cultural ambiance of the site.

? Boats & Tidal Access

At high tide, the temple appears to float on the ocean, creating a mesmerizing sight. While the temple itself is not accessible during this time, visitors can enjoy the view from the shore or opt for a boat ride to experience the temple from the water. It's advisable to check the tide schedule before planning your visit to make the most of this unique experience.

 Sunset Views

The temple is renowned for its breathtaking sunset views. As the sun sets over the Indian Ocean, the silhouette of the temple against the vibrant sky creates a magical atmosphere, making it a popular spot for photographers and romantics alike.

? Visitor Tips

Opening Hours: 7:00 AM � 7:00 PM

Entrance Fee: Approximately IDR 60,000 for international visitors

Dress Code: Modest clothing is required; a sarong and sash are recommended for temple entry

Best Time to Visit: Early morning for a tranquil experience or late afternoon to witness the stunning sunset

??? Accessibility

The temple is accessible by foot via a causeway during low tide. At high tide, access is limited, but the view from the shore remains spectacular. It's advisable to check the tide schedule before planning your visit to make the most of this unique experience.

 Final Thoughts

Tanah Lot Temple is a must-visit destination in Bali, offering a harmonious blend of natural beauty, cultural richness, and spiritual significance. Whether you're a history enthusiast, a nature lover, or someone seeking a peaceful retreat, Tanah Lot provides a memorable experience that captures the essence of Bali's charm.

Tanah Lot Temple, located in Tabanan Regency on Bali�s west coast, is a Hindu temple perched atop a rocky outcrop in the sea, world-famous for its sunsets. At low tide, visitors can walk to the base of the temple; at high tide, it appears as an island floating in the waves. As the sun sets over the Indian Ocean, the silhouette of the temple against the glowing sky and sea creates a breathtaking scene of gold and crimson hues. The surrounding area is lined with souvenir shops and food stalls, and traditional Balinese �Kecak� dance performances�complete with dramatic fire scenes�add to the cultural experience. Non-Hindus cannot enter the temple itself, but its sacred atmosphere can be felt from the outside. Changing tides and weather ensure that each visit offers a unique and memorable view.

Tanah Lot Temple in Bali is an absolutely breathtaking experience! Perched on a rocky outcrop overlooking the vast Indian Ocean, the temple offers some of the most stunning sunset views you�ll ever witness. The atmosphere is serene and spiritual, making it a perfect place for reflection and appreciating Bali�s rich culture. The pathways are well-maintained, and there are plenty of spots to relax, take photos, and enjoy the scenery. The sound of waves crashing against the rocks below adds to the peaceful ambiance. Local stalls nearby offer delicious Balinese snacks and souvenirs, adding to the experience. The temple�s architecture and its connection to ancient legends make it a must-visit destination. Whether you�re traveling solo, as a couple, or with family, Tanah Lot leaves you mesmerized with its beauty, charm, and tranquility. Highly recommend it to anyone visiting Bali!

Tanah Lot is a unique temple, build on the sea side, where you can enjoy a wonderfull setting. When the there is a high tide you cannot get close to the temple otherwise it is ok to enter (you might have to go past a few spots with sea water).
Once you enter the parking lot, you will be charged 75000IDR /pax.
After you enter the official area, you will pass by an art market where you can bargain some souvenirs. You also an ATM machine inside a grocery store (but this one charges around 2.5%, even on Revolut).
If are visiting Bali, I would strongly recommend a visit to Tanah Lot, and if happen to ve there late in the afternoon, you can also enjoy a nice sunset.
BTW, stop by Seminyak on your way to the temple...

Tanah Lot was the first temple we visited during our stay in Bali.  This visit set our expectations for temples here.

We really enjoyed the temple and the architecture there was amazing.  All the views were perfect. Unfortunately, we went in the morning during high tide and couldn't walk to the temple but that was fine.  I do think there is a fee to go there for the blessing ceremony though. I'm not sure how much. Based on our visit, we would recommend this to everyone.

One negative is that a Grab driver will drop you off at the ticket counter but couldn't do pick ups there.  We had to walk 10-15 minutes outside to a Circle K to get picked up.

Going back to expectations, this temple didn't require us to wear sarongs so we thought that the norm. All the temples we visited after that had us wear sarongs which was totally fine but I wonder why that was.  In addition, I loved that we didn't need to have a "guide" who forced us to tip him and could explore freely. We also loved that there was no one pressuring us to take photos or to buy things. In this regard, Besakih Temple was probably the worst.

All in all, we had a good time at Tanah Lot.

The final straw for me was they closed the main bathroom then made you pay 3,000 to use a traditional bathroom (ie hole with a bucket) with no water to wash your hands!  There are much nicer temples and sites of significance that are less over run with people and pushy vendors to visit in the Ubud area.  Also, beware that Grab/Gojek will take you to Tanah Lot but won�t pick you up, you have to pay twice the rate and get the on-site taxi to bring you back to Canggu.

Der eigentliche Tempel auf der Klippe vor der K�ste ist schon sehr beeindruckend.
Die Anlage auf der K�stenstreifen mit mit den gro�en Toranlagen, breiten Stra�en und Treppen ist zwar auch beeindruckend, aber auch ziemlich voll mit Gesch�ften und Touristen, obwohl wir schon vormittags dort gewesen sind.
Daf�r erschien mir die Anlage bedingt barrierefrei zu sein.

Pura ikonik dan destinasi wisata populer di Bali, terkenal karena posisinya yang megah di atas batu karang besar di tengah laut, menciptakan siluet indah saat matahari terbenam. Daya tarik utamanya meliputi pemandangan alam yang dramatis, arsitektur pura yang unik, serta atraksi budaya seperti pertunjukan Tari Kecak dan Gua Ular Suci, menjadikannya tempat wisata alam, budaya, dan spiritual yang tak terlupakan
Sempre fantastico, al cambio di marea... e ancora meglio nei momenti di calma dalla calca dei turisti.

To enter the tanah lot area you have to pay 75,000 rupiah per person. This is just for the area surrounding tanah lot, not tanah lot itself. We thought that was a bit strange. Tanah lot was very nice to see. To see such a temple in the water is definitely unique. However, we expected more of it. Maybe because we had already visited many other temples in bali and we thought those were more spectacular. We went up to the temple and a priest blessed us by letting us put 'holy' water on ourselves, putting some sort of rice on your forehead and putting a flower behind your ear. We paid 50,000 (you could give what you wanted) and then we could enter the temple. We thought we could see the whole temple, but you could only go up a little bit and the rest was closed off. You couldn't see anything of the temple. That was quite a scam. Overall, it was nice to see. It especially looked nice from a viewpoint further away and it was cool to walk on the rocks to the temple. We went there in the evening to eat and saw tanah lot. Then we went in the morning to really see it, there was a ceremony going on which was cool to see.

Sin duda, lo m�s recomendable es contemplarlo desde lejos, ya que la panor�mica completa con el oc�ano de fondo es impresionante.

Si la marea est� baja se puede caminar hasta el templo, pero la experiencia de observarlo desde la distancia merece mucho m�s la pena. El complejo es grande y cuenta con varios rincones interesantes para recorrer. Un lugar imprescindible en Bali.

The ticket price is undoubtedly good for this place.
The best way to get here is by scooter.
I also met guides who shared stories and guided tourists around.

Great views by the temple ND around the grounds. There are some restaurants up on the cliffs that over look the temple. There is also a market as you walk from the entrance to the temple.

Tanah Lot Temple in Bali captivates with its dramatic oceanfront location and stunning sunsets. This iconic sea temple offers a unique blend of natural beauty and spiritual significance, making it an unforgettable and must-visit destination for travelers seeking culture and breathtaking views.

Temple by the sea on a rocky outcrop.
Check the tide times so you aren't disappointed and take/wear suitable footwear.
If you chose to have a blessing from the holy men you'll need cold hard cash (to wash you're face in the holy spring, have some uncooked rice stuck on your forehead and a flower popped behind your ear).  There's also a holy snake (didn't contribute to see that!).
There is the usual collection of shops selling selling tourist tat and toilets at a charge - there is a free one by the car park if you can hold on!
No tickets required.

If you can see the sunset then only visit the temple otherwise there is nothing great to see other than the beach view that you can see anywhere in Bali.
The entry ticket is 75k IDR which is too much and I found it not worth the visit as there is a temple that you cannot visit inside.
It was cloudy when we visited so we couldn't see the sunset and the tides were so high that we were not able to go down.
The main highlight of this place sunset otherwise there is no point in visiting.

Beautiful temple and location but terrible experience getting a taxi out of the place. The locals won't let you get picked up anywhere in the area but the Grab app allows it. The locals police this like a gang with people on foot and scooters with walkie talkies and they will chase you and your drivers for kms along the road before you are allowed to get in any other forms of transport. It is very intimidating for women travelling on their own. Bear this in mind before you go!

We are all for supporting local, and donated cash even when not required, but as foreigners and women travelling on our own, we feel unsafe getting transport that isn't verified and tracked through a digital platform.

A must-visit temple in Bali!
Tanah Lot is a truly beautiful and unique temple. If the tide is low, you can walk across and explore the base of the temple, which is a special experience. However, it's important to know that access to the top of the temple is not allowed. Near the base, you'll find the sacred snake�make sure you see the real one in front of the temple on the sand. Be cautious, as there are other people nearby offering photos with snakes that are not the original.

There's also a small temple nearby that's worth a quick visit. The whole area is full of charm and spirituality. Around the temple, there's a market with lots of local souvenirs�bargaining is common and quite easy.

Highly recommended if you're in Bali!

After 1 month and a half in Bali I can confidently say that this place is the definitive tourist trap. The structure itself is not at all impressive when compared to other sites, and though its location on the water is picturesque you may not even be able to actually see the place. We went this morning and the tide was high, so there was no way to visit the temple. What you're left with in this case is a hundred shops selling the same turisty stuff and a hundred more overpriced restaurants.
I've seen many many places in Bali and I can tell you this: feel free to make this one the last in terms of priority.

If you ever come to Bali, don�t miss the chance to watch the sunset at Tanah Lot Temple. This temple stands majestically out in the sea, and during low tide, you can actually walk across the water to reach the rocky base where it sits. If you�re a bit nervous, don�t worry�friendly locals are there to help guide you across. You can also make a small donation and receive a blessing with holy water.

Afterward, head back to shore and find a spot along the nearby cliffside, where there are plenty of little shops and caf�s. Grab a drink, sit back, and watch the sun slowly dip below the horizon, painting the sky with beautiful colors. It�s the perfect moment to relax, feel the ocean breeze, and take in this unforgettable view.

Perched dramatically on a rocky outcrop off Bali�s southwestern coast, Tanah Lot Temple (Pura Tanah Lot) is more than a postcard-perfect landmark�it�s a spiritual beacon steeped in myth and natural majesty. As waves crash below and the sun melts into the horizon, this sea temple offers a sensory experience that transcends mere sightseeing.

Built in the 16th century by the revered priest Dang Hyang Nirartha, Tanah Lot is one of Bali�s seven sea temples, each positioned to form a spiritual chain along the coast. Dedicated to the sea god Dewa Baruna, the temple is believed to be guarded by venomous sea snakes that dwell in nearby caves�symbols of protection and mysticism that echo through Balinese lore.

At high tide, the temple appears to float on the ocean, its silhouette framed by foaming waves and golden light. During low tide, visitors can approach the base for a blessing ritual, though entry into the temple itself is restricted to worshippers. The surrounding cliffs and black volcanic sand beaches offer stunning vantage points, especially during sunset, when the sky ignites in hues of amber and rose.

The approach to Tanah Lot winds through a bustling market of souvenir stalls and warungs, adding a lively contrast to the temple�s serene aura. While the area can feel touristy, the spiritual ambiance remains intact�especially if you arrive early in the morning or linger into twilight.

The best time to visit is in the late afternoon to watch the sunset or in the early morning when it is quieter. There is an entrance fee for tourists, which is inexpensive and includes parking. Visitors are required to dress modestly; sarongs are available for rent at the entrance. Be sure to check the tide schedule if you plan to walk closer to the temple.

AVOID - A potentially great experience ruined by scammers and tourist traps.

I rarely bother writing a bad review. But if I can save anyone the trip, I�ll put this one out there.

It�s sad really. Because the temple itself is great to see, and timing sunset makes for a great view. Which is what will make you want to visit in the first place.

BUT, it�s one red flag after another.
First, there is one price for locals and another price for tourists.

Then (less of a red flag, but adds to the bad experience) entrance can only be paid for by cash. Something we were never told before making the trip. And then, the only ATM near? Inside the entrance. Not exactly helpful.

Then, to get to the temple you are forced down a street of classic tourist trap style mass production copies of local craftware.

You�ll find yourself dodging photo ops with snakes or fighting with other visitors for the few popular photo spots.

And then, if that�s not turned you away already, you�ll reach the steps of the temple. To which you�ll be told you must wash in the holy water (fair enough). Except once you do, you�ll be asked for a donation. Refuse to donate (or in our case, just not carry cash) and you�ll be refused entry - so the donation is more of a second entry fee. Or perhaps, just another scam.

There are plenty of temples in Bali. I�d suggest choosing one of the many others instead.

Tanah Lot, Bali - a picturesque temple perched majestically on a rock formation, surrounded by the crashing Indian Ocean waves. This ancient Hindu temple complex is a must-visit destination for any traveler to Bali.
The temple's stunning architecture and breathtaking ocean views make it a photographer's paradise. Witness the sunset here, and you'll be treated to a kaleidoscope of colors dancing across the sky.
Tanah Lot is steeped in history and mythology, adding a layer of cultural depth to your visit. Explore the surrounding areas, and you'll discover lush green landscapes, scenic hiking trails, and quaint souvenir shops.
Be prepared for crowds and vendors, but don't let that deter you - the experience is well worth it. As the sun dips into the ocean, Tanah Lot transforms into a magical setting, with the temple's silhouette set against a vibrant sky.
Rating: 4.5/5 stars. Worth a visit for its natural beauty and cultural significance

Tanah Lot Temple � A Must-Visit Coastal Gem in Bali

Tanah Lot is a breathtaking sea temple perched on a dramatic rock formation along the southwestern coast of Bali. One of the island�s most iconic landmarks, it�s especially popular during sunset for its stunning views.

While the main temple is currently undergoing renovation and entry inside is restricted, visitors can still explore the scenic surroundings, take memorable photos, and enjoy everything else the complex has to offer.

You can easily spend hours here wandering through the temple grounds, shopping for souvenirs, dining at oceanfront restaurants, and even spotting the sacred sea snake said to guard the temple.

Entrance Fee: IDR 75,000
Parking Fee: IDR 5,000

 Travel Tip:
To get the most out of your visit, use the "Best of Bali" app, which helps you explore all seven sea temples linked by spiritual legend, plan your route, and discover hidden gems nearby.

Even with limited access to the temple itself, Tanah Lot offers a rich cultural and visual experience that shouldn't be missed on your Bali itinerary.

If you are visiting Bali temples, this one has spectacular view during sunset

Tanah Lot Temple is a stunning sea temple in Bali, Indonesia, that's steeped in history and spirituality. Perched on a rocky outcrop, it's a breathtaking sight, especially during sunset when the sky transforms into a kaleidoscope of colors.

*Best Time to Visit:*

- Early morning for a peaceful and serene experience
- Late afternoon for the famous sunset spectacle
- Consider visiting during the dry season (April to October) for clear skies and optimal viewing conditions

*Things to Do:*

- *Explore the Temple Grounds*: Discover intricate carvings, statues, and beautifully crafted stone gates
- *Witness the Sunset*: A truly unforgettable experience with breathtaking views
- *Visit Batu Bolong Temple*: A nearby spiritual site with impressive views and a peaceful atmosphere
- *Participate in a Traditional Blessing*: Engage with Bali's rich spiritual heritage
- *Explore the Surrounding Market*: Find local crafts, souvenirs, and traditional snacks

*Practical Information:*

- *Entrance Fees*: IDR 75,000 (approximately $5 USD) for adults, IDR 40,000 (approximately $2.50 USD) for children
- *Opening Hours*: 7:00 AM � 7:00 PM daily, with 24-hour access for praying
- *Getting There*: About 20 kilometers from Kuta, 30 kilometers from Ngurah Rai International Airport, accessible by car, motorbike, or taxi

*Tips:*

- Arrive early to secure good viewing spots, especially during sunset
- Respect the temple's spiritual significance and dress modestly
- Consider hiring a local guide for deeper insights into the temple's history and culture �

Pura Tanah Lot (aksara Bali: ??????????) adalah salah satu Pura (Tempat Ibadah Umat Hindu) yang sangat disucikan di Bali, Indonesia. Nama Tanah Lot berasal dari kata "tanah" yang artinya tanah atau pulau dan "lot" atau lod yang artinya laut. Sehingga nama Tanah Lot dapat diartikan sebagai sebuah tanah atau pulau yang terletak di laut[1]. Di sini ada dua Pura yang terletak di atas batu besar. Satu terletak di atas bongkahan batu dan satunya terletak di atas tebing mirip dengan Pura Uluwatu. Pura Tanah Lot ini merupakan bagian dari Pura Dang Kahyangan. Pura Tanah Lot merupakan Pura laut tempat pemujaan dewa-dewa penjaga laut. Tanah Lot terkenal sebagai tempat yang indah untuk melihat matahari terbenam.

Also, some advice to those planning to visit here,

Advice 1:
Never take offer from those off app driver with green vest stating �Ojek Tanah Lot�. Gojek drivers are not allowed to enter Tanah Lot area (not sure till which part of the area). We visited Tanah Lot around 6:30 PM, hoping to see the famous temple of Lord Shiva. Upon arrival, we were stopped by some pujaris (priests) before entering. They performed a brief purification ritual�applying a tilak of rice and pouring Gangajal (holy water) on us. After the ritual, they asked for donations, which we gave in good faith.

However, we were disappointed to find out shortly after that the temple was already closed. Unfortunately, the pujaris did not inform us about this beforehand, which felt misleading, especially since they took donations knowing we wouldn�t be able to enter.

Despite this, the temple itself is beautiful and the setting is truly serene, with powerful waves crashing around the temple rock. It's a sight to behold and definitely worth visiting�but with better planning.

Tip for future visitors:
Make sure to go early in the day. Before participating in any rituals or giving donations, confirm whether the temple is open. This will help avoid disappointment and ensure you get the full spiritual and scenic experience Tanah Lot has to offer.

A Must-Visit Iconic Temple in Bali!
I recently visited Tanah Lot Temple in Bali, and it was truly an unforgettable experience. The temple itself is perched on a rock formation in the middle of the sea, creating a dramatic and beautiful sight�especially during high tide when it looks completely surrounded by water.

While visitors aren�t allowed to go inside the temple, the surrounding area is open for exploration and offers absolutely breathtaking views from every angle. The sea breeze, crashing waves, and the silhouette of the temple against the sky make it a photographer's dream.

Many people come here to catch the sunset, which I�ve heard is spectacular. Unfortunately, due to time constraints, we couldn�t make it.

The area around the temple is also filled with charming shops selling local crafts, souvenirs, and snacks. It's a great place to pick up some gifts or just enjoy browsing.

Overall, Tanah Lot is a must-see if you're in Bali. The natural beauty and cultural significance of the site make it a unique and memorable stop on any itinerary.

Entry is affordable, and the area is well-maintained considering how popular it is. I appreciated the local touches, from the traditional Balinese architecture to the offerings placed near the pathways. There are plenty of shops along the entrance path, selling everything from souvenirs to local snacks. It can feel a bit touristy, but it�s easy to see past that once you reach the coastline.

We tried some local food near the temple, and I was pleasantly surprised. The satay was fresh and nicely grilled�very flavorful. However, I didn�t enjoy the peanut sauce as much; I personally prefer the richer, slightly sweeter Malaysian-style version. The banana fritters were okay�crispy on the outside, soft inside, but nothing particularly special.

What really makes Tanah Lot worth visiting is the overall experience: the scenery, the cultural significance, and the peaceful energy of the place. It�s popular, yes, and can get crowded, especially during sunset�but with a little patience and the right timing, you�ll find moments of serenity and awe.

Highly recommend it for anyone visiting Bali. Just be sure to bring your camera, wear comfortable shoes, and maybe arrive a bit earlier than sunset to beat the crowds and soak in the full beauty of the place.

A must-visit cultural and scenic landmark in Bali! Tanah Lot is absolutely breathtaking, with the ocean. The coastal views are stunning, and the spiritual atmosphere adds a unique charm.

There are a couple of special experiences here � you can view the holy snake (for a fee) and receive spring water near the entrance in the ocean. The area is popular with tourists, so expect crowds, but it�s well-managed with lots of local shops and stalls along the way. A beautiful blend of nature, culture, and tradition � highly recommended!

An impressive temple in a unique seaside setting � definitely worth a visit. It's best to go before the tide comes in, and there were fewer tourists than expected. The view from the beach is fantastic, and in my opinion, it's best enjoyed from a distance.

Datang ke Pura Tanah Lot sekitar jam 10 pagi, sayangnya air laut sudah pasang jadi tidak bisa menyeberang ke area puranya. Tapi tetap tidak mengecewakan karena pemandangannya luar biasa indah. Banyak spot unik dan estetik untuk foto, cocok banget buat yang suka eksplor tempat-tempat ikonik di Bali. Saat saya datang, suasana cukup ramai, banyak wisatawan asing dan juga rombongan study tour dari sekolah.

Cuaca saat itu sangat terik, jadi sangat disarankan untuk membawa payung dan pakai sunscreen tebal agar tidak kepanasan. Tempat ini memang lebih nyaman dikunjungi saat pagi buta atau menjelang sunset, apalagi kalau ingin menikmati siluet pura dengan latar belakang matahari terbenam.

Meski tidak bisa masuk ke area pura karena pasang, suasana spiritual dan keindahan alam sekitar tetap terasa. Ada juga beberapa warung dan toko oleh-oleh di sekitar area parkir, cukup lengkap untuk sekadar beli minuman dingin atau suvenir. Secara keseluruhan, Pura Tanah Lot tetap jadi salah satu destinasi wajib kalau ke Bali, baik untuk wisata budaya maupun menikmati panorama laut yang menakjubkan.

Tanah Lot Temple is one of the most iconic and scenic spots in Bali. Built on a rock formation by the sea, this temple offers a unique and unforgettable view, especially during sunset. The fresh sea breeze and the sound of waves crashing against the rocks create a cool and calming atmosphere.

The landscape is simply stunning. As the tide rises, the temple appears to stand alone in the ocean, making it look mystical and powerful. Visitors can enjoy panoramic views of the coastline and take beautiful photos with the temple silhouette in the background.

Tanah Lot is not only a spiritual place but also a perfect destination to enjoy Bali�s natural beauty in a peaceful setting. A must-visit for anyone traveling to the island.

Tanah Lot, merupakan salah satu dari sedikit destinasi wisata pantai di Bali yang memiliki nuansa lebih tenang, syahdu dan "khidmat". Dibanding beberapa pantai lain yang lebih menawarkan "keriuhan" dan semarak keramaian.
Ketika mengunjungi Tanah Lot, kita masih bisa merasakan Bali yang alami, tidak terlalu banyak "tambahan-tambahan" demi menyenangkan pengunjung. Di tanah lot wisatawan lah yang mesti mengikuti "aura" yang telah tertanam disini.
Kesan hangat diantara sesama pengunjung sangat terasa disini; interaksi hangat, sapaan-sapaan kecil sering muncul diantara pengunjung yang bahkan baru ketemu. Penjual aneka asesoris dan oleh-oleh juga "melayani" dengan hangat

Tanah Lot adalah sebuah pura Hindu yang terletak di atas batu besar di pantai selatan Bali, Indonesia. Berikut beberapa ulasan tentang Tanah Lot:

Keunikan dan Keindahan
- Terletak di atas batu besar yang unik dan indah, membuat Tanah Lot menjadi salah satu ikon pariwisata Bali.
- Menawarkan pemandangan sunset yang spektakuler dengan siluet pura yang dramatis.
- Arsitektur pura yang khas dan suci bagi umat Hindu.

Sejarah dan Legenda
- Didirikan pada abad ke-15 oleh Dang Hyang Nirartha, seorang brahmana yang menyebarkan agama Hindu di Bali.
- Menurut legenda, Dang Hyang Nirartha memindahkan batu besar ke laut dengan kekuatan spiritual dan membangun pura di atasnya.
- Pura ini dipercaya sebagai tempat pemujaan dewa-dewa penjaga laut.

Aktivitas Wisata
- Mengunjungi pura dan menikmati keindahan arsitektur serta pemandangan sekitar.
- Berjalan-jalan di sepanjang pantai dan menikmati sunset.
- Membeli souvenir dan makanan khas Bali di sekitar pura.

Informasi Praktis
- Alamat: Desa Beraban, Kecamatan Kediri, Kabupaten Tabanan, Bali.
- Waktu terbaik berkunjung: Sore hari untuk menikmati sunset.
- Tiket masuk: Tersedia untuk wisatawan domestik dan asing,

Pros
1. Great views
2. Many restaurants and eateries on site
3. Great place for sunset, if you are lucky
4. There is a natural bridge

Considerations
1. The temple could get super crowded on religious days. Please avoid visiting here on festivals unless you like to explore the local culture.
2. The temple road and the whole area gets choked because almost all tours leave at the same time.

Visited Tanah Lot at sunset today and it was amazing. This is one of the sea temples in Bali which is devoted to Dewa Bahruna. Visiting during sunset means you will also get to see the local culture where the people in locality visit the temple for poojas with white dresses and offerings which they carry on the head. You won't be able to enter the temple but you can see it from the viewpoints. Entry to the temple area which covers other temples and kecek dances costs IDR75k and can be bought at gate. Highly recommended!

Tourist trap - littered with shops from the entrance to the main temple.
Not much of a temple, definitely not a Hindu temple.  AS a devoted Hindu, I was disallowed access to enter the main temple.  But the temple authority had no problems taking money from us on the entrance.
It seem they try to price gouge at every angle if you're not careful.
When you go to get "purified" with the holy water, they ask for a donation, and then at the temple entrance, they tell you the temple is only open to balenese nationals.
At this point, I'm confused about if balenese hinduism is a religious or a nationality concept.
This is definitely not Hinduism. It seems more like a marketing spin on what they think Hinduism is supposed  to be like. No wonder  Bali feels like a 3rd world island... with unexpected power cuts.

Tanah Lot Temple is one of Bali's most iconic heritage sites and an absolute must-visit!  Nestled on a rock formation by the sea, the temple offers breathtaking sunset views that are serene and soul-soothing. The spiritual vibe, the sound of waves crashing against the cliffs, and the temple�s silhouette at dusk make it a magical experience.

The surrounding area is great for local street shopping too. You'll find plenty of stalls selling souvenirs, handicrafts, and clothes. Just remember � bargaining is a must here! You can often get items at half the quoted price with a friendly negotiation.

Whether you're into cultural exploration, spiritual tranquility, or just want that perfect sunset Instagram shot � Tanah Lot has it all. Highly recommended for all kinds of travelers.

Tip: Visit in the evening for the sunset, and wear comfortable shoes for walking through the market area.

Tanah Lot adalah salah satu tempat paling ikonik di Bali yang wajib dikunjungi! Tempat ini terkenal dengan pura yang berada di atas batu besar, tepat di tepi laut. Pemandangan matahari terbenam di sini luar biasa indah, sangat cocok untuk foto-foto atau sekadar menikmati keindahan alam.

Selain itu, suasana sekitar Tanah Lot juga sangat tenang, dengan banyak warung yang menyediakan makanan dan minuman untuk menemani waktu santaimu. Kamu bisa menikmati pemandangan laut yang memukau sambil mencicipi kuliner lokal.

Satu hal yang pasti, Tanah Lot punya aura yang magis, apalagi saat gelombang laut menyapu batuan di sekitar pura. Bagi yang suka sejarah dan budaya, pura Tanah Lot juga memiliki nilai spiritual tinggi bagi masyarakat Bali.

Pura Tanah Lot adalah salah satu pura laut paling ikonik dan suci di Bali, terletak di atas batu karang besar di tepi pantai Desa Beraban, Kecamatan Kediri, Kabupaten Tabanan. Pura ini sangat terkenal karena keindahan matahari terbenamnya dan letaknya yang seolah berada di tengah laut saat air pasang.

Asal-usul dan Sejarah Pura Tanah Lot
1.	Dibangun oleh Dang Hyang Nirartha (abad ke-16)
�	Sejarah Pura Tanah Lot erat kaitannya dengan perjalanan seorang pendeta suci dari Jawa Timur bernama Dang Hyang Nirartha (juga dikenal sebagai Danghyang Dwijendra).
�	Saat melakukan perjalanan suci menyebarkan ajaran Hindu di Bali, beliau tiba di pantai Beraban dan merasakan kekuatan spiritual yang sangat kuat di atas batu karang di laut.
�	Beliau kemudian bermeditasi di tempat tersebut dan menyarankan kepada penduduk setempat untuk membangun pura pemujaan Dewa Baruna (dewa laut) di tempat itu.
2.	Konflik dengan Penguasa Lokal
�	Kepala desa saat itu, yang menentang ajaran Dang Hyang Nirartha, mencoba mengusirnya.
�	Menurut legenda, beliau memindahkan batu tempat beliau bermeditasi ke tengah laut hanya dengan kekuatan spiritual, dan menciptakan ular penjaga dari selendangnya.
�	Ular itu masih dipercaya hidup di gua sekitar pura dan dianggap sebagai penjaga suci pura.
3.	Makna Nama
�	�Tanah Lot� berasal dari kata �Tanah� (daratan) dan �Lot� atau �Lod� (laut), yang secara harfiah berarti �Daratan di Tengah Laut�.

Fungsi dan Spiritualitas
�	Tanah Lot merupakan salah satu dari enam pura sad kahyangan (pura utama penjaga arah mata angin di Bali).
�	Pura ini adalah tempat pemujaan kepada Dewa Baruna atau Bhatara Segara, dewa penguasa laut.
�	Masyarakat Bali datang untuk sembahyang, memohon keselamatan dan berkah dari laut.

Ciri Khas dan Daya Tarik
�	Terletak di atas batu besar di laut, akan terpisah dari daratan saat air pasang.
�	Terdapat gua dengan ular suci yang dipercaya sebagai penjaga pura.
�	Spot matahari terbenam yang sangat terkenal, menjadikan Tanah Lot destinasi wisata utama.

Kalau kamu tertarik, aku juga bisa bantu jelaskan legenda ular penjaga Tanah Lot lebih detail, atau upacara keagamaan yang biasa dilakukan di sana. Mau?

Tanah Lot is an ancient Hindu pilgrimage temple founded on rock in Bali. It is a very large peaceful area where temples, beautiful gardens, and walks hug the sea coast. Visitar Tanah Lot es una experiencia que despierta todos los sentidos y conecta profundamente con la espiritualidad balinesa. Al acercarte al templo, el sonido r�tmico de las olas rompiendo contra la base rocosa crea una sinfon�a natural que acompa�a tu caminata. La vista del templo, encaramado majestuoso sobre una formaci�n rocosa en el mar, es simplemente impresionante, especialmente al atardecer cuando el cielo se pinta de tonos dorados y naranjas, ofreciendo un espect�culo visual inolvidable.

Antes de llegar al templo, muchos visitantes optan por participar en un ritual de purificaci�n en las fuentes sagradas cercanas. Este ritual es una oportunidad para sumergirse en la cultura local, donde el agua bendita se utiliza para limpiar el cuerpo y el esp�ritu, prepar�ndote para la experiencia espiritual que te espera. La sensaci�n del agua fresca sobre la piel, combinada con el aroma del incienso y las flores, crea un ambiente de paz y renovaci�n.

Al cruzar hacia el templo, sientes una conexi�n profunda con la historia y la tradici�n que han perdurado a lo largo de los siglos. Tanah Lot no es solo un lugar de belleza natural, sino un s�mbolo de la resistencia y la fe balinesa. La experiencia de estar all�, rodeado por el mar y la espiritualidad, es verdaderamente transformadora, dejando una huella imborrable en el coraz�n de cada visitante.

Marvel at the stunning Tanah Lot Temple, just north of Densapar, on a guided tour in Bali. Admire the imposing rock formation the temple sits upon and learn about its ancient history. Explore the sacred complex and discover the charming stalls around it. Tanah Lot is one of seven ocean temples in Bali and has been a center of mythology for centuries. This Hindu temple, dedicated to the Gods of the sea and dates back to the 16th century, holds much significance for locals but is now just as well loved by visitors to the island. It�s an ideal place to relax and admire the skies change color against the backdrop of the ocean, with Tanah Lot standing proudly at the forefront. So come and spend time exploring the temple and its dramatic surroundings, and learn about the rich history of Tanah Lot and its religious beliefs here. Many local market stalls also surround Tanah Lot temple. Wander around the area's nearby shops that offer handmade trinkets, Balinese instruments, textiles, and more.

? Rainy Experience � Since the rain didn�t stop, we eventually rented an umbrella, which is readily available there.
? Scenic Beauty � Despite the rain, the place looked stunning, adding to the experience.

Final Thoughts
Although the rain limited our time, the overall experience was great. If visiting during the rainy season, be prepared with raincoats or umbrellas!

Was supposed to be a beautiful place to visit full of the history of how Bali�s religion was built, however most (95%) of the temple in the �island� is not visitable when you go which combined to the amount of tourists may create an unpleasant visit. When leaving the temple make sure to not return with the taxi drivers available, we had an awful experience with those who run the area as a monopoly to overcharge unaware tourists. Instead go with Grab or Gojek, just walk along the main road until the first gate you pass by when entering by car and order your car there. Otherwise the taxi drivers will come angry and not let your pickup car leave (we had 8 of those coming by and making us leave our car to then walk 200m to a �pickup stop� they decided)

The place is absolutely breathtaking! Imagine lush green gardens surrounded by the sparkling sea�it's the perfect spot for a picnic with your loved ones. Nestled on a rock away from the main temple, you'll find the Pura Batu Bolong, a stunning temple steeped in mystery. It's said to be protected by a legendary divine snake god, adding an air of intrigue to the whole experience. While you're enjoying the beauty of the sea, don't miss out on this sacred site! Just a heads-up�both temples are still active and used for prayers, so be sure to show respect and dress appropriately. Stay until sunset, and you'll be treated to a mesmerizing view as the sun dips into the ocean, creating a scene you won�t soon forget.

This is an absolute beauty ! Yes it was spoiled by the tourists not throwing away their litter as we saw remnants of plastic etc but the actual site was lovely. Very reasonable price to enter (100 IDR) and donation points throughout. Lots of photo ops and places to grab a drink and bargain.

Tanah lot dianggap suci oleh umat Hindu Bali. Terdiri dari 2 pura yang ada di batuan laut serta pinggir tebing. Tanah Lot artinya batuan di temgah lautan. Digunakan untuk menghormati dewa di lautan dan sampai sekarang masih untuk ibadah, terutama Galungan dan Kuningan. Sejarahnya dulu,  abad ke -15, Bagawan Dang Hyang Niratha atau dikenal dengan nama Dang Hyang Dwijendra, brahmana dari Jawa menyebarkan agama Hindu ke pulau Bali yang disambut baim Raja Dalem Waturenggong. Namun bandesa Beraban Tabanan menolak. Hingga sang begawan memindahkan karang ke tengah laut hingga dikenal tanah lot, dan meninggalkan keris yang bisa mengobati sakit. Akhirnya seluruh penduduk percaya. Sampai sekarang keris di simpan di Pura Kediri dan pura tanah lot masih kokoh berdiri. Sedangkan di bawah tebing pura yang satu terdapat goa ular suci yang dikisahkan dari selendang samg brahmana. Ombak disini besar, bahkan jika pasang ombaknya, maka akses ke goa tertutup dan tangga untuk menyeberang ke tanah lot tidak tampak. Hati-hati jika pasang, HTM cukup 15ribu. Menuju lokasi sudah banyak kali lima cindermata dan jajanan serta pakaian, tak kalah juga cafe dan konter terkenal lainnya. Dari Kuta sekitar 1 jam. #literasyikgalih #kilasdokumenter @galih.wib

Instead, you�re funneled into a mandatory �purification� ritual that requires additional donations, only to climb a few steps and be met with a locked gate. Tanah Lot Temple
It means Land in The Sea, an ancient Hindu Shrine that sits on a rocky island just off the coast. It's been around for more than 400 years.

This place is definitely a must come, the view and feel is out of the world. The sun, the wind, the sea, the holy place makes everything so magical here.

Make sure to cut half price or slightly more for everything. (Except food)

Tanah Lot adalah salah satu pura laut yang terkenal di Bali, didirikan pada abad ke-16 oleh Dang Hyang Nirartha, seorang pendeta Hindu dari Jawa. Selama perjalanannya menyebarkan agama Hindu di Bali, beliau tiba di sebuah pantai di Desa Beraban, Tabanan, dan merasakan energi spiritual yang kuat di tempat tersebut.
Beliau kemudian membangun pura di atas batu karang yang menjorok ke laut sebagai tempat pemujaan kepada dewa-dewa laut.

Nama "Tanah Lot" berasal dari kata "Tanah" yang berarti daratan atau pulau, dan "Lot" yang berarti laut. Secara harfiah, Tanah Lot berarti
"pulau kecil di tengah laut".

Tapi jadi punya memori lain soal wisata di Bali yg biasanya terik, ini tumbenan ketemu hujan angin. Harga oleh2 yg dijual di toko2 sekitar ataupun pedagang kelilingnya juga wajar menurutku, bukan yg mahal bgt cuma karena ini kawasan wisata. Pura Ulun Danu Bratan adalah sebuah pura dan candi air besar di Bali - candi utama air lainnya menjadi Pura Ulun Danu Batur. Kompleks pura ini terletak di tepi barat Danau Bratan di pegunungan dekat Bedugul, tepatnya di Desa Candikuning, Kecamatan Baturiti, Kabupaten Tabanan.
Komplek pura ini menjadi tempat tujuan wisata yang sangat diminati baik wisatawan mancanegara maupun domestik. Selain menikmati keindahan alam, keindahan pura, keindahan danau kita juga bisa menyusuri danau dengan menyewa motor air. Bisa melihat dan memberi makan ikan yang dibuat sangat indah ada jembatan diantara air, sayang saat saya berkunjung hujan gak bisa sepenuhnya menikmati. Jika ingin layaknya penduduk bali atau bangsawan bali bisa menyewa baju adat untuk photo atau berjalan jalan menikmati suasana Ulun Danu. Ntuk masuk tetap membeli tiket terlebih dahulu Ro. 50.000/orang.
Parkir cukup luas, fasilitas toilet juga tempat makan atau restoran. Bisa juga menyewa jada tukang photo agar hasil pohotonya bagus.
Sungguh mencapai tempat ini adalah yang terbaik di dalam hidupku. Momen ini saat berjalan-jalan liburan bersama istri tercinta.

Ulun Danu Beratan Temple � A Magical & Serene Experience

Ulun Danu Beratan Temple is truly one of the most breathtaking places in Bali. The moment you arrive, the cool mountain air and stunning lakeside setting make you feel calm and refreshed. The temple floating on Lake Beratan is absolutely picture-perfect � peaceful, spiritual and incredibly scenic.

The grounds are beautifully maintained, with vibrant gardens, clear pathways and plenty of spots to enjoy the view. Even with visitors around, the atmosphere remains serene and respectful.

It�s a wonderful place to learn about Balinese culture, enjoy nature and take unforgettable photos. Highly recommend visiting early in the morning for the best lighting and a quieter experience.

A must-visit spiritual and cultural gem in Bali!

??? Pura Ulun Danu Beratan, Bali: A Serene Morning Visit
?We visited the iconic Pura Ulun Danu Beratan early in the morning, which was an excellent decision! The complex was wonderfully peaceful and less crowded, allowing us to fully appreciate the serene beauty of the setting.

?? The Stunning Scenery
?The temple's location on the shores of Lake Beratan is breathtaking, especially with the surrounding hills shrouded in mist and clouds, as seen in the wide-angle photo . This misty atmosphere added a magical, almost mystical quality to the landscape.

?The most famous structure, the Pura Penataran Agung or the 11-tiered Meru (pagoda), standing partially submerged in the lake, was the highlight. It is a stunning sight, perfectly framed by the water and the distant green hills. Another smaller Meru is also visible, and the overall temple grounds are beautifully maintained with vibrant flowers and greenery .

? Garden and Entryway Attractions
?Before reaching the main lake temple, the entrance area features beautiful, manicured gardens. There is a prominent stone sign that reads "Ulun Danu Beratan BALI" alongside a traditional tower replica and a large, colorful Koi fish fountain shooting water into the air. This area provides a great photo opportunity and welcomes visitors.
?We also walked through the elegant stone paths leading to other temple pavilions and courtyards, like the one seen in the photo . The architectural details, framed by neat lawns and flower beds, were impressive and provided a deeper look into the temple complex's design.

? Recommendation: Go Early!
?I highly recommend visiting Pura Ulun Danu Beratan as early as possible. Our morning timing meant we avoided the mid-day rush, resulting in a tranquil experience and fantastic, atmospheric photos. The cool, crisp air is also a welcome change from the coastal heat. The earlier you arrive, the more likely you are to capture the beautiful fog rolling over the lake and mountains.

Visiting Ulun Danu Beratan Temple was one of the most peaceful and memorable experiences of my Bali trip. The setting is absolutely breathtaking � the temple looks like it's floating on the lake, surrounded by calm waters and mist-covered mountains. It truly feels like a scene from a postcard, especially during the early morning when the light is soft and there�s a gentle fog on the water.

The temple grounds are beautifully maintained, with lush gardens, colorful flowers, and scenic walkways that make the whole place feel very serene. What I loved most is how the spiritual atmosphere and natural beauty blend so perfectly. Even with other tourists around, there's a sense of calm and tranquility that makes you pause and just appreciate the moment.

There are several quiet sitting spots near the lake where you can relax and take in the view. I also enjoyed reading the signs explaining the cultural and religious significance of the temple � it's dedicated to the water goddess, which adds a deeper meaning to its stunning lakeside location.

The locals were friendly and respectful, and the facilities including parking, restrooms, and small caf�s were well-organized. I would highly recommend visiting early in the morning to beat the crowds and capture some stunning photos. Definitely a must-visit landmark in Bali!

Ulun Danu (Indonesian: Pura Ulun Danu Bratan) is a large Hindu temple in the Bedugul district, Tabanan Regency, Bali, Indonesia. The temple is located on the shores of Lake Bratan. This and smaller water temples help to irrigate the land.The structure was built in 1633. The temple is used for sacrifices to Dewi Danu, the goddess of water, rivers, and lakes.
The 11-tiered tower is dedicated to the deity Shiva and his consort Parvati. The temple also houses a statue of Buddha and a stupa.
The temple is also called the Water Temple because at high tide, it appears to be floating on water.
The Bali Botanical Garden is located nearby on the mountain slopes. You may reach the temple with tourist coaches or private tour cars only

Pura Ulun Danu Bratan is a Hindu Temple built on the shores of Lake Bratan and personally it�s the one I liked the most during my visit to Bali. It was built in 1633 and it�s dedicated to the Balinese water goddess Dewi Danu. The most iconic picture of this place is the �Pelinggih Meru� on the lake, the pagoda-like shrine with multi-level thatched roof, but aside from that all the complex is really beautiful with its neat garden full of flowers and statues.

breathtaking temple and one of the most iconic spots in Bali. The location on Lake Beratan gives it a magical atmosphere, as if the temple is floating. Surrounded by mountains, fresh air and beautifully kept gardens, it�s a very serene place to walk around.
We enjoyed visiting in the morning when the water is calm and the light is soft � it�s also less crowded. The site is clean, organized, and there are plenty of spots for photos without feeling rushed.
Even though it�s a quick visit, the peaceful atmosphere and unique scenery make it an absolute must-see in the Bedugul area.

Ulun Danu Beratan Temple is one of those places that just takes your breath away. The temples seem to float right on the lake with the mist rolling down from the mountains � it�s picture-perfect. But can be lots of people at various times.  The gardens are well maintained and full of colour, with temples, shrines, and statues, and even a quiet Buddhist stupa tucked away in the gardens. .

We noticed many people wandering through just taking photos, but not realising how much meaning and history this place holds. Its literally thousands of years old.  so crazy.   We used the Voicemap app for a self-guided audio tour, and it honestly made such a difference � it explained the stories behind the temples, the goddess of the lake, the central temple story floating in the lake, which is quite amazing, and why this Temple is so important to Balinese life.  We would recommend this App if you're travelling without a guide, or if you're guide stays in the car like many do, whilst you walk through.  Its so worth it

Go early when it�s calm and the light hits the water � it�s just magic. Understanding what you�re seeing makes it all feel even more special.  From there we then drove to Jatiluwih Rice Fields which are not far away, so saw two great places in one day.

Our visit to Ulun Danu Beratan Temple was truly a memorable experience. The temple's stunning location on the shores of Lake Beratan offers breathtaking views, especially with the misty mountains in the background. The architecture of the temple is intricate and beautifully preserved, reflecting Balinese culture and spirituality. Walking around the temple complex, I felt a sense of tranquility and reverence. The surrounding gardens are well-maintained and add to the peaceful atmosphere.

While the area can get quite crowded, especially during peak hours, it didn�t detract from the overall beauty of the site. The staff was friendly and respectful, and I appreciated the opportunity to learn about the temple�s significance to local Balinese Hindus. One minor downside was the limited shade in some areas, so it�s best to visit early in the morning or later in the afternoon to avoid the heat.

Overall, Ulun Danu Beratan is a must-visit destination in Bali, offering both cultural insight and stunning scenery. I would definitely recommend it to anyone exploring Bali's spiritual sites!

Pura Ulun Danu Beratan, often called the "Floating Temple," is an ethereal masterpiece nestled high in the cool, misty Bedugul mountains on the serene shores of Lake Beratan. This temple complex is a profound departure from Bali's bustling coastal temples, offering a tranquil, deeply spiritual experience that easily warrants a five-star rating. It�s a place where nature and architecture blend into a single, breathtaking illusion.
?The main attraction is the iconic multi-tiered Meru shrine, which appears to float when the lake water is high, reflecting perfectly on the still, glassy surface. The backdrop of verdant mountains and the cool, fresh air creates an atmospheric scene that is often shrouded in a spectacular, slow-moving mist�especially in the early morning. This provides not only a perfect photo opportunity (the site is even featured on the Indonesian Rp 50,000 banknote) but also a truly peaceful moment of contemplation.
?Historically and spiritually, the temple is indispensable to Balinese life. It is dedicated to Dewi Danu, the goddess of water, lakes, and rivers, and serves as the primary water temple for the entire subak (irrigation) system in central Bali. Worshippers come here to ensure agricultural prosperity and stable water supplies. Furthermore, the complex famously contains a small Buddhist Stupa alongside its Hindu shrines, an unusual and beautiful testament to the religious harmony and syncretism found in Balinese culture.
?Beyond the main floating shrines, the surrounding complex features beautifully manicured gardens, smaller shrines dedicated to other deities, and peaceful walking paths. Visiting Pura Ulun Danu Beratan is an essential journey into the heartland of Bali, revealing the island's deep connection to nature and water. It is a stunning, calming, and culturally rich must-see.

Udara di sana terasa suci�dingin namun menenangkan, seperti doa yang turun bersama embun pagi. Di tepian danau, pura Ulun Danu berdiri anggun, pantulannya di air bagai cermin antara bumi dan langit. Pura Ulun Danu Beratan, located in the cool highlands of Bedugul, feels like something out of a dream. This water temple sits quietly on Lake Beratan, its reflection shimmering on the surface like a painting. Surrounded by mountains and mist, the whole scene feels calm and sacred, a perfect place to slow down and breathe deeply.

Walking along the lakeside, I could feel the fresh air brushing against my face, so different from the heat of southern Bali. The temple itself seems to float on the water, almost as if it�s part of the lake.

The temperature difference in the mountainous areas of Bali is also quite large. When the driver took us up the mountain, it started to fog up and the temperature dropped a lot. It is recommended to bring a jacket or warm clothes with you.

Ulun Danu Beratan Temple � The Floating Beauty of Bali

Visiting Ulun Danu Temple was like stepping into a postcard. Set right on the edge of Lake Beratan in Bedugul, the temple looks as if it�s floating on water, especially when the mist rolls over the lake � it�s absolutely breathtaking. The reflection of the temple on the calm surface of the water creates a magical, almost dreamlike scene that you�ll never forget. 

The whole place is peaceful and filled with positive energy. Surrounded by mountains and cool fresh air, it�s a perfect escape from the heat of South Bali. We reached early in the morning, and the fog around the temple made it feel mystical and calm. The sound of gentle waves, the temple bells, and the soft chanting in the background created a truly spiritual atmosphere.

There are plenty of photo spots, gardens, and even small boats that you can rent to go around the lake for a closer view of the temple. The area is well maintained, clean, and family friendly. We also enjoyed a warm coffee at a nearby caf� overlooking the temple � such a peaceful moment!

Overall, Ulun Danu Beratan Temple is a must-visit for anyone traveling to Bali. Whether you�re interested in culture, photography, or just soaking in nature�s beauty, this place perfectly captures the spirit of Bali � calm, spiritual, and absolutely stunning. ?

Ulun Danu Beratan Temple is truly one of the most breathtaking places to visit in Bali. Set on the shores of the serene Lake Beratan in Bedugul, this floating temple offers a magical and peaceful experience that feels almost otherworldly. The moment you arrive, the cool mountain air and misty surroundings make it a refreshing escape from Bali�s coastal heat. The temple�s reflection on the calm lake water creates a postcard-perfect scene that�s simply mesmerizing.

The temple complex is beautifully maintained, with lush gardens, colorful flowers, and scenic pathways that add to the charm. It�s a perfect spot for photography � especially in the early morning when the mist floats over the lake and the temple looks like it�s levitating. You can also rent small boats to explore the lake and get closer views of the temple from the water.

Besides its beauty, Ulun Danu Beratan holds deep spiritual significance as it�s dedicated to Dewi Danu, the goddess of water, making it an important site for Balinese Hindus. The surrounding area also has local food stalls, souvenir shops, and a small park, making it a pleasant half-day trip. Overall, it�s a must-visit attraction in Bali that beautifully blends natural beauty, spirituality, and culture. ?

One of the most beautiful and iconic landmarks in Bali. Located on the shores of Lake Beratan in Bedugul, this floating temple offers stunning scenery surrounded by cool mountain air and peaceful nature. The temple itself sits partly on the lake, creating a magical reflection that�s perfect for photos. The area is well-maintained, with gardens, statues, and traditional Balinese architecture that showcase the island�s culture and spirituality. It�s best to visit early in the morning when the mist rises over the lake � the atmosphere feels serene and almost mystical. There are also local food stalls, restaurant, souvenir shops. Beautiful lake and mountain backdrop. Peaceful and spiritual atmosphere. Great spot for photography. Cool climate and well-kept gardens. A must-visit destination for anyone traveling to Bali, perfect for culture lovers and nature enthusiasts alike.

The Ulun Danu Beratan Temple (also known as Pura Ulun Danu Bratan) is widely considered one of Bali's most beautiful and iconic landmarks. It is having stunning natural setting, spiritual significance, and picturesque architecture, though some also note its popularity as a tourist destination.

Stunning Location and Scenery:
The temple is set on the tranquil shores of Lake Bratan in the cool, misty
Bedugul highlands.
The multi-tiered shrines (meru) appear to be floating on the water's surface, especially when the lake level is high, making it one of the most photographed spots in Indonesia.

Aesthetic and Photogenic: The combination of the temple, the lake's reflection, the lush manicured gardens, and the mountain backdrop creates a truly spectacular and "must-see" visual experience. It's often referred to as the "floating temple of Bali."

Spiritual Significance: It is an important Hindu water temple dedicated to Dewi Danu, the goddess of water, rivers, and lakes, and plays a vital role in Bali's traditional *subak* irrigation system.

Cooler Weather: Located about 1,200 meters above sea level, the area offers a refreshing break from the heat of the coastal regions.

Accessibility: The grounds are generally well-maintained and easy for all types of visitors, including families and older travelers, to explore.

Best Time to Visit: To avoid the crowds and the mist/fog that can roll in during the afternoon, it is highly recommended to visit early in the morning (around 7:00 AM to 9:00 AM). This also provides the best lighting for photos.

Cash Only:Entrance fees and payments at many local stalls require cash.

Boat Rides:For a unique view, visitors can take a traditional boat ride on Lake Beratan.

The general consensus is that despite being a popular tourist spot, the sheer beauty of the temple's setting makes it absolutely worth visiting for anyone exploring central Bali.

My visit to temple in Bali was a pleasant experience. The temple stands on the edge of Lake Beratan in Bedugul and looks like it is floating on the water. Surrounded by green mountains and cool air, the place feels very calm. The temple is dedicated to the goddess of lakes and rivers. Its tall pagoda-style roofs and neat gardens make it very attractive. We also enjoyed the view of the lake. It is a peaceful and must-visit spot in Bali.

What a disappointment. I came for the temple, which, yes, is gorgeous. But you admire it for a minute and then..? The commercial theme park really ruines the vibe: there are 3 big food courts, a playground and for an extra fee you rent a (pedal boat), feed or take pictures with captivated animals (please don't pay for exploitation) or feed koi fish in the pond.

There are better ways to spend your money and enjoy the true Bali

Ahh, what a place Ulun Danu Temple is! 

I feel a lot of people miss this spot since it�s about an hour�s ride from Ubud central and not overly hyped on Instagram. But believe me, it�s an absolute must-visit when in Bali.

The drive itself is beautiful, and once you reach, the entire temple complex and grounds are just stunning. Everything feels serene and picture-perfect.

Easy logistics � paid parking & smooth ticketing.

Weather drama � it changes every few minutes! One moment it was bright and sunny, and the next it turned misty, foggy, and drizzly.

Photography heaven � Balinese gates, lush landscapes, and the iconic temple floating on the lake make for unreal backdrops.

There are also nice, reasonably priced restaurants inside the premises, and the washrooms are clean and well-maintained (paid). You can even rent Balinese outfits for a photoshoot � sadly I missed this due to the rain.

I loved every bit of it.
Tip: Go prepared for sudden weather shifts and give yourself enough time to just soak in the beauty.

A must-visit, one of Bali�s gems.
