A Spiritual Place Turned Into a Money-Making Machine - Avoid!

This temple has completely lost its cultural and spiritual soul, transforming into a cynical money-making machine. While the Ulun Danu Beratan Temple is architecturally beautiful and the lakeside setting is picturesque, the overall experience is now cheapened, stressful, and deeply unethical.

We visited early in the morning to avoid the crowds, which we recommend only for a clearer photo opportunity, as any sense of tranquility is quickly shattered. The temple grounds have been filled with various structures, props, and stalls that have more in common with a funfair or a county fair than a sacred site. The spiritual atmosphere has been replaced by the feeling of a commercial enterprise designed to extract money at every turn.

The most egregious offense, however, is the unacceptable "mini-zoo." The conditions in which the animals are kept are heartbreaking. The enclosures are small, barren, and utterly unsuitable, representing blatant animal neglect. Using these sentient beings as a tourist attraction to generate extra income is morally reprehensible and casts a permanent shadow over the entire complex.

Between the carnival-like atmosphere and the disturbing animal exhibits, the temple has forfeited its integrity. The 75,000 IDR entrance fee feels like you are funding this exploitation, not preserving a cultural site.

I cannot recommend a visit to this temple. It is a stark example of how commercialization can destroy a place's sanctity. Avoid this place entirely until the management removes the animal exhibits and refocuses on preserving the site's cultural dignity rather than its revenue streams.

user_name: Juli Mdj Bali Tour organizer and travel

review_text:
I wanted to leave feedback on the official website but it wasn�t working, so I am sharing it here instead.

The temple itself is beautiful, but my experience at the motorcycle parking area was very disappointing. I parked my bike neatly near the ticketing entrance, where there was no visible sign saying �staff only.� A security guard told me to move, saying the shaded area is for staff while visitors must park far away under the hot sun.

Here�s the issue:

1. The �staff only� sign is at the back of the parking lot, not at the entrance. By the time visitors see it, they�ve already parked. This makes no sense. A clear sign should be placed right where people enter.

2. Visitors pay both entrance and parking fees, yet staff get the shaded, convenient spots while visitors are pushed to the far end without shade.

I recorded a short video to highlight this, but the guard told me not to take it. Instead of addressing the issue, he told me to �respect� and even said I cannot change another country as I like. This left me confused � I was only giving constructive feedback about signage and fairness. Why should that be treated as disrespect?

I also uploaded photos of the guard so management can identify who was involved. This is not a personal attack, but evidence of what happened.

I understand rules are rules, but why can�t there be some flexibility? If I unknowingly park in the staff lot for two hours because there is no sign, what really happens? Nothing. Staff could easily park in the normal lots too. Why make it so difficult for paying visitors? A little flexibility and common sense would go a long way.

Don�t get me wrong � I love Indonesia and respect its culture. But experiences like this leave a sour taste at such a famous landmark. With clearer signs and more considerate treatment of visitors, this temple could truly live up to its world-class reputation.

Just one word: FAKE! It is a massive spot of IG lovers who want to post their pics with stages built just for that (such as heart-shaped stuff). Go there if you like fake stuff. Do not take this review personally please

Ulun Danu Beratan Temple is undoubtedly one of the most enchanting places in Bali, and visiting it was a truly unforgettable experience. Nestled on the shores of Lake Beratan in the cool highlands of Bedugul, the temple is surrounded by serene waters and misty mountains, giving it a magical and almost surreal charm. The moment we arrived, the foggy climate added an extra layer of beauty, making the entire scenery look like a painting come to life.

One of the highlights of our visit was trying boating on the calm lake. Gliding across the water while seeing the temple beautifully reflected on the surface was simply superb. The peaceful ride gave us a unique perspective of the temple and its surroundings, something I would highly recommend to anyone visiting. The atmosphere was refreshing and soothing, far from the busy city life, allowing us to fully immerse ourselves in the tranquility of the place.

We were so captivated by the beauty that we ended up taking around 400 pictures at this single location alone. Every corner seemed photogenic, and the shifting mist made each shot unique. Without doubt, Ulun Danu Beratan Temple stands out as one of my favorite locations in Bali, offering a perfect mix of culture, spirituality, and natural beauty.

What makes it even more special is the atmosphere � you can enjoy your meal with a breathtaking view of the lake, mountains, and mist. It felt like a magical experience, combining culture, nature, and food in the best possible way.

**Ulun Danu Temple**:

---

#Ulun Danu Temple

Ulun Danu Temple, also known as **Pura Ulun Danu Bratan**, is one of the most iconic temples in Bali, Indonesia. Situated on the shores of **Lake Bratan** in the Bedugul highlands, this temple holds immense cultural, historical, and spiritual significance. Surrounded by the calm waters of the lake and the misty mountains, Ulun Danu Temple is not just a place of worship but also a symbol of Bali�s natural beauty and rich heritage.

The temple was built in **1633** by the King of Mengwi as a place to honor **Dewi Danu**, the goddess of water, lakes, and rivers. The Balinese people believe that the lake and its temple play a vital role in their irrigation system, which supports agriculture across the region. For this reason, Ulun Danu Temple is not only a spiritual landmark but also a center of harmony between nature, people, and the divine.

Architecturally, Ulun Danu Temple showcases the unique **Balinese Hindu style**. The most striking part of the temple is its **multi-tiered Meru shrines**, which stand gracefully against the backdrop of the lake. These shrines are dedicated to different gods and goddesses, including Lord Shiva, Lord Vishnu, and Goddess Danu. The temple complex consists of several smaller shrines and courtyards, each carrying deep religious meaning. The reflection of the temple on the lake creates a magical view, especially during sunrise and sunset, making it one of the most photographed sites in Bali.

Culturally, Ulun Danu Temple is a place where traditional ceremonies are held to honor the goddess and ask for blessings for water and fertility. Farmers often gather here to pray for successful harvests. The temple is also a symbol of **Tri Hita Karana**, the Balinese philosophy of harmony among humans, nature, and the spiritual world.

Today, Ulun Danu Temple attracts thousands of visitors from around the world. It is not only a sacred site for Balinese Hindus but also a major tourist destination. Visitors are drawn by its breathtaking scenery, cultural richness, and peaceful atmosphere. Despite modernization, the temple has managed to preserve its traditions, rituals, and spiritual importance.

In conclusion, Ulun Danu Temple is more than a religious monument; it is a beautiful blend of spirituality, culture, and nature. Standing gracefully on Lake Bratan, it reminds people of the deep connection between humans and the environment. Its serene beauty and cultural significance make it one of Bali�s most treasured landmarks and a must-visit destination for anyone exploring the island.

Ulun Danu Bratan Temple, often referred to as the "Floating Temple," is a serene Hindu Shaivite temple situated on the shores of Lake Bratan in Bali's Tabanan Regency. Built in 1633, it is dedicated to Dewi Danu, the goddess of water, lakes, and rivers, playing a crucial role in Bali's traditional irrigation system, Subak .

 Serene Atmosphere & Scenic Beauty

Visitors often describe the temple as enchanting, especially during early mornings when mist envelops the lake, creating a tranquil and ethereal ambiance . The temple's unique location on the lake's edge, combined with its traditional Balinese architecture, offers picturesque views, making it a favorite spot for photography.

 Wildlife and Surroundings

While the main attraction is the temple itself, the surrounding area includes a small botanical garden. Some visitors have noted the presence of various birds and other small animals in the vicinity, adding to the natural charm of the location. However, there isn't a formal zoo on the premises.

 Temple Layout and Features

The temple complex comprises several structures, including:
Meru Shrines: Pagoda-like structures dedicated to various deities.
Buddhist Stupa: A unique feature, reflecting Bali's religious harmony, located outside the main temple area .

Lake Beratan: The lake's calm waters enhance the temple's floating illusion, especially during high water levels.

 Visitor Information

Opening Hours: 7:00 AM to 7:00 PM daily.

Entrance Fee: IDR 75,000 for foreign adults; IDR 50,000 for foreign children .

Dress Code: While modest attire is recommended, visitors are not required to wear traditional Balinese temple attire unless entering specific worship areas.

 Getting There

Ulun Danu Bratan Temple is approximately a 2-hour drive from Ubud and about 1.5 hours from Denpasar. The journey offers scenic views of Bali's countryside, making the trip enjoyable. Car is recommended for families.

In summary, Ulun Danu Bratan Temple offers a peaceful retreat amidst Bali's natural beauty. Its serene atmosphere, combined with the unique setting on Lake Bratan, makes it a must-visit destination for those seeking tranquility and cultural enrichment.

I had the chance to visit Ulun Danu Bratan Temple, one of Bali�s most iconic landmarks, and it was truly a beautiful experience. The temple, set against the backdrop of Lake Bratan and surrounded by mountains, creates such a serene and picturesque atmosphere.

The reflection of the temple on the lake, especially in the morning when the air is crisp and mist lingers, feels almost magical. The surrounding gardens are very well-maintained and impressively clean, making the whole area pleasant to explore.

It can get quite busy with visitors, but the peaceful setting of the lake and the cultural significance of the temple still shine through. For anyone visiting Bali, this is definitely a must-see destination that perfectly combines natural beauty, cultural heritage, and a tranquil environment.

Ignore the naysayers, it�s worth the drive. We drove our scooter here from our stay near central Ubud, for around 1hr 30min, leaving at around 8 am, and it was totally worth it. The drive itself was quite pleasant, as the roads are very nice, and because of the low traffic and the time of the day, the views during the drive itself were quite nice. The drive back in the evening was another story though, one full of traffic (but on a scooter, you can still zoom through a bit). The temple itself is also really beautiful, I�ve seen nothing like it. From inside, it looks like the lake is part of the temple itself, and during the early hours, there weren�t that many tourists, so it wasn�t overwhelmed with people, so we got to take it in at a comfortable pace. My recommendation, rent a scooter (if you can drive it and don�t mind driving up/down hill good roads), and leave early. The earlier you leave, the better (though I don�t recommend leaving without *some* natural light).

Pura Ulun Danu Beratan is one of those places that truly takes your breath away. Set right on the edge of Lake Beratan in the cool highlands of Bedugul, this temple feels like it�s floating on water.

It�s not just a spiritual site, but also a Balinese icon�with its unique architecture and peaceful surroundings. The mountain backdrop, calm lake, and fresh air make it a perfect spot to pause, take photos, and just enjoy the beauty of Bali. Definitely worth a visit.

However, there are areas where the site management could improve the overall visitor experience. At peak hours, the temple grounds often become congested, with large tour groups crowding walkways and disrupting the peaceful atmosphere.

In some cases, chaotic tourist behavior�such as loud conversations, disregard for sacred zones, or climbing on restricted areas�detracts from the temple�s spiritual significance. These issues highlight the need for more professional crowd management, clearer signage, and on-site staff presence to guide and educate visitors.

Given the sacred nature of the site, more attention should be placed on preserving its calm and respectful atmosphere. Simple steps like timed entry, designated quiet zones, and reinforced cultural etiquette could make a big difference.

Beautiful and peaceful spot that�s definitely worth a visit if you're exploring Bali. The temple is set right on the edge of Lake Beratan, and the views are stunning � especially in the morning when the water is still and reflects the temple perfectly. Ulun Danu Beratan Temple is a fantastic stop and one of the highlights of the area. The grounds are beautifully kept, with plenty of space to wander and endless opportunities for stunning photos. There is a small coffee and ice cream stand with fair prices, which makes for a nice break during your visit. We were lucky to catch a ceremony while we were there, and it was absolutely beautiful to watch, adding to the cultural experience. There is also a playground for children, though it looks a bit dated and could use some updates. Overall, this is a wonderful place to visit, and I would highly recommend it, especially for families or anyone interested in seeing temples in a peaceful and scenic setting.

Ulun Danu Temple is located on Lake Beratan, in the highlands of Indonesia, is a beautiful spiritual destination, loved by many tourists. In the mild weather of the highlands about 1,500 meters above sea level, the air here is always very fresh and cool. The lake surface is clear, beautiful and almost completely calm, occasionally a few breezes blow through creating small ripples that are extremely poetic.

Ulun Danu Beratan Temple is a must visit destination especially anyone who is seeking spiritual charm and natural beauty of Bali.

This place offers a peaceful lake, culturally rich, unique scenic and aesthetic building.

Pura Ulun Danu Bedugul is an absolute must-visit for anyone traveling to Bali. This iconic temple on the lake should definitely be on every tourist�s list.

The entrance fee is very reasonable � only Rp40,000 per person for adults domestic (above 5 years old), and it�s free for children under 5.

The area is incredibly spacious with beautifully maintained grounds. There�s also a restaurant inside, which is perfect for relaxing after exploring.

One of the best parts is the variety of activities available here. You can try speedboats or rent pedal boats (duck-shaped ones) to enjoy the lake from up close.

Overall, it�s a fantastic spot to take photos, soak in the cool mountain air, and experience one of Bali�s most stunning landmarks. Highly recommended!

Ulun Danu Beratan Temple is truly one of the must-visit places in Bali. The temple is set against a stunning backdrop of hills and floating clouds that come down all the way to the lake  the views are absolutely breathtaking!

While the temple itself may appear small and simple, it's located within a large, beautifully maintained park that makes the entire visit feel peaceful and refreshing. It�s perfect for nature lovers and photography enthusiasts you'll find endless spots for amazing pictures.

There�s no trekking involved, just easy walking paths, so it�s suitable for all age groups. Inside the park, you�ll find some enjoyable commercial activities like feeding fishes and animals, shopping stalls, and even a play area for kids.

Highly recommended for families, couples, or anyone looking to relax and soak in the beauty of Bali�s natural charm.

Danau beratan atau danau Bedugul, terletak di Desa Candikuning, Kecamatan Baturiti, Kabupaten Tabanan, Bali. Jika menggunakan mobil, jarak tempuh ke Danau ini dari area Kuta atau Seminyak adalah sekitar 2 sampai 2,5 jam, sementara dari Ubud adalah sekitar 1,5 hingga 2 jam. Di temgah danau terdapat Pura Ulun Danu yang terkenal. Lokasi ini telah ditara bagus di tengah lembah gunung yang sejuk. Selain iconik beberapa pura yang masih dipergunkan juga untuk latihan tari dan prosesi tradisi, juga ada sentra bermain anak, relief legenda, taman bunga dan selfi, Resto, pusat cinderamata, rekreasi air dan taman yang terkadang masih terlihat rusa. Pura Ulun Danu merupakan pemujaan dewi Laksmi. Yang berbeda terdapat Pelinggih Telengin Segara yang berwujud meru bertumpang 11 dan Pelinggih Lingga Ulun Danu yang berwujud meru bertumpang tiga. Posisinya dikeliling gunung dan air danau, bahkan seringkali berkabut menjadikannya estetik. Di kompleks ini terdapat 5 pura dan di luar terdapat stupa Budha, diperkirakan dibangun sekak 1555 saka (1634 M) oleh I Gusti Agung Putu dari Kerajaan Mengwi. Di depan terdapat sarkofagus yang diperkirakan sudah ada sejak 500 SM.

Ulun Danu Beratan Temple, located on the shores of Lake Beratan in Bedugul, Bali, is one of the island�s most iconic water temples. It was built in the 17th century during the reign of the Mengwi Kingdom as a place to honor the lake goddess Dewi Danu. The temple is significant in Balinese Hinduism for its role in the subak irrigation system, which is central to the island�s agriculture. The site includes multiple shrines and meru towers dedicated to various deities, including Shiva, Vishnu, and Brahma. Ulun Danu means �head of the lake,� reflecting the temple�s spiritual and physical connection to water. The complex is built on small islands, making it appear to float when the lake's water level rises. It reflects a harmonious relationship between humans, nature, and the divine, central to Balinese philosophy known as *Tri Hita Karana*. The architecture features traditional Balinese design with intricate carvings and tiered roofs. The temple is not only a religious site but also a cultural landmark and popular tourist destination. Today, it remains an active place of worship and a symbol of Bali�s spiritual heritage.

Pura Ulun Danu Beratan., disebut juga Bratan Pura) adalah sebuah pura dan candi air besar di Bali - candi utama air lainnya menjadi Pura Ulun Danu Batur. Kompleks pura ini terletak di tepi barat Danau Bratan di pegunungan dekat Bedugul, tepatnya di Desa Candikuning, Kecamatan Baturiti, Kabupaten Tabanan. Pura air (ulun/segara) memenuhi seluruh wilayah di daerah aliran; di tepi hilir ada banyak pura kecil air yang spesifik untuk setiap asosiasi irigasi (subak).Pura ini sebenarnya digunakan untuk upacara persembahyangan Dewi Danu, dewi air, danau dan sungai. Danau Bratan merupakan salah satu danau penting dalam hal irigasi. Pura Batur atau Pura Ulun Danu pertama kali didirikan pada abad ke-17. Pura ini didedikasikan untuk dewa Wisnu dan untuk Dewi Danu sebagai dewi danau.Selain itu, Dewi Laksmi yang merupakan dewi kesuburan dan keindahan juga dipuja di pura ini.

Pura Ulun Danu Beratan adalah mahakarya budaya Bali yang memadukan keindahan alam, spiritualitas, dan sejarah dalam satu panorama memukau. Terletak di tepi Danau Beratan yang biru kehijauan di kawasan Bedugul, pura abad ke-17 ini tampak seperti ilusi: pagoda meru bertingkatnya seolah mengapung di atas air, dikelilingi kabut pegunungan dan taman bunga begonia yang warna-warni. Suasananya sejuk (18-25�C) dan mistis, membawa nuansa ketenangan meski pengunjung ramai. Sebagai tempat pemujaan Dewi Danu (dewi air), pura ini bukan sekadar objek wisata�ia menyimpan warisan sakral yang masih hidup dalam ritual masyarakat Bali.

Spot foto di sini benar-benar tak terhitung! Dari sudut danau yang memantulkan bayangan sempurna pagoda utama, gazebo tradisional di tengah taman, hingga dermaga kayu dengan perahu warna-warni�setiap sudut layak diabadikan. Saya berhasil mendapatkan beberapa bidikan epik di antara kerumunan, seperti close-up ukiran batu halus pada meru atau latar belakang perbukitan hijau dari tepi air. Area Botanical Garden di sekitarnya juga menawarkan sudut kreatif dengan rumah pohon dan labirin tanaman. Namun, bersiaplah antre untuk spot ikonik seperti dermaga utama, terutama saat siang hari ketika turis domestik dan mancanegara membanjiri lokasi.

Ulun Danu Beratan Temple is a truly beautiful spot and definitely worth a visit if you're exploring central Bali. Located right on the edge of Lake Beratan, the temple appears to float on the water, especially when the lake is calm � it's a stunning sight, especially in the early morning light.

The temple grounds are spacious, well-kept, and filled with colorful gardens and traditional Balinese structures. It has a calm and peaceful atmosphere, making it a nice break from the more crowded tourist areas. The surrounding mountain scenery adds to the sense of tranquility.

There are helpful signs throughout the complex giving some background on the temple's cultural and spiritual significance, and the area is well-organized for visitors. It's also a great spot for photos, though it can get a bit busy during peak hours.

Overall, Ulun Danu Beratan offers a unique mix of natural beauty and cultural heritage � a very rewarding stop for anyone traveling through the region.

Ulun Danu Beratan Temple is a beautiful and iconic spot in Bali, located right by Lake Beratan. There�s an entrance fee to get in, and while you can�t go inside the main temple (it�s only open to locals and during certain festivals), the outside area is still stunning and well worth exploring.

When I visited, it was quite crowded, but the scenery made up for it�especially the temple�s reflection on the lake. It's a must-visit

This place is one of the iconic tourism in Bali, this place is called Pura Ulun Danu Bratan, Bedugul. This place is very aesthetic for taking pictures, a beautiful place, pretty, natural, and of course amazes tourists.

Ulun Danu Beratan is truly one of the most picturesque spots in Bali � beautifully set against the serene Lake Beratan with mountains in the background. The gardens are well-maintained, making it a perfect place for photography and relaxation.

There are plenty of photo-worthy spots throughout the area, and you can even rent traditional Balinese costumes for a fun and memorable photoshoot. A few restaurants are available nearby for a convenient bite.

There's also a small petting area and a pet-feeding session available where, for a fee, you can hold an owl, bat, and a few other gentle animals � a unique experience! And if you're up for a bit of adventure, you can enjoy a boat ride around the lake. Highly recommended for a peaceful and scenic cultural stop in Bali.

Pura Ulun Danu Beratan di Bedugul adalah salah satu ikon Bali yang paling memukau, terkenal dengan lokasinya yang unik seolah mengapung di tepi Danau Bratan. Pemandangan pura ini benar-benar seperti kartu pos.
Saat berkunjung, saya langsung terpikat oleh ketenangan dan keindahan alamnya. Pura yang berdiri anggun di atas air, dikelilingi oleh pegunungan hijau dan kabut tipis di pagi hari, menciptakan suasana yang sangat magis dan damai. Ini adalah tempat yang sempurna untuk menikmati udara sejuk Bedugul sambil mengagumi arsitektur pura yang khas.
Selain pura utama, kompleks ini juga memiliki taman yang terawat indah dengan beragam bunga dan pohon, menambah pesona lokasi ini. Anda bisa berjalan-jalan santai, berfoto di berbagai sudut, atau sekadar duduk menikmati pemandangan. Pura Ulun Danu Beratan adalah destinasi wajib bagi siapa pun yang mencari perpaduan spiritualitas, keindahan alam, dan spot foto yang ikonik di Bali.

Ulun Danu Beratan Temple is one of the most beautiful and peaceful places I�ve ever visited in Bali. Located by the shores of Lake Beratan in the mountains of Bedugul, this temple offers a refreshing escape from the tropical heat. The cool, crisp air combined with the serene atmosphere makes it a perfect place to relax and enjoy nature.

The scenery is absolutely breathtaking. Surrounded by misty hills and calm lake waters, the temple looks like it�s floating�especially when the water level rises. The reflection of the temple on the lake creates a stunning view, perfect for photos and quiet contemplation.

Whether you're a nature lover, a cultural enthusiast, or just looking for a peaceful spot to unwind, Ulun Danu Beratan is definitely worth a visit.

Pros
1. It looks exactly like the pictures
2. Its beautiful and colourful with flower garlands
3. The area is clean and well maintained
4. There are many photo spots
6. You may take pictures with Luwak, owl and snake if that interests you. Snake was for 100K while other animals could be pictured with for 30K

Tempio shivaista pi� importante di Bali. Si trova nel villaggio di Bedugul sul lago Bratan, all�interno della caldera di un vulcano estinto e a circa 1200 metri sul livello del mare. Il tempio � dedicato alla dea dell�acqua Dewi Danu e, per questo motivo, � posizionato sulla riserva d�acqua pi� importante di tutta la zona. La bellezza e il grande fascino di questo luogo sacro sono due dei motivi per cui questa � una delle tappe che non puoi perdere se desideri scoprire tutti i templi pi� spettacolari di Bali. Il complesso del tempio si trova sul lato occidentale del lago e consiste in due parti: una adagiata sulla riva e una �galleggiante�. Il meru principale a undici livelli, posto su un isolotto tra le acque del lago, � chiamato Lingga Petak ed � dedicato a Shiva. Sulla sponda che fronteggia il Lingga Petak trova spazio la restante parte del tempio che omaggia il Pura Puncak Mangu, un piccolo tempio che si trova a nordest del lago, dedicato alla fertilit� del terreno. Questa parte del tempio � caratterizzata da diversi bale, il padmasana e un alto meru a sette livelli dedicato a Brahma ed � solitamente interdetta ai non fedeli. Lungo la sponda del lago si sviluppa un bel giardino fiorito in cui trova posto anche un grande stupa buddista adornato di statue. La presenza di questo stupa conferma, come nel caso del tempio di Goa Gajah, la correlazione tra siti religiosi buddisti e induisti.

Ulun Danu Beratan Temple was one of the top 5 places of my trip to Bali. Nestled on the serene shores of Lake Beratan, this temple feels like it's floating on water, creating an absolutely breathtaking view�especially in the early morning mist.
The temple itself is beautifully maintained, with intricate Balinese architecture and cultural elements that reflect the deep spiritual roots of the island. I was particularly moved by how harmoniously it blends with nature. There are also well-kept gardens, and plenty of opportunities to take amazing photos. Whether you're into photography, culture, or simply looking for a quiet, reflective spot, Ulun Danu Beratan offers a bit of everything.

Highly recommend adding this to your Bali itinerary�it�s a must-see.

Pura Ulun Danu Bratan is undeniably picturesque, a stunning temple floating on the tranquil waters of Lake Bratan. The scenery is postcard-perfect, making it easy to see why it's a must-visit in Bali. However, the sheer volume of tourists transforms what should be a serene spiritual site into a chaotic photo-op. It feels less like experiencing a temple and more like navigating a crowded backdrop, where everyone is vying for the perfect social media shot. The constant stream of visitors and the pressure to capture that "Instagrammable" moment completely overshadows any sense of the temple's inherent tranquility and spiritual significance. Sadly, the essence of Pura Ulun Danu Bratan is lost in the crush, leaving one feeling more like they've visited a tourist attraction than a sacred space.

A beautiful lakeside temple complex with typical Balinese architecture and use of volcanic stones. A shaivite temple, it also contains a Buddhist Stupa on the Southern side. Apparently, the lake feeds water to the traditional subak irrigation system. Built around the 17th century, it is a great landmark and a must visit heritage complex on Bali island. Best to use a hired vehicle if you're a tourist as parking can be challenging. Ticketing is possible at the entrance gate.

This temple is surrounded by stunning natural scenery, making it a perfect destination for both photography and feel the nature. If you're a nature lover, you'll appreciate the breathtaking views of the lake, mountains, and vibrant flowers, all within a calm and serene atmosphere.

Every corner offers a picture-perfect view, providing plenty of great spots for photos. The vast area is ideal for a leisurely walk, allowing you to fully immerse yourself in the beauty and tranquility of the surroundings. Truly a peaceful and beautiful place to visit.

The temple ground are completely beautiful to walk around, however you cannot enter the actual temples as they�re for prayers only. This is fair enough, but the exception is if you pay to hire the traditional clothing for 40K IDR then you can enter one of the temple grounds where you can take photos. This doesn�t make sense and the rest of the vibe is also too commercial for my taste.

You even have to pay to enter the fish pond as you can only enter it if you want to feed the fish.
Then of course there are captive animals that you can once again pay to hold and take photos with including a Luwak.

And you then pay for parking when you leave.

This could be one of the most beautiful and scenic places in Bali if profits from tourists were not prioritised at every step of the way.

Ulun Danu Beratan Temple is absolutely stunning. The combination of the serene lake, misty mountains, and traditional Balinese architecture creates a truly magical atmosphere. The reflection of the temple on the water makes it one of the most picturesque spots in Bali, and the cool mountain air adds to the peaceful experience.

However, one major downside was the presence of captive animals being used for tourist photos. I was saddened to see a caged civet cat, an iguana, and owls with their feet tied so they couldn�t fly. The civet cat, in particular, was extremely obese, likely due to being overfed for entertainment purposes. This kind of treatment is cruel, and I strongly urge fellow tourists not to take photos or engage with these attractions. Supporting them only encourages more exploitation of these beautiful creatures.

Overall, the temple itself is breathtaking and well worth a visit, but I hope the management takes action to end the mistreatment of animals. If you�re visiting, enjoy the scenery, respect the culture, and please avoid supporting unethical wildlife practices.

Ulun Danu Beratan Temple is one of the most picturesque temples in Bali. Located on the shores of Lake Beratan, it seems to float on the water, creating a truly magical and serene atmosphere. The surrounding mountains and misty air make the whole place feel almost surreal.

The temple grounds are beautifully maintained, with lush gardens and stunning viewpoints. It�s a fantastic spot for photography, and the reflections of the temple in the lake add to its charm. The area is peaceful, making it a great place to relax and take in Bali�s spiritual side.

Whether you�re into culture, nature, or photography, this temple is definitely worth a visit. The morning hours are ideal if you want fewer crowds and a more tranquil experience!

There�s also a small caf� near the temple where we stopped for some snacks. It was a nice spot to relax and take in the serene atmosphere before continuing our exploration. Overall, it was a wonderful experience, and I�d definitely recommend visiting if you�re in Bali!

Danu Beratan is a beautiful attraction and a gorgeous area to visit. We arrived at 3.15pm, and I'm not sure if it was the time or a general thing but we couldn't enter any of the actual temple structures themselves which was disappointing. However there is just so much to walk around and do here that it's definitely still worth a visit. We enjoyed the views of the lake, fed the (very fat!) fish for 10000 rupiah each, enjoyed the temple architecture from the outside including the well designed lawn / garden spaces, and drove to the nearby local market. We used a car and driver for the day which helped explore nearby attractions as well. We were on a tight time schedule without which we could have enjoyed more time at the temple complex including the speed boat ride etc which we didn't know about at the time of visiting.

Resto: Vegetarian food is readily available in the restaurant (resto) including no-onion + no-garlic options for those who want this. Vegan food isn't clearly signposted but some of the food on enquiry was already vegan, I asked for vegetarian options without milk / eggs / butter / fish and they understood what I needed. Service was timely but very chilled out and laidback. There are clean restrooms at the back of the restaurant.

Ulun Danu Beratan Temple adalah mahakarya spiritual yang berdiri anggun di tepi Danau Beratan, Bedugul, Bali. Kuil yang didedikasikan untuk Dewi Danu, dewi air dan kesuburan, ini menyajikan pemandangan yang begitu memukau, terutama saat kabut tipis menyelimuti danau, menciptakan suasana mistis yang menenangkan. Arsitektur khas Bali dengan meru (atap bertingkat) berpadu harmonis dengan latar belakang pegunungan yang hijau, menjadikannya salah satu destinasi paling fotogenik di Pulau Dewata. Saat matahari terbit atau terbenam, refleksi candi di permukaan air menambah keindahan dramatis, memberikan pengalaman spiritual sekaligus visual yang tak terlupakan bagi setiap pengunjung.

Ulun Danu Beratan Temple, a true icon of Bali, offers a captivating blend of spiritual significance and natural beauty. Perched on the serene shores of Lake Beratan in the highlands of Bedugul, the temple's "floating" appearance is a sight to behold, making it a must-visit for any traveler.

The temple complex itself is a testament to Balinese architecture and Hindu traditions, with intricate carvings and multi-tiered pagodas. The tranquil atmosphere and the surrounding mountain scenery create a truly magical experience.

Here's a breakdown of the entrance fees:

-Adult Foreigner: IDR 75,000 per person
-Child Foreigner (5-10 years): IDR 50,000 per person
-Adult Domestic (Monday-Friday): IDR 40,000 per person
-Adult Domestic (Saturday-Sunday) and National Holiday: IDR 50,000 per person
-Child Domestic (5-10 years): IDR 20,000 per person
-Adult (Bali ID Card): IDR 30,000 per person
-Child (Bali ID Card) (5-10 years): IDR 20,000 per person

Beyond the stunning visuals, visitors can explore the temple grounds, learn about its history, and even take a boat ride on the lake for a unique perspective. The cool mountain air and the peaceful ambiance make Ulun Danu Beratan Temple a refreshing escape from the heat and bustle of Bali's coastal areas.

Whether you're a photography enthusiast, a culture seeker, or simply looking for a serene getaway, Ulun Danu Beratan Temple is sure to leave a lasting impression.

Visiting Ulun Danu Beratan Temple was one of the most serene and memorable experiences in Bali. The temple, sitting gracefully on the calm waters of Lake Beratan, looks like it�s floating, especially when the mist rolls in from the surrounding mountains�it�s absolutely magical!

What made the visit even more special was the peaceful atmosphere. The cool mountain air, the beautifully landscaped gardens, and the gentle ripples of the lake created a sense of calm that�s hard to put into words. It�s a place where you just want to pause, take a deep breath, and soak in the beauty.

The temple itself, dedicated to Dewi Danu, the goddess of lakes and rivers, feels deeply spiritual. We took a boat ride on the lake, and seeing the temple from the water gave us an entirely new perspective�it was stunning!

If you�re in Bali, don�t miss this place. Whether you go in the morning for a quiet moment or later in the day for those postcard-perfect views, Ulun Danu Beratan Temple is a must-visit. I�d go back in a heartbeat!

Serene scenery on top of Danau Beratan, this is a must visit site on a clear day for Bali first timers. The temperature is quite chilly around 17-22�C for people living in the equator, so bring some cover. Exploring the place takes around 1 hour, unless you also want to take in the view using speedboat

Pura Ulun Danu Beratan adalah salah satu ikon wisata Bali yang terkenal dengan keindahannya. Terletak di tepi Danau Beratan, Bedugul, pura ini menawarkan pemandangan spektakuler dengan latar belakang pegunungan dan air danau yang tenang. Suasana sejuk khas dataran tinggi semakin menambah daya tarik tempat ini, menjadikannya destinasi favorit bagi wisatawan lokal maupun mancanegara.
Pura ini dibangun pada abad ke-17 dan didedikasikan untuk Dewi Danu, dewi yang dipercaya menjaga keseimbangan air dan kesuburan. Arsitektur pura sangat khas dengan atap meru bertingkat yang mencerminkan kepercayaan Hindu Bali. Saat air danau sedang pasang, pura ini tampak seolah-olah mengapung di atas air, menciptakan pemandangan yang magis dan menawan.
Selain keindahan pura, kawasan sekitar juga menawarkan berbagai aktivitas menarik. Pengunjung dapat menyewa perahu untuk mengelilingi danau, berfoto dengan latar belakang pura, atau menikmati taman yang tertata rapi dengan berbagai jenis bunga dan tanaman tropis. Terdapat juga fasilitas seperti restoran dan pasar kecil yang menjual oleh-oleh khas Bali.
Secara keseluruhan, Pura Ulun Danu Beratan adalah destinasi wisata yang memadukan keindahan alam, sejarah, dan budaya Bali. Keunikannya menjadikannya tempat yang wajib dikunjungi, baik bagi pencinta fotografi, pecinta alam, maupun mereka yang ingin merasakan ketenangan spiritual di tengah keindahan alam Bali.
Pura ini terletak di Danau Beratan, Candikuning, Baturiti, Tabanan Regency, Bali.

Uluwatu Temple in Bali is a breathtaking destination that offers a unique blend of natural beauty, culture, and spirituality. Perched on a 70-meter cliff overlooking the Indian Ocean, the temple provides stunning views of the surrounding landscape, especially during sunset

The temple is home to the iconic Kecak Fire Dance, a traditional Balinese performance that tells the story of Ramayana, a Hindu epic. The dance is performed by a group of male dancers, who chant "cak-cak-cak" in unison, creating a mesmerizing atmosphere. The performance is usually held at sunset, adding to the dramatic effect

*Key Highlights:*

- *Stunning Views*: Uluwatu Temple offers breathtaking views of the Indian Ocean and surrounding cliffs.
- *Kecak Fire Dance*: A traditional Balinese dance performance that tells the story of Ramayana.
- *Sunset*: The temple is a popular spot to watch the sunset, with the sky turning golden and pink.
- *Cultural Significance*: Uluwatu Temple is one of Bali's six main temples and is considered a sacred site.

*Practical Information:*

- *Show Times*: Kecak Fire Dance performances are held daily at 6:00 PM and 7:00 PM.
- *Ticket Prices*: IDR 150,000 for adults, IDR 50,000 for children.
- *Dress Code*: Sarongs and sashes are provided for visitors .

Uluwatu Temple is in a serene and beautiful hill surrounded by sea on one side &  forest and garden greenary on the other sides with lots of aggressive monkeys and soothing sea views with breeze.

One can purchase the ticket for visiting the temple in the front office. Tickets are available to enter the temple. People don't have to buy tickets in advance for the fire dance here. They still provide tickets inside the temple near the ticket counter. If it's season then better book in advance. Beware of the monkeys here. They are a menace and super aggressive. There are guards who will be there to help in times of need. However do not mess with them as they snatch away phones, goggles, anything for that matter. Don't take selfies or pictures of them. They don't like it. They don't harm us until we do something. Let them be.

Pura Luhur Uluwatu is a Hindu temple on the south western part of the Bukit Peninsula and it�s famous for its dramatic location on a 70 meters high limestone cliff and for the Kecak Dance performances that are held in its amphitheatre. There is also a population of about 700 long-tailed macaques, the same animals of the Ubud Monkey Forest, but here they are concentrated in a much smaller space so you have to be extra careful with them because they easily steal anything shiny from you (smartphones included). The entrance fee is 100.000 IDR (less than 3�), but if you want to attend the Kecak Dance show you have to pay an extra and in this case I suggest you book the ticket in advance because there�s a high demand.

Visiting Uluwatu Temple was truly one of the most beautiful experiences I�ve had in Bali. As soon as we entered, we were given sarongs to wear, which added to the cultural feel of the place and made the visit even more special.

The temple sits right on the edge of dramatic cliffs overlooking the ocean, making it a perfect spot for stunning photos. Everywhere you turn, there�s a view worth capturing.

There are many monkeys around, and we were strictly instructed to be careful with our belongings because they can quickly grab and run away with anything in their reach. It added a little thrill, but as long as you�re cautious, it�s fine.

One of the most memorable moments was seeing a beautiful couple�s proposal happening there. The backdrop of the ocean, sunset, and temple made it feel incredibly dreamlike. Honestly, it�s a perfect spot to take your loved one for a proposal. Peaceful , romantic, and naturally breathtaking.

Overall, Uluwatu Temple is a must-visit if you�re in Bali for the views, the culture, and maybe even a magical moment or two.

Uluwatu Temple, or Pura Luhur Uluwatu, is a Balinese Hindu sea temple renowned for its dramatic location atop a sheer cliff. The name itself reflects this setting, derived from "ulu" meaning "land's end" or "peak," and "watu" meaning "rock". The temple is famous for its breathtaking, panoramic ocean views, particularly during sunset when the sky explodes in vibrant colors, casting a magical glow over the water and cliffs. A serpentine pathway with concrete walls runs along the cliff edge, offering numerous points to stop and admire the scenery. KNEES AND SHOULDERS TO BE COVERED

Uluwatu Temple is one of the most stunning temples in Bali, especially if you visit around sunset. The temple sits high on the cliffs with incredible ocean views, making it one of the most scenic spots on the island.

The area is spacious and beautiful to walk around, with traditional Balinese architecture and dramatic cliff edges. It can get busy, but the views make it completely worth it.

A very important note: the monkeys! They are everywhere and they�re quick � they will grab sunglasses, phones, hats, or even water bottles. Hold your things tightly and avoid bringing anything loose or shiny.

The temple has an entry fee, but the experience and scenery are 100% worth it. A must-see if you�re in Bali.

A breathtaking temple by the cliffs � full of spirit, sunsets, and culture.
Uluwatu Temple is one of the most stunning places in Bali, perched high above the ocean with endless views of the waves below. The energy here feels sacred and alive, especially at sunset when the Kecak Dance begins � a mesmerizing performance that tells ancient Balinese stories through rhythm, chant, and movement.

There are two evening shows, and the queue for tickets can be quite long, so it�s best to arrive early or have your guide stand in line while you explore the temple grounds. Be mindful of the monkeys � they are playful but quick to grab glasses, hats, or even jewelry!

Dress respectfully (shoulders and knees covered), take your time to enjoy the cliffs and temple carvings, and let yourself feel the serenity of this sacred space.

Visited Uluwatu Temple during our Bali honeymoon, and the views were absolutely breathtaking. ?
The cliffs covered in green dropping straight into the bright blue ocean looked like something out of a movie. Every angle had waves crashing below and endless sea stretching into the sky. 

Walking through the stone paths, old gates, and carved statues gave the place a peaceful, sacred feel.  The tree-tunnel walkway and the long path under tall branches made the whole visit calm and romantic. 

The best part was standing at the edge, watching the waves hit the rocks far below. Pure magic. 

Overall: A must-visit spot in Bali for couples. Stunning views, relaxing walks, and perfect honeymoon memories.

Visited Uluwatu Temple and it completely lived up to the hype. The view from the cliffs is absolutely breathtaking � endless ocean on one side and the ancient temple perched right on the edge. It�s one of those places that really makes you stop and just take it all in.

The area is clean and well-maintained, and the walk around the cliffs is beautiful, especially during sunset. The colors of the sky, the sound of the waves, and the breeze from the ocean make it feel almost magical.

I also watched the Kecak Fire Dance during sunset � it was such a unique cultural experience. The performance, the chanting, and the setting with the ocean in the background were unforgettable.

A quick tip: the monkeys around the temple can be sneaky, so hold onto your sunglasses, phones, or hats!

Overall, Uluwatu Temple is definitely a must-visit spot in Bali � whether you come for the view, the culture, or just to enjoy the sunset, it�s an experience you won�t forget.

Visited Uluwatu Temple today and honestly, it�s one of the most beautiful places I�ve seen in Bali. The temple is right on top of a cliff with a crazy ocean view � literally every corner looks perfect for photos and videos. We saw so many tourists from all around the world, and still, the place felt calm and peaceful in its own way.

Before entering, they give you traditional clothes � my wife got a cute sarong (something like a lungi), and men have to wear a cloth tied around the waist. It actually made the experience feel more cultural and special.

There are monkeys everywhere, and apparently, they have a big history connected to the temple. It�s fun to watch them, but yeah, you�ve got to be a little careful because they can get naughty with glasses and small things .

The whole place is huge, and the views from the top are just amazing. We spent quite a while just sitting and watching the waves hit the rocks below. Uluwatu Temple is simply magical. Perched dramatically on a towering cliff, the views overlooking the Indian Ocean are absolutely breathtaking, especially as the sun begins to set. It's truly one of the most stunning places to watch the sunset in the world.
The highlight, however, is the Kecak Fire Dance performance held in the open-air amphitheater right beside the cliff edge. The hypnotic chanting of the male chorus, the vibrant costumes, and the incredible Ramayana storyline, all set against the backdrop of the fiery sunset, is a powerful and unforgettable cultural experience.
A few tips: Be cautious of the local monkeys, as they are mischievous! Keep your sunglasses, hats, and phone secure. Also, book your Kecak dance tickets in advance, and try to arrive early to get a good seat for the sunset view. This place is pure Bali magic!

Uluwatu Temple is a Balinese Hindu sea temple located on a cliff top in Bali, Indonesia, renowned for its spectacular ocean views and sunset backdrop. It is one of six key temples of high spiritual significance in  Bali and is a popular spot for visitors to witness  the daily  Kecak Fire Dance. The temple is also known for the long-tailed monkeys that inhabit the area.

Location: around 25-27 km from Seminyak and will take around 2 hrs to reach due to very slow traffic of Bali.

What to wear: sarong is a must to cover the lower parts of body if you�re on shorts

What to expect: spectacular views of mountain cliffs and ocean , temple is located at the edge of clip. More serene and majestic at the time of Sunset. Kecak fire dance is a must watch depicting Ramayana in Balinese style and culture

Caution: be aware of long tail monkeys who are habitat there.. many travellers have lost their mobile phones, spectacles and other belongings

Nice experience. Perched dramatically on the edge of a 70-meter-high cliff overlooking the vast Indian Ocean, Uluwatu Temple (Pura Luhur Uluwatu) is one of Bali�s most iconic sea temples and a true embodiment of Balinese spirituality, culture, and natural beauty. My visit to this sacred site was not just a sightseeing stop but a deeply immersive experience blending history, mythology, architecture, and breathtaking scenery.
As you approach the temple, the winding road lined with frangipani trees and the sound of crashing waves below sets a serene tone. The temple is believed to date back to the 10th century, and its name itself reveals its essence � Ulu meaning �top� and Watu meaning �rock� � a fitting description for a temple that literally sits at the top of a cliff. Dedicated to the Balinese sea gods, particularly the spirits guarding Bali from evil oceanic forces, the temple holds immense spiritual importance for locals.
What strikes you first is the panoramic view from the cliff. Standing at the edge and watching the endless stretch of turquoise-blue ocean merging with the sky is nothing short of magical. The vantage point offers one of the best sunset views in Bali. As the sun begins to set, painting the sky in hues of orange and pink, the entire place transforms into a mystical canvas. It�s easy to understand why this spot is so revered and why it attracts travelers, photographers, and worshippers alike.
One of the highlights of visiting Uluwatu is the Kecak Fire Dance, held every evening in an open amphitheater with the ocean as the backdrop. This traditional dance is a captivating spectacle of rhythm and storytelling. Around seventy bare-chested men sit in concentric circles, chanting �cak-cak-cak� in hypnotic unison while performers enact scenes from the Ramayana � particularly the story of Prince Rama, Sita, and the heroic Hanuman. As the flames rise and the chorus intensifies, the scene depicting Hanuman setting fire to Ravana�s Lanka (or �Rahwana�s Alengka� in Balinese culture) unfolds dramatically against the twilight sky. Watching this performance at Uluwatu is truly a once-in-a-lifetime experience � it feels like ancient mythology coming alive amidst nature.
However, one must also mention the mischievous monkeys that inhabit the temple grounds. They are playful but notorious for snatching sunglasses, hats, or even mobile phones, so visitors are advised to hold their belongings carefully. Despite their antics, they add a layer of liveliness to the experience and are considered sacred in local belief, symbolizing guardians of the temple.
The temple�s architecture is simple yet profound, marked by traditional Balinese stone carvings, split gates, and shrines adorned with checkered cloth. Tourists are not allowed inside the innermost sanctum (reserved for worshippers), but the accessible areas are sufficient to appreciate the temple�s grandeur and sanctity.
In essence, Uluwatu Temple is not merely a tourist attraction � it is a spiritual and cultural journey. The combination of its cliffside setting, the rhythmic power of the Kecak Dance, and the serene aura of the ocean below make it an unforgettable experience. It�s one of those places where nature, culture, and faith come together harmoniously, leaving every visitor touched by Bali�s timeless spirit.
? Rating: 4.8/5 � A must-visit for anyone seeking to experience Bali�s soul through its culture, mythology, and mesmerizing natural beauty.

Visiting Uluwatu Temple was one of the absolute highlights of our trip to Bali! The moment we arrived, we were struck by how beautiful and peaceful the setting was � perched high on dramatic cliffs overlooking the endless blue ocean. It truly feels like a sacred place where nature and spirituality come together.

The staff were so friendly and helpful, guiding us through the entrance and explaining the temple�s history and traditions. They also provided sarongs with warm smiles, making us feel welcome and comfortable from the start.

The temples themselves are stunning, full of detail and surrounded by lush greenery and curious monkeys. The pathways along the cliffs offer some of the most spectacular views we�ve seen in Bali � the kind of scenery that makes you stop and just take it all in.

A little tip: go early in the morning. It�s peaceful, cooler, and much less crowded than later in the day. And definitely be careful of the monkeys � they�re cheeky and love to grab sunglasses, hats, or water bottles if you�re not paying attention!

If you�re visiting Uluwatu, this temple is an absolute must. It�s a magical mix of culture, nature, and breathtaking views, and one of those places that truly captures the spirit of Bali.

Pura Luhur Uluwatu (Aksara Bali: ??????????????) atau Pura Uluwatu merupakan pura yang berada di wilayah Desa Adat Pecatu, Kecamatan Kuta Selatan, Kabupaten Badung.

Pura Luhur Uluwatu

Pemandangan dari arah Pura Luhur Uluwatu
Pura yang terletak di ujung barat daya pulau Bali di atas anjungan batu karang yang terjal dan tinggi serta menjorok ke laut ini merupakan Pura Sad Kayangan yang dipercaya oleh orang Hindu sebagai penyangga dari 9 mata angin. Pura ini pada mulanya digunakan menjadi tempat memuja seorang pendeta suci dari abad ke-11 bernama Empu Kuturan. Ia menurunkan ajaran Desa Adat dengan segala aturannya.
Pura ini juga dipakai untuk memuja pendeta suci berikutnya, yaitu Dang Hyang Nirartha, yang datang ke Bali pada akhir tahun 1550 dan mengakhiri perjalanan sucinya dengan apa yang dinamakan Moksa atau Ngeluhur di tempat ini. Kata inilah yang menjadi asal nama Pura Luhur Uluwatu.[1]
Pura Uluwatu terletak pada ketinggian 97 meter dari permukaan laut. Di depan pura terdapat hutan kecil yang disebut alas kekeran, berfungsi sebagai penyangga kesucian pura.
Pura Uluwatu mempunyai beberapa pura pesanakan, yaitu pura yang erat kaitannya dengan pura induk. Pura pesanakan itu yaitu Pura Bajurit, Pura Pererepan, Pura Kulat, Pura Dalem Selonding dan Pura Dalem Pangleburan. Masing-masing pura ini mempunyai kaitan erat dengan Pura Uluwatu, terutama pada hari-hari piodalan-nya. Piodalan di Pura Uluwatu, Pura Bajurit, Pura Pererepan dan Pura Kulat jatuh pada Selasa Kliwon Wuku Medangsia setiap 210 hari. Manifestasi Tuhan yang dipuja di Pura Uluwatu adalah Dewa Rudra.[2]
Pura Uluwatu juga menjadi terkenal karena tepat di bawahnya adalah pantai Pecatu yang sering kali digunakan sebagai tempat untuk olahraga selancar, bahkan event internasional sering kali diadakan di sini. Ombak pantai ini terkenal amat cocok untuk dijadikan tempat selancar selain keindahan alam Bali yang memang amat cantik.

NB : Mohon hati-hati dengan barang bawaan anda seperti tas yang ada makanan atau minuman, sunglasses, mobile phone  karena ada kera yang suka mencuri barang-barang tersebut

Uluwatu Temple (Pura Luhur Uluwatu) is one of Bali�s most breathtaking cultural and natural landmarks � a place where spirituality meets the raw beauty of the ocean. Perched dramatically on the edge of a towering cliff, the temple offers some of the most stunning sunset views you�ll ever witness. The panoramic sight of waves crashing against the cliffs beneath the golden sky is nothing short of magical.

Beyond its scenic charm, the temple holds deep cultural and spiritual significance for the Balinese people. The architecture, stone carvings, and peaceful ambiance give visitors a glimpse into Bali�s sacred heritage. Arrive before sunset to explore the grounds and then stay for the Kecak fire dance performance, which takes place every evening � a mesmerizing cultural show set against the backdrop of the ocean.

A quick tip: watch out for the playful monkeys near the entrance; they�re cheeky and love sunglasses and hats!

Overall, Uluwatu Temple is an absolute must-visit in Bali � a perfect blend of culture, nature, and soul-stirring beauty that will stay with you long after you�ve left.

Perched high on cliffs overlooking the Indian Ocean, Uluwatu Temple (Pura Luhur Uluwatu) is nothing short of magical. The dramatic ocean views, especially at sunset, take your breath away. Inside the grounds, the sacred temple architecture has a soulful calm, while the daily Kecak Fire Dance performance at dusk adds drama and culture. Just be prepared: mischievous monkeys love to snatch hats, glasses and anything loose. Despite small crowds and a little chaos during showtimes, the mix of spirituality, natural beauty, culture and sunset makes visiting Uluwatu a truly unforgettable experience.

We absolutely adored Uluwatu Temple! It�s an awe-inspiring, spiritual, and prestigious place, especially if you value Balinese religion and culture. You can walk around and explore at your own pace, or hire a guide for more insight into its history and significance. The views are breathtaking � truly an unmissable experience.

I visited this place after hearing so many glowing praises, and the temple grounds certainly lived up to the hype with their well-maintained premises and genuinely scenic views.

?A necessary caution for visitors: the entire area has a significant monkey population, so be extremely careful not to carry any loose items.

We arrived at 5:15 PM and, since the 6:00 PM show was already booked solid, we immediately purchased tickets for the 7:00 PM performance. This left us with about half an hour to explore the temple.
?However, when we returned to the main entrance, we were met with a huge, chaotic queue for the show. The crowd management was truly pathetic, with people aggressively rushing to get in. This severely detracted from the experience before the performance even began.
?On a point of civic responsibility, it's worth noting that the organizers do not sell tickets beyond the capacity of the venue. Therefore, visitors should be patient and just, and avoid the impulse to rush the entrance.

The dance itself was good. The performers were all excellent, delivering a strong and enjoyable show.

?The overall performance lasted about 50 minutes. While many reviews call it 'mesmerizing and magical,' our experience was unfortunately interrupted. Just five minutes into the show, it began to rain. Although the performance continued without stopping in the open-air amphitheater, and we were provided with temporary raincoats, it remained a 'good show' at best for us, certainly not magical given the conditions.

An announcement was made stating that everyone would get a chance to take pictures with the artists after the performance. We waited patiently for a long time, but when only 3-4 families were left, the performers suddenly and abruptly left the stage. This was a frustrating and disheartening end to the night.

This was my personal experience. While the temple's beauty and the performers' talent are undeniable, the poor crowd control, the untimely rain, and the broken promise of a photo opportunity dampened the evening. It may still be a worthwhile and interesting visit for others, especially if the weather holds up and all attendees act responsibly.

Uluwatu Temple (Pura Luhur Uluwatu) is one of Bali�s most famous Hindu sea temples, dramatically perched on a cliff about 70 meters above the Indian Ocean and offering breathtaking sunset views. It is one of Bali�s six key temples and holds deep spiritual significance as a place dedicated to the sea gods. The complex features striking Balinese architecture, ancient stone carvings, and Ganesha statues, and while an entry fee is required (including a sarong), visitors should note that access is restricted to the surrounding gardens rather than the inner sanctum. The grounds are also home to long-tailed macaques, who are notorious for grabbing belongings such as phones, glasses, or bags�during our visit, one monkey even snatched a tourist�s brand-new iPhone 17 Pro Max and smashed the screen. Although local staff help retrieve stolen items, they often return them damaged, and signage in English with clear dos and don�ts is limited. We were advised by friends to be cautious, which helped us avoid losses, but we saw many tourists fall victim. While we didn�t attend the Kecak Dance ourselves, several travelers we spoke to shared that it was marketed as a �fire dance� but turned out to be more of a mythological performance with only minimal fire elements, leaving them disappointed. Adding to this, local guides were pushy and demanded extra money at the end, which felt like a scam. Overall, despite its cultural significance and scenic beauty, the aggressive monkeys, limited temple access, unclear expectations, and poor visitor experience made our visit underwhelming.

Watching the sunset at Uluwatu Temple followed by the 6 PM Kecak Dance show was truly magical! The temple sits on a stunning cliff with breathtaking ocean views, especially at sunset. The Kecak Dance was mesmerizing, with chanting, fire, and storytelling from the Ramayana, perfectly timed with the sunset in the background.

Tips: Arrive early to get good seats for the show, as it gets very crowded. Be mindful of the monkeys around the temple as they may grab loose items like sunglasses or hats. Overall, it�s the perfect mix of culture, tradition, and natural beauty � a must-visit in Bali!

I very much enjoyed the show in the amphitheatre overlooking thenocean at sunset.

Do try to arrive by 5:15-5:30 for the 6 o'clock show. Attendants will encourage people to sit closer several times so that as many people as possible can sit.

Once the show begins:
- Read the information sheet to know what is going on and appreciate an ancient story being told in a majestic context by a group of highly skilled performers. Accept that it is unfamiliar and enjoy.
- Do not chat loudly, but wisper with your friends.
- Do not watch Tik Tok, Instagram, etc with the volume on if you are bored.
- Do no stand-up to capture something, as others also want to see.
- And, though we admire assertive people who have the gumption to ask a whole row of people to "please move down... we also want to see the show", doing so when the show is already on and complaining "why are they asking me to sush-down?" when you keeps complaining about not having enough room is the definition of "disruptive". You are guests to something unique even though you have paid to attend.
- Don't expect the actors to jump into the crowd or to recruit you (hint hint)

There are positives about visiting this temple but the negatives far outweigh them. #1 the transport. Coming from Denpasar, Kuta to be exact, in the late morning it took 1 hour and 15 minutes each way. The roads are one lane all the way, crowded and windy. #2 the access. You will not be able to step into the temple, or get anywhere near it. That access is restricted to monks only. #3 the monkeys. They may look cute in pictures but they are aggressive and will steal anything that they can get their hands on. I personally saw cell phones stolen, glasses and water bottles. They don't care if you're holding something, they will grab at it and try to take it. #4 the serang. You have to wear it, and it's not washed, and made from polyester so you will be hot while wearing it. Positives? Stunning views of the cliffs, entry ticket is cheap at c. $3/3.50 USD

Visiting Uluwatu Temple to watch the Kecak Dance was an unforgettable experience. The temple itself is perched dramatically on a cliff overlooking the ocean, and the view at sunset is absolutely breathtaking. ?

The Kecak Dance performance was mesmerizing�set against the backdrop of the sunset, with the sound of chanting and the energy of the performers creating a truly magical atmosphere. It�s not just a show, but a cultural experience that really captures the spirit of Bali.

The area is well-organized, and the staff did a great job managing the crowd while still keeping the atmosphere comfortable. I�d recommend arriving a little early to get good seats and to explore the temple grounds before the performance begins.

Overall, it�s a must-visit when in Bali�both for the stunning scenery and the chance to experience one of Bali�s most iconic cultural traditions.

We visited on a Saturday afternoon, lots of people but the line moves quickly. Views are beautiful. Dress modestly, sarongs provided for people wearing shorts. Entry fee 100k and fire show 150k per person. If you want the sunset fire show it's best to book ahead of time, they also do a second show with enough tickets for to purchase on site. If you are in the second show, there's a lot of waiting around. There are tour groups as well as people just exploring on their own. The monkeys are so habituated to people to the point of stealing glasses from your face. If this happens, there are locals nearby who will bribe the monkeys with food to get them back, but you'll need to pay them - 100k seems to be the asking price. This reinforces the stealing behaviours of monkeys so it happens at high frequency. Personally I'd recommend skipping this place, plenty of other temples to visit and put the money towards a lovely meal at any of the restaurants on the west side  with the exact same cliffside sunset view

Il Tempio di Uluwatu � una tappa che rimane nel cuore. Arroccato su una scogliera a picco sull�oceano, ti accoglie con una vista che toglie il fiato: l�acqua che si infrange sulle rocce sotto di te e l�orizzonte che sembra infinito. An absolutely stunning place that must be visited at least once on your Bali trip. Surreal cliff views, mesmerising Kecak dance. The temple is almost bare and locked for tourists (as is the case with most temples in Bali) but the temple ground is the real beauty and like a walk in a nature park with ocean setting in the background.
Word of caution : The monkeys are notorious and snatch from unsuspecting tourists, one has to be very careful and avoid wearing hats/caps, sunglasses and/or anything flashy there.

If you wish to see Kecak dance (which is the traditional balinese dance and also most of the people visit uluwatu temple only for seeing the Kecak) , it's better to book online tickets 2 or 3 weeks before. Because may be you'll not get the 6p.m. show which has a beautiful sunset view with the Kecak dance if you wish to buy tickets on spot. Then may be you can see the 7 p.m. show but there is a long queue for the tickets and there is limited seats. So it�s not guaranteed you'll get the ticket. Also online tickets are cheaper than the tickets you buy from the temple. We bought our tickets from the  temple, cost Rp-150k per person and didn�t get the 6pm slot. We had to wait for 3 hours for the show.

The expectation was set too far away from the reality.
I've lived in SriLanka for 5 years and visited a lot of Buddhist templates. When they say visit temple, you visit the temple, you walk in bare foot, you respect, follow rules, and seat next to many others who are paying. This location sell ticket to enter the temple but it ONLY allow you to walk around the temple's garden. No one was allowed to go inside.
Walking around the garden, you have to be very self-aware and your surroundings. Monkeys would steal anything you have on you, glasses, mobiles, anything they can grab. Even though they are many locals officially tasked to be around the garden to assist people getting their stuff back, you may get a piece of your glass or broken mobile. I did not see any big clear signs anywhere when we entered in english clearly says what to do what not! I have not lost anything as I have been advised by a friend,  but I saw many victims.
For the show we attended we had to buy a seperate ticket, we thought it is a fire dance show as the name says, but it was a mix of mythological, fun engaging, not really much fire dance.
As mentioned earlier the expectations were set not right, hence the experience was not good at allfor everyone in our group.

Rabies shots: 2,7 Million in Nusa Penida for 1 shot, you need 4 (or 2 if you are already vaccinated). Or: Go, but stay faaaar away from the monkeys. Only go to watch the sunset here.

Uluwatu Temple is a magical spot you can't miss in Bali. Perched on a cliff with endless ocean views, it�s stunning any time of day�but the sunset here is truly next level. Watching the famous Kecak dance as the sun dips into the sea is an unforgettable experience. The atmosphere, the sound of the waves, and the energy of the performance make it feel almost otherworldly. A perfect mix of culture, nature, and beauty.

We zijn in 2022 al eens bij de Uluwatu Temple geweest. Het is een schitterende plek met prachtige uitzichten. Let wel goed op de apen, want ze pakken echt alles af � van telefoon tot bril of zelfs een slipper.

Arrive early to buy tickets ( recommended arrive 4-4:30) for evening dance performance and despite  waiting on line for 1/2 hr to buy tickets for evening show by the time I was able to purchase already sold out and we already had ride arranged and we were hungry so did not stay for late evening show. They allow people to buy as many tickets as they want and tour groups we're buying 25 plus tickets. No food within temple area. So if hungry and want to wait for show you are out of luck. We went on a Tuesday.  Arrived and lined up at 4pm for tickets.  There was a large line, but we got tickets for the 6pm show.  There was also a large line for those that bought in advance.  The theater was full for the show.  There was also a 7pm show in August that had a mass of people lined up as we exited.  We tried to see the temple as there was still 15 min to closing but they had closed it already.  You probably need to arrive at 3pm-ish to see the temple and be able to line up for tickets.

In August the sun is very intense while sitting in the theater waiting for the show to start.  It's general seating so we sat for nearly an hour.   You sit on concrete so you may want to bring a cushion.  You will want sunscreen and maybe a hat and umbrella to shade yourself before the show.

Visiting Uluwatu Temple was one of the highlights of our Bali trip. The location itself is breathtaking � perched on a dramatic cliff overlooking the endless blue ocean, the views are unforgettable, especially during sunset.

Temple & Atmosphere:
The temple grounds are serene and carry a deep spiritual energy. It�s a place where culture, history, and nature blend beautifully. Just being there as the sun goes down feels magical.

Kecak Dance Performance:
The famous Kecak fire dance at Uluwatu is an absolute must-see. Performed right at the edge of the cliff with the golden sunset as the backdrop, the chants, rhythm, and storytelling were mesmerizing. It�s an experience that gives you a true taste of Balinese culture.

Tickets & Entry:
One thing to note is that even if you buy your ticket online, you still need to collect a physical ticket for the dance show at the counter. On top of that, you�ll need to purchase a separate entrance ticket to enter the temple grounds. There were long queues both for the tickets and entry, but the experience was totally worth the wait.

Overall:
Uluwatu Temple is more than just a sightseeing spot � it�s a cultural and spiritual journey. Between the jaw-dropping cliff views, the captivating Kecak dance, and the unique Balinese atmosphere, it�s an experience I�d highly recommend to anyone visiting Bali.

Il Tempio di Uluwatu, o Pura Luhur Uluwatu, � uno dei luoghi pi� iconici e mozzafiato di Bali. Arroccato su una scogliera a picco sul mare, a circa 70 metri di altezza, offre una vista panoramica incredibile sull'Oceano Indiano. L'atmosfera che si respira qui � a dir poco magica, specialmente al tramonto, quando il cielo si tinge di sfumature arancioni e rosa.
La sua storia e la sua spiritualit� sono profondamente radicate nella cultura balinese. Il tempio � dedicato al dio del mare e si ritiene che protegga Bali dalle forze maligne. Sebbene non sia possibile entrare nella parte pi� sacra del tempio, la passeggiata lungo il sentiero che costeggia la scogliera � un'esperienza indimenticabile.
Oltre alla bellezza del tempio, il sito � famoso per gli spettacoli di danza Kecak che si tengono ogni sera. Questa danza, che rappresenta una storia epica del Ramayana, � eseguita da un coro di uomini che emettono un "chak-a-chak" ritmico, creando un'atmosfera ipnotica. Assistere a questo spettacolo con il sole che tramonta sull'oceano � un'esperienza che rimarr� per sempre nel cuore.
Unica avvertenza: fate attenzione alle scimmie! Le scimmie del tempio sono note per essere piuttosto dispettose e non esitano a rubare occhiali da sole, cappelli o altri oggetti luccicanti. La visita al Tempio di Uluwatu � un must per chiunque si trovi a Bali, una combinazione perfetta di spiritualit�, natura e cultura.

The skies paint a beautiful backdrop of orange and pink hues, with waves crashing against the cliffs below. It�s a photographer�s dream spot. Another highlight is the Kecak Fire Dance performed in an open-air amphitheater near the temple grounds. Also it has holy snake  who protect the temple. It has black sand which is awesome .

Uluwatu Temple is one of the most breathtaking spots in Bali. Placed on a dramatic cliff overlooking the Indian Ocean, the views are absolutely stunning, especially during sunset (golden hour, great for some awesome pics). The temple itself is serene and rich in cultural significance, offering a peaceful and spiritual atmosphere.

The famous Kecak fire dance performed at sunset adds to the magical experience and is highly recommended. Though, most of the times it is packed, so better to check alternatives as well for the Kecak (like at the GWK Status).

P.S. Just be cautious of the monkeys, they�re clever and quick to grab loose items like phones, jewellery, bags, etc.

A perfect blend of culture, nature, and history. Definitely a must-visit when in Bali.

Perched high on a breathtaking cliff overlooking the Indian Ocean. Imagine ancient stone pathways sweeping sea views, mystical energy, and sunsets so beautifully they will leave you speechless.
Pro tips:
1. Arrive by 3 pm to explore the temple and enjoy the views before it gets dark. There are many stairs to climb to get to the temple.
2. By 5 pm, find a cozy spot at the open air amphitheater for the sunset Kecak dance.
3. Monkey alert: do not wear glasses, jewelry, food, hats and loose items. They will grab them. Keep your phone and camera secure. Don�t make eye contact.

It isn�t just a tourist attraction. It is where nature, culture and spirituality come alive in the most stunning way. You will leave with more than just pictures. You will carry a memory that will stay with you forever!

**Uluwatu Temple** (locally known as **Pura Luhur Uluwatu**) is one of Bali�s most iconic sea temples. Perched dramatically on a steep cliff about 70 meters above the Indian Ocean, it offers breathtaking views, especially at sunset.

Here�s a quick overview:

---

###  **About Uluwatu Temple**

* **Location**: Southern tip of Bali, Indonesia
* **Religious Importance**: One of the six key temples believed to be Bali's spiritual pillars.
* **Hindu Deity**: Dedicated to **Sang Hyang Widhi Wasa** in his manifestation as **Rudra**, the god of storms and the wind.

---

###  **Why Visit?**

* **Cliffside Views**: The temple is situated on a stunning cliff with expansive ocean views.
* **Sunset Spot**: It�s one of the best places in Bali to watch the sunset.
* **Kecak Dance Performance**: A traditional Balinese dance performed at sunset daily in an open-air amphitheater.
* **Monkeys**: The temple is home to a lot of macaques. They�re notorious for stealing items like sunglasses and hats, so be cautious!

---

###  **Tips for Visiting**

* **Entry Fee**: Around IDR 30,000 (may vary slightly).
* **Dress Code**: Sarongs and sashes are provided at the entrance; modest attire is required.
* **Best Time to Visit**: Late afternoon to catch the sunset and the Kecak dance.
* **Transport**: It's best accessed via private driver or scooter. Public transport is limited.

Uluwatu Temple is located in the southwestern part of Bali. It is famous for its location - an iconic sea temple perched on a cliff. The view from the cliff is breathtaking, and beautiful sunsets can be seen from here.

Uluwatu Temple is also well known for its Kecak fire dance. There are two show timings: one at 6 PM and another at 7 PM, both during sunset. The fire dance depicts the story of the Ramayana.

One thing to be cautious about is the large monkeys roaming around the temple. They may snatch mobile phones, sunglasses, bags, or anything you're holding. There are staff members dedicated to helping retrieve items taken by the monkeys, but it's advisable to always keep your belongings safely inside your bag.

If you are wearing shorts, you need to put purple sarong which they will provide, otherwise orange sash (scarf) will be provided which you can tie around your waist.

Amazing temple to go visit. We went first thing (7am) so had the entire grounds to ourselves. Had a lovely walk round and took in the beautiful views.

He then proceeded to laugh and basically told us good luck if you get attacked by a monkey. I understand that volunteers / employees can be there to take people round on a tour but only if people want that, there is no need to be pushy or rude if people deny this, and especially not laugh at the fact we might get attacked by monkeys.

Visiting Uluwatu Temple in the late evening was an unforgettable experience! The sunset views were absolutely breathtaking, with the golden hues reflecting over the ocean and the temple�s dramatic cliffside setting. The natural beauty here is unmatched, making it a must-visit spot in Bali.

Adding to the magic was the Kecak dance performance, which was both captivating and culturally enriching. The rhythmic chants, fiery visuals, and the backdrop of the setting sun created a mesmerizing atmosphere.

I highly recommend Uluwatu Temple for its stunning sunsets, incredible views, and the unique Kecak dance show. It�s a perfect blend of nature, culture, and spirituality. A definite highlight of any Bali trip!
