I was walking and taking video of the monkeys and the scenery then my glasses was taken by one of the large monkeys. It started eating the plastic part of the glasses. A Lebanese couple stayed to help and the locals came in and threw a bag of fruit to the monkey in exchange for my broken glasses. It dropped my glasses but other monkeys took it. I then took out a sun glasses (with prescription) from my bag thinking I should be able to recover the first pair of glasses. However, within a minute my sunny was taken by another large monkey. The locals security came in but only could retrieve the first damaged pair of glasses. It was an extremely bad experience in Bali. The two pairs costed me nearly $1500. I thought it was bad enough then came with an Indian saying his iPhone was taken only a few meters away from me. I spent the next 30min telling tourists on my way back to be aware of the monkeys attack.

Looks like the monkeys have formed the habit of taking items from tourists. With the amount of tourists passing through each day, the authorities shall have enough funding to work on some sensible counter measures against these unpleasant behaviors from the monkeys.

History of Uluwatu Temple

Uluwatu Temple, or�Pura Luhur Uluwatu, is one of the six key directional temples in Bali. Its exact founding date remains uncertain, but historical records suggest that the temple dates back to at least the�9th century, with evidence of an ancient�candi kurung�(split gateway) bearing a�candrasengkala (chronogram)�indicating the year�808 Isaka (886 AD).

The temple�s development is often attributed to�Mpu Kuturan, a highly influential Hindu sage who arrived in Bali during the reign of�King Sri Msula-Masuli�in the�11th century. Mpu Kuturan introduced the concept of�Tri Kahyangan, which classified Balinese temples into three spiritual centers: village temples, mountain temples, and sea temples. Uluwatu Temple was established as a�sea temple, meant to protect Bali from negative spiritual forces coming from the ocean. Its dramatic location, perched on a�70-meter-high limestone cliff, symbolizes its role as a guardian of Bali�s southwestern coastline.

The Role of Uluwatu Temple in Balinese Hindu Culture

Uluwatu Temple is one of�Bali�s Sad Kahyangan, or six holiest temples, strategically placed around the island to maintain�spiritual balance. It serves as a�guardian of the southwest direction, protecting Bali from negative forces and aligning with other directional temples to create a sacred grid of energy.

The temple is dedicated to�Shiva Rudra, the manifestation of Lord Shiva as the�god of transformation and dissolution. Balinese Hindus regularly visit Uluwatu Temple to offer prayers, seek blessings, and participate in religious ceremonies, particularly during�Piodalan, the temple�s anniversary, which is celebrated every�210 days�according to the�Balinese Pawukon calendar

Iconic Statues of Uluwatu

Kumba Karna Kerebut Statue

The�Kumba Karna Kerebut Statue�at Uluwatu Temple depicts�Kumbakarna, a legendary warrior from the Hindu epic�Ramayana. Known for his immense strength and unwavering loyalty, Kumbakarna fought in the battle against�Lord Rama�out of duty rather than malice. The statue symbolizes�sacrifice, devotion, and moral integrity, values deeply embedded in Balinese Hindu teachings.

Positioned among Uluwatu�s dramatic cliffs, the statue is often associated with the�sacred monkeys�that inhabit the temple grounds. The intricate carvings bring to life the struggle between�Kumbakarna and the Vanara army, blending mythology with the natural surroundings, making it an important cultural and spiritual landmark.
Danghyang Nirartha Statue
The Danghyang Nirartha Statue honors one of Bali�s most revered Hindu priests, Danghyang Nirartha, who played a crucial role in shaping Balinese Hinduism in the 16th century. He is credited with founding several major temples, including Pura Uluwatu, where he is believed to have attained moksha (spiritual liberation) through deep meditation on the temple�s cliffs.

The statue, depicted in a serene meditative pose, represents wisdom, enlightenment, and spiritual guidance. As a key figure in Balinese religious history, Nirartha�s influence is still felt today in temple rituals and traditional ceremonies, making his statue a place of reverence and reflection for visitors.

The Wonderful Beauties of Uluwatu Temple
Cliffside Temple-Perched 70 meters above the Indian Ocean.
Breathtaking Sunset-One of Bali�s most spectacular sunset spots.

Plan Your Visit
Opening Hours & Entrance Fees
Entrance Fee
To enter Uluwatu Temple, visitors are required to pay an entrance fee, which helps with the temple�s maintenance and conservation efforts. Below is the updated ticket pricing:
International Visitors:
Adult: IDR 50,000 Child: IDR 30,000
Domestic Visitors:
Adult: IDR 30,000 Child: IDR 20,000
Note: The entrance fee does not include parking or the ticket for the Kecak Dance performance, which requires a separate ticket purchase.
Opening Hours
Uluwatu Temple is open to visitors every day from 7:00 AM to 7:00 PM. The temple welcomes both local and international travelers who wish to experience its breathtaking views, cultural heritage, spiritual importance

Uluwatu Temple is one of the most stunning places I visited in Bali! Perched on a high cliff overlooking the ocean, the view is absolutely breathtaking especially during sunset. The temple itself has a peaceful and spiritual vibe, with beautiful traditional architecture and sacred energy all around. The Kecak dance performance at sunset is a must-see; the setting, the chants, and the ocean backdrop make it unforgettable. Just be mindful of the monkeys they�re cheeky but part of the fun! Overall, it�s a magical spot that captures the heart and spirit of Bali.

One of the most iconic temples in Bali, perched dramatically on a cliff overlooking the Indian Ocean. The view at sunset is absolutely stunning � a must-see experience. The atmosphere is peaceful and deeply spiritual, and it's one of the most sacred sites for Balinese Hindus.

You can also enjoy the traditional Kecak dance performance at the open-air theatre during sunset � a unique cultural experience.
Watch out for the monkeys in the area � they�re clever and love to snatch small items.

Highly recommend visiting before sunset to enjoy the full experience.

If you�re a photographer, go at sunset and point your shot towards the break water area. Wait for a big wave to hit the shore and capture the splashes as the sunset light touches those droplets and haze.

A sacred experience beyond words. Visiting Uluwatu Temple was not just a sightseeing moment � it was a spiritual journey. The energy here is deeply felt, especially during prayer at the highest point of the temple. We were guided by a kind Balinese priest who welcomed us with warmth and reverence, gently leading us through the rituals.

Wearing traditional Balinese temple attire is a must if you wish to enter the sacred inner area for prayer � a reminder of the respect this holy site deserves. As we stood at the edge of the cliff overlooking the vast ocean, it felt like the veil between worlds grew thinner. A truly humbling and soul-anchoring experience.

Highly recommended for those seeking more than just beautiful views � come with an open heart, and you�ll leave with a blessed spirit. ?

#UluwatuTemple #SpiritualBali #SacredTravel #BalineseBlessings

Breathtaking views and a cultural must-see in Bali!

Uluwatu Temple is truly one of the most iconic and scenic places in Bali. Perched dramatically on the edge of a cliff, the views of the Indian Ocean are absolutely stunning�especially at sunset. The whole atmosphere is spiritual and serene, and the ocean breeze makes the experience even more magical.

We also attended the Kecak Fire Dance at sunset, which was a mesmerizing cultural performance in an open-air amphitheater right by the cliff. It�s definitely worth timing your visit around the show�just make sure to get there early to grab good seats.

One word of caution: the monkeys! They�re clever and can snatch sunglasses, phones, or even hats, so keep your belongings secure and avoid carrying anything loose.

There are a few steps and uneven paths, so wear comfortable shoes and be prepared to walk a bit.

Overall, Uluwatu Temple is a must-visit in Bali for the views, the cultural significance, and the unforgettable sunset experience.

Uluwatu Temple (Pura Luhur Uluwatu) is one of Bali�s most iconic sea temples, perched dramatically on the edge of a 70-meter-high cliff overlooking the Indian Ocean. The views here are absolutely breathtaking, especially during sunset, when the sky glows and waves crash against the rocks below � a photographer�s dream!

The temple itself is sacred to the Balinese and holds deep spiritual significance. Visitors are required to wear a sarong, which is available at the entrance, and to be respectful as this is an active place of worship.

One of the highlights is the Kecak fire dance performance, held daily at sunset. It�s a mesmerizing and powerful show set against the backdrop of the ocean � not to be missed!

There are wild monkeys roaming the temple grounds. While they can be amusing, they�re also notorious for grabbing sunglasses, hats, and even phones, so hold on to your belongings.

The paths around the cliffs are well-maintained, offering amazing viewpoints, but can get slippery in the rain, so be cautious.

Crowds do gather at peak hours, but the overall experience is magical. A visit to Uluwatu Temple is a perfect mix of natural beauty, culture, and spirituality � one of the best experiences in Bali.

Uluwatu Temple is truly a magical place! Perched dramatically on a cliffside, it offers breathtaking views of the Indian Ocean, especially at sunset. The atmosphere is serene and spiritual, with traditional Balinese architecture and playful monkeys adding to the charm. Don�t miss the Kecak dance performance at sunset � it�s an unforgettable cultural experience with the ocean as a backdrop. A must-visit when in Bali!

We went to watch the traditional Kecak dance at Uluwatu Temple. We had tickets for the 7:00 PM session, but in hindsight, we wish we had chosen the earlier one  once it gets dark, you miss out on the beautiful sunset and the magical ocean view that makes the atmosphere so special.

Even though I had purchased my ticket a week in advance, we had to wait in line for nearly 1.5 hours. It�s clearly a very popular show. Unfortunately, during the performance, most of the Indian tourists left with zero respect for the dancers or the audience, which was quite upsetting and distracting.

There are a lot of monkeys around the temple, but since it was already dark, we couldn�t see them very well, and staff were also keeping them away from the show area.

I highly recommend learning about the story and background of the Kecak dance before attending it makes the experience much more meaningful when you understand what you�re watching.

Overall, it was a beautiful and unforgettable cultural experience, and I�d definitely recommend it to anyone looking to explore something unique and traditional in Bali.

Der Tempel Pura Luhur Uluwatu ist ohne Zweifel einer der beeindruckendsten Orte auf Bali. Hoch oben auf einer Klippe mit spektakul�rem Blick �ber den Indischen Ozean, bietet dieser Ort nicht nur spirituelle Atmosph�re, sondern auch atemberaubende Sonnenunterg�nge.

Ein echtes Highlight ist die traditionelle Kecak-Feuertanz-Show am Abend � eine kulturelle Darbietung, die in dieser Kulisse einfach magisch wirkt.

 Achtung wegen der Affen!
So sch�n der Ort auch ist, die vielen freilaufenden Affen k�nnen sehr aufdringlich sein. Sie klauen gerne Sonnenbrillen, Handys, H�te oder sogar Wasserflaschen. Es ist sehr wichtig, nichts in der Hand zu tragen und gut auf seine Sachen aufzupassen � die Affen sind schnell und clever! Manchmal wirken sie harmlos, k�nnen aber auch aggressiv werden, wenn man versucht, etwas zur�ckzuholen.

?? Fazit: Ein absolutes Muss auf Bali wegen der Kulisse, der Kultur und der Energie des Ortes � aber mit Vorsicht und Vorbereitung wegen der Affen. Lieber alles Wertvolle im Rucksack lassen und ruhig bleiben!

Manzarasi �ok g�zel bir tapinak biz gittigimiz zaman �ok kalabalik degildi. Rahatlikla y�r�y�s yolundan tapinagi gezebiliyorsunuz. Maymunlara kesinlikle dikkat etmeniz gerekiyor arkadasimin g�zl�g�n� g�z�nde takiliyken aldi. �ok ugraslar sonucunda geri alabilirdik.

If you're planning a trip to Bali and looking for something that combines natural beauty, cultural depth, and pure entertainment, I can�t recommend Uluwatu Temple enough. Visiting this place was one of the highlights of my entire trip!

Perched high on a dramatic cliff overlooking the vast Indian Ocean, Uluwatu Temple offers some of the most breathtaking views you�ll ever see�especially during sunset. The temple itself is beautiful and historic, with a peaceful yet powerful energy. But what made my experience truly unforgettable was the Kecak dance performance held right next to the cliff edge as the sun went down.

I had so much fun watching the show! The Kecak dance is unlike anything I�ve ever seen�it�s not just a performance, it�s an experience. The way dozens of men chant in harmony, creating a rhythm with only their voices, while dancers tell the story of Ramayana through expressive movement, was both mesmerizing and exciting. Add to that the dramatic backdrop of the ocean, the setting sun, and the temple silhouette, and it honestly felt like something out of a movie. I was completely immersed the whole time.

Here are a few tips if you plan to go (and you definitely should!):

Arrive around 4:30 PM so you have time to explore the temple grounds and find a good seat for the dance.

Bring a sarong or use the one provided at the entrance�they�re required for temple entry.

Grab your ticket for the Kecak show early�it fills up quickly, and the best seats are first-come, first-served.

Watch your belongings�there are cheeky monkeys around (cute, but clever!).

Whether you're traveling solo, with a partner, or in a group, Uluwatu Temple and the Kecak dance show offer a perfect mix of nature, spirituality, and local culture. It�s one of those Bali experiences that stays with you long after the trip is over.

Highly, highly recommended!

�	Danza Kecak al tramonto: Un�esperienza da non perdere � la tradizionale danza Kecak, eseguita all�aperto con il sole che cala alle spalle del tempio. Il ritmo ipnotico dei canti e l�ambientazione naturale creano uno spettacolo unico.

Pura Luhur Uluwatu atau Pura Uluwatu merupakan pura yang berada di wilayah Desa Adat Pecatu, Kecamatan Kuta Selatan, Kabupaten Badung.Pura yang terletak di ujung barat daya pulau Bali di atas anjungan batu karang yang terjal dan tinggi serta menjorok ke laut ini merupakan Pura Sad Kayangan yang dipercaya oleh orang Hindu sebagai penyangga dari 9 mata angin. Pura ini pada mulanya digunakan menjadi tempat memuja seorang pendeta suci dari abad ke-11 bernama Empu Kuturan. Ia menurunkan ajaran Desa Adat dengan segala aturannya.

Pura ini juga dipakai untuk memuja pendeta suci berikutnya, yaitu Dang Hyang Nirartha, yang datang ke Bali pada akhir tahun 1550 dan mengakhiri perjalanan sucinya dengan apa yang dinamakan Moksa atau Ngeluhur di tempat ini. Kata inilah yang menjadi asal nama Pura Luhur Uluwatu.

Pura Uluwatu terletak pada ketinggian 97 meter dari permukaan laut. Di depan pura terdapat hutan kecil yang disebut alas kekeran, berfungsi sebagai penyangga kesucian pura.

Pura Uluwatu mempunyai beberapa pura pesanakan, yaitu pura yang erat kaitannya dengan pura induk. Pura pesanakan itu yaitu Pura Bajurit, Pura Pererepan, Pura Kulat, Pura Dalem Selonding dan Pura Dalem Pangleburan. Masing-masing pura ini mempunyai kaitan erat dengan Pura Uluwatu, terutama pada hari-hari piodalan-nya. Piodalan di Pura Uluwatu, Pura Bajurit, Pura Pererepan dan Pura Kulat jatuh pada Selasa Kliwon Wuku Medangsia setiap 210 hari. Manifestasi Tuhan yang dipuja di Pura Uluwatu adalah Dewa Rudra.

Pura Uluwatu juga menjadi terkenal karena tepat di bawahnya adalah pantai Pecatu yang sering kali digunakan sebagai tempat untuk olahraga selancar, bahkan event internasional sering kali diadakan di sini. Ombak pantai ini terkenal amat cocok untuk dijadikan tempat selancar selain keindahan alam Bali yang memang amat cantik.

Uluwatu Temple is a truly special and extraordinary place. A temple built atop steep coral cliffs (likely over 100 meters high) overlooking the ocean. It has a vast, terraced area with quite high levels, and the breathtaking open sea views make you want to stay here for hours. The beautiful and intricate temple ornaments add to its charm.

However, the presence of mischievous wild monkeys keeps visitors on edge and requires caution. On the other hand, these monkeys add a dramatic, natural touch to the experience. As sunset approaches, the Kecak dance performance creates an incredible, almost magical allure.

Irecently visited Uluwatu Temple in Bali, and it was truly an unforgettable experience! Perched on a cliff overlooking the Indian Ocean, the temple's stunning architecture and breathtaking views made for a perfect combination.

The temple's cliffside location offers panoramic views of the ocean and surrounding landscape.
Uluwatu Temple is a significant Hindu temple in Bali, showcasing the island's rich cultural heritage.
The temple's intricate carvings and traditional Balinese design make it a must-see attraction.
The temple's nightly Kecak Fire Dance performance is a mesmerizing spectacle.
1. Beat the crowds and enjoy the sunrise or early morning views.
2. Respect the temple's dress code and wear appropriate attire.
3. Take time to explore the temple grounds and admire the intricate carvings.
Overall Experience
Uluwatu Temple is a must-visit destination in Bali, offering a unique blend of natural beauty, rich history, and cultural significance. Don't miss it! ?

Prices are: 1.000 per bike for parking, 50.000 per person for temple ticket and 150.000 per person per show ticket. The temple is in a beautiful location. Loads of not really friendly monkeys that will steal your accessories if you have any (sunglasses, earrings, hats, cameras, phones, water bottles etc), but if you keep everything in your bag, you should be fine. Go to the bathroom before it gets darks since it's a long jungle corridor with no lights. The show was good, and very interesting (they also gave us raincoats in case of rain).

The sea itself is a vast expanse of shimmering blue, transitioning in shades from deep navy near the horizon to turquoise closer to land. Distant boats may be visible as tiny white specks drifting slowly, adding to the sense of scale and serenity.

Besakih (Pura Besakih) is a temple complex in the village of Besakih on the slopes of Mount Agung in eastern Bali, Indonesia. It is the most important and largest temple of the Hindu religion in Bali. Situated almost 1,000 metres up the slope of Mount Agung, it is a vast complex of 23 separate but interconnected temples, the largest and most important of which is Pura Penataran Agung. The temple is built on six levels, terraced up the slope. The entrance is marked by a candi bentar gate, behind which is another kori agung gate into a second courtyard. Most of the time, the sun is hidden behind clouds here, and the temperature is 5 degrees Celsius lower than on the coast. Local people from the coast consider the area cool. The exact origins of the temple are unclear, but its significance as a holy place almost certainly dates to prehistoric times.  The stone foundations of Pura Penataran Agung and several other temples resemble megalithic step pyramids that are at least 2,000 years old.

The temple itself is absolutely breathtaking � peaceful, grand, and well worth the visit. The views are stunning, and the site is truly a gem.

However, the management and organisation seriously undermine the overall experience. The mandatory payment for a guide is completely pointless � the guide service adds no real value. In our case, the guide seemed far more interested in pushing us toward nearby shops offering photography services and souvenirs than actually explaining anything about the temple. When we firmly refused to buy or use any of those services, he simply left us mid-tour, and we ended up exploring the site on our own.

The shuttle service from the entry point to the temple is another disappointment. It�s one-way only, which is not mentioned anywhere on the ticket � a very poor system, especially since the shuttles return empty after dropping visitors off.

It�s a real pity because the temple and surroundings are magnificent, but the experience is overshadowed by poor management, lack of transparency, and unprofessional behaviour from the guides. I genuinely hope the authorities address these issues so that future visitors can enjoy this beautiful place without unnecessary frustration.

Besakih Temple is the largest Hindu Temple in the island of Bali, built on the slope of Mount Agung: to be precise it's a complex of 25 different but related temples. The entrance is marked by a "Candi Bentar", the famous split gateway that can be found all over Bali. Unfortunately when I visited there was bad weather so I couldn't enjoy the view of the surroundings. The temple itself is quite nice.
Absolutely stunning place to visit, should be one of the wonders of the world, if you visit Bali then make sure you visit this amazing bit of architecture.

The temple itself was absolutely breathtaking�peaceful, grand, and well worth the visit. Unfortunately, the experience was overshadowed by the mandatory guide, who repeatedly pressured me for donations and tips. At one point, he even counted my donation in front of others, saying it was �too small,� which felt very uncomfortable and disrespectful.

It�s a shame, because the spiritual atmosphere was beautiful, but the constant hassling made it hard to enjoy the moment. I hope future visitors can have a more respectful and serene experience.

Besakih Temple is the largest and holiest temple complex in Bali, Indonesia, dating back to prehistoric times. The temple is built on six levels and terraced up the slope of Mount Agung. It is the most important place of worship for Balinese Hindus and has been in use since the 13th century.

Besakih Temple is truly beautiful, with breathtaking views over Bali and its lush nature. However, I feel I have to comment on the way the site is managed for visitors, which was personally disappointing � especially considering this is Bali�s largest and most sacred Hindu temple.

The entry fee is 150K IDR, which is higher than average for temples in Bali. The ticket includes a sarong, a shuttle bus to the temple, and a private guide.

As I met my guide and headed to the shuttle bus, a group of temple ladies stopped me, insisting I had to buy an offering basket for 50K IDR. When I said I wasn�t interested, they pressured me to buy one, and my guide remained silent, so I felt forced to purchase it. Later I realised other visitors were not asked to do so, and a leaflet I was given prior stated offerings were suggested but not mandatory. When I asked the guide about it, he simply told me I could return it afterward for a refund � which confirmed the situation was misleading.

The guided visit itself lasted about 20 minutes, which I felt quite quick considering the size of the temple. We were not allowed inside all of the temple areas reserved for prayers, which is understandable, however that left us to only be able to walk around the various temples' gates. My guide provided very little information on the temple, its history, architecture etc despite my questions and only advised on good locations to take pictures. At the end, he even asked for an additional tip, even though the tour was brief and unsatisfactory, and said I could wonder around on my own as he had to leave. Only later did I learn from other guides that the original main temple is located slightly uphill � something my guide completely forgot to mention. I went there on my own and found it to be the most beautiful and historically significant part of the complex.

On the way back, I realised that the return shuttle is not included, so visitors have to walk 15 minutes downhill back to the entrance. I returned the offering basket to the ladies by the entrance and, after showing the leaflet, was refunded the money without a word, as I was saying how I did not appreciate to have been forced into buying when it was clearly not an obligation.

Overall, I was very disappointed that such a meaningful and spiritual place is managed in a way that allows behaviours to simply make money out of visitors. It was upsetting to be misled and pressured under the guise of sacred practice. I hope the management will improve, as the temple deserves to be remembered for its spiritual value and beauty � not for the unpleasant visitor experience.

Entrada car�sima en comparaci�n con el resto de templos, el gu�a tur�stico que estaba incluido en el tour nos subi� a la entrada principal y se quit� del medio, el estado de conversaci�n de los templos es malo y la sensaci�n con la que te quedas es de que has perdido casi dos horas de trayecto para ir, y dos horas de vuelta desde ubud.

I am very confused by my visit to Besakih Great Temple. My fianc� and I visited to learn more about the history and culture of this temple, and appreciate its holy nature.

After we paid entry, a woman right away was adamant we had to purchase offerings, so we did for 50k each - okay, fine.

Then we were introduced to our guide - an older man in his 60s, he seemed friendly and we followed him for the tour. However, things turned weird very quickly. The man spoke a lot about many irrelevant things and his knowledge of other religions was slightly incorrect and felt a bit patronising/repetitive. He then compared me to Indonesia miss universe and opened up his Facebook on his phone with multiple pictures of this young woman saying I look like her and she is beautiful. He then told every woman we passed how beautiful they were and called one an angel. He also spoke about different countries and surgical procedures and the prices involved. He gave unsolicited and very odd "advice" to us - saying things like I am with my fianc� for his "economy"/money, that after 30 it's too late to get married, things aren't perfect because we don't have a baby yet?!?!?! He talked about relationships and gave us pseudonames and tried to give us examples of life situations where we'd need to be good to each other, or how my fianc�'s path would be a big manager in a company with 5 female secretaries. He joked (or maybe seriously) said that as a wife I will be asking him for money to get my hair done or to buy an expensive handbag. Then he continued with saying attraction in a relationship is required - and as a joke (or maybe not) that it's good if I wear a bikini for my fianc�. Then he was showing us physically the different types of handshakes/physical touch people in politics vs a friendship vs a romance would do, and was rubbing my fianc�'s hand - it was all very strange and inappropriate. I'm shocked and flabbergasted to be quite frank.

That being said, credit where credit is due: he took some nice pictures for us and said a prayer for us during our offering prayers to wish us luck, happiness, etc.

But again, towards the end he said the tour was done, we said thank you, he replied with "tip??" I felt awkward and mainly had very large notes on me, so I picked the smallest I had (I probably shouldn't have) and it totalled around 16k. He looked at it very disappointed and said "wow this is not even a few euros..." - I just smiled and said hope that's okay, and we walked off. It was the only bad experience we've had in all of Indonesia.

My advice to staff: please stick to information and conversation about the temple and Balinese Hinduism only. Please tell this guide to not discuss other people's relationships or situations - you never know if a couple might have problems having a baby, what their ages are, what their history is, what their beliefs are. Please also tell him to not keep talking obsessively about women, it's strange and predatory. And also, better to not make physical contact with tourists.

My advice to other tourists: please speak up if anything like this happens to you. Solo female travellers, be careful. I was keeping my discomfort internal, but my fianc� was openly telling me he was incredibly uncomfortable and wanted to leave as soon as possible. For a man to feel uncomfortable, I would hope you understand that I'm not some "dramatic girl" about this situation.

Honestly, I would only recommend visiting if you have another guide. We didn't actually learn much but I guess we were very unlucky. We've seen other beautiful temples in Bali and enjoyed our visits and the guides were absolutely incredible and knowledgeable. Here it sadly ended in disappointment :(

Unfortunately the whole experience is designed to take tourists money, and to me that is not a spiritual experience.
It's a sell out and shameful that this happens in such a sacred place. It cost me and a friend $60 aud and the feeling from the guide is that you haven't given enough.

We visited Besakih Great Temple after hearing so many wonderful things about it, but unfortunately the experience felt very commercialized, perhaps due to the ongoing renovations (or maybe not). The ticket price is 150K per person (for tourists and 80K for locals), which includes a tour guide. The guided portion itself barely takes any time, and from the very beginning our guide laid the groundwork for asking for money by inquiring about our work and currency exchange rates. At the end, he asked for a tip, explaining that he does not receive anything from the ticket price. Visitors who have never been here should definitely be aware of this.

At the main area where tickets are purchased, salespeople immediately hand out offerings to each person. To anyone new, it might look like this is included in the ticket price, but it actually costs an additional 50K per offering. The tour guide who was with us during this time didn't inform us otherwise. Inside the temple grounds, salespeople are scattered everywhere selling postcards, mirror photos, drinks, and snacks�often with inflated prices where you are expected to bargain. Unfortunately, you end up spending more time navigating these distractions than actually taking in the spiritual beauty and significance of the temple itself.

Besakih is undeniably an important and sacred temple, but as a tourist, the constant commercialization makes it hard to enjoy. I would suggest visiting other temples in Bali if you want a more genuine and serene experience.

Bali itself was beautiful, but this temple experience completely ruined it for me. What should have been a cultural visit turned into a constant scheme to squeeze money out of the tourists. I can�t believe so many people inside are using the temple to plot scam the tourists

1. The Photographer Scam
-Within one minute of meeting our tour guide, a �photographer� pressured us into taking pictures
-Price agreed at 50K, but he demanded 100K because he lured us pose on two staircases. Not to mention the photos he took was awful
-Felt deceived and manipulated from the very beginning

2. The Tour Guide
-Barely explained anything about the temple itself
-Spent most of the time chatting with random people around the temple
-His English was hard to understand, but he had no issues talking about money
-Bring us to get cash out with a credit card so that we get cash with us

3. Manipulative behaviour
-The tour guide pretended to be too tired to continue the climb when my partner wanted to see more - he kneel down out of the blue in the middle of the tour after we got cash. Looking back, it feels like he was trying to cut the tour short deliberately
-While I had some cash in my hand, a woman literally put her kid (like 3-5 years old) in front of me while saying �money�, �money�, absolutely disgusting behaviour

4. Family Shop Pressure
-At the end, he took us to a shop near the exit runs by his family
-Clear attempt to make us spend more money before leaving, also wasted our time
-In the end, they ended up sold my partner a vest and a trousers (those with elephant prints on it) that the size don�t even fit him for 950K (�45), they didn�t tell him the price until they handed him the card machine.

The entire visit felt like one big setup. What a waste of time. We were constantly manipulated into paying for things. It left such a negative impression that it overshadowed the beauty of Bali

The biggest temple in Bali... Don't go!!! Everybody in this temple is begging for more money. The entrance fee for the temple complex is double compared to other temples on the island. The ticket includes a guide, but the guides only pay attention to you and guide you trough the temple only if you pay them extra, even though they are paid already (they receive a salary from the temple). Our guide asked for money several times during the tour. The moment we told him that the guided tour was already paid for with the ticket, the guide ran ahead and stopped paying attention to us. Of the complex of 20 temples, you have access to only one of them, and then again only after buying flowers - a "donation" that buys you access to enter it. Once you enter, you will again be "asked" for a new donation for the temple itself. All along the way, you are pulled by different people to take a fake Instagram "mirror" photo of you with gates and a reflection in a lake, there is no lake at all at the temple. In general, the purpose of the guides is not to show you around and introduce you to Balinese culture and the history of the temple, but to beg more money from you for various photos, donations, etc. In the end, you pay a significant amount of money for local standards, and get a terrible experience. The Balinese are extremely kind and welcoming people, Besakih Temple is an absolute tourist scam. Ulun Danu, Tanah Lot, the Water Temple in Ubud are examples of wonderful Balinese temples. There are a lot of amazing temples in Bali, skip this one. Very poor experience.

Even though the Besakih temple is one of the most sacred and majestic places in Bali, it is also one of the biggest tourist traps. The entrance fee is 150 000 IDR for foreigners. rame banget, jadi sembahyangnya harus antre & sabar ya, tapi dagangnya banyak kok jadi kalo haus ato laper bisa beli, di tempat ngantre sembahyang juga ada dagang, pura besakih pura paling besar di bali, jadi umat hindu wajibb pokoknya kesini

Very nice temple but felt much more like a money grabbing entertainment park then a spiritual place.
The entrance price is considerable (150k per person, parking excluded) but ok considering this is the most important temple in Bali. Unfortunately soon after entering we got pushed (not in a friendly way) into buying offerings at 50k each which they said were mandatory (and we later found out it wasn't).
All temples inside were closed when we visited so we missed a good part of it.
The complex contains many different temples but unfortunately there were far more "souvenir" and improvised shops then things to see, with people constantly asking if you are interested to buy something.
We also weren't super happy about having a guide with us at all times, but apparently it's the only way.
The price for the guide is included in the ticket, but you will be of course asked to leave a tip at the end of the trip.
All in all it's a nice place (hence the 3 stars), but all of the money-grabbing ruined our experience and left a sour taste in our mouths.
We really hope this review can help warn other tourists and improve how things will develop in the future.

We are very disappointed about visiting this temple. It should be the a very nice temple to visit as it is the most important temple in Bali, but we really didn�t like the experience due to all the money grabbing and the fact that is was mostly under construction.

Our driver already warned us for not having to buy the offering, but we visited the temple on a ceremonie day and they just let us believe that we had to buy it this day (100k for two offerings). Also after doing the ceremonie, the guide told us we had to leave them a tip for their help by the ceremonie and after a sort of rushing through the tour, the guide asked for a tip for his service, told us we at least should do 70k and he said us goodby at the top because he was going home. He actually wasn�t going home, he took the car down to the entrance, we had to walk down and when we came down, we saw him guiding some new guests.

We really didn�t feel comfortable in this situation and the entire �money grabbing situation� destroyed our experience.

Pure tourist scam. Everything is just a made up spectacle. Tickets are expensive, no maintainence on site at all, trash is all around. Guide "guided us" for 5 minutes and was insisting on tips. Don't buy the blessings, you can get them on the top temple if you come to pray and then the "priest" will insist on donation again.

Het is een gigantisch groot complex met mooie tempels maar alles draait hier om toeristen en geld verdienen. Dat doet af aan juist de rust en mooiheid van de andere tempels in Bali. Ik zou hier niet nog eens heen gaan.

Place has good accessibility by main road and despite my decision to try super remote rural route, had no trouble getting here and there is good parking too.

They have trained kids with standard scripts to sell postcards at premium rates and they do harass you if you respond politely. Buy it and move on. Or not!

If you only wish to visit, please ask for an entry ticket (I don't know if that's available as an option, some temples in Bali did). We were given a ticket that covered entry, personal guide (super useless yet asked for extra $), one way ride and a sarong.

These guides let you be scammed by local sellers who forces you to buy temple offerings, once you reach the temple area, then these guides tell that you can't offer with just sarong and have to buy/rent Balinese traditional dress.

To me, a guide not being able to explain about the temple and just pointing and telling to take photos despite requesting him to educate us a thing or two about the temple and consciously letting us be misled into buying temple offerings and then telling about conditions to be met just ruined the experience.

PS: My agitation is due to the unethical practices of these guides in comparision to other temples; not from the money spent.

The temple complex is quite large and offers several beautiful sites to see. A guide will accompany you, and appropriate clothing is provided at the entrance. Some cultural areas cannot be entered, especially when ceremonies are taking place, but taking photos is allowed.

During the tour, visitors are asked if they would like to join in prayer. It is important to mention that after the prayer, a mandatory �donation� of 100,000 Rupiah per person is demanded, which puts everyone under pressure. At the end of the tour, the group is deliberately guided to nearby sales stands, the purpose of which is quite obvious.

When leaving, we were again asked for a tip of at least 50,000 Rupiah, which felt very intrusive. From the prayer ceremony onward, the overall atmosphere in the group noticeably shifted, and the experience became less enjoyable.

I don�t believe this was an isolated incident but rather a common practice among the guides here. If you are asked to take part in the prayer, I would recommend politely declining if you are not willing to give a donation. A guide is mandatory until the end of the tour, but after that, you are free to explore the local restaurants and shops on your own.

Highest temple in Bali and the mother temple. It�s quite a drive up from ubud but a beautiful one, especially if you go on the road around the rim looking down on lake Batur.
I was a bit blown away when we arrived and there is an enormous multi storey carpark and welcome centre! That was all built a few years ago.
You pay the 150K IDR tourist fee for a sarong, shuttle bus up, entry and guide. We had a great guide for our family. Spoke good English, was funny and interesting.
The temple complex is huge and the village is set amongst it. We really liked it. The temples are made from the black volcanic ash.
The views looking down over Bali are also amazing and it is built on the slopes of  mt agung which you can see behind it. We had a great view of agung just before it clouded over and the rain came.
It probably takes an hour or so to wander around the temples with the guide. There are various shops set amongst the temples selling gifts and food/drink.
You then walk the 1km back to the car park/centre past all the shops. Lots more sarong sellers.
We got soaked as it rained but it�s a nice walk down.

- La entrada cuesta 150k idr pp e incluye sarong, gu�a y transporte pero con condiciones. La mayor�a de gu�as te exigen una propia al final. El transporte es solo un viaje. [ENG] We visited the temple today. Please be careful with the guides � they encourage you to join various attractions, claiming they are included in the ticket price. However, after the activity ended, we were told we had to pay extra.

During the payment, we found it very unpleasant that the guide literally looked into our wallet and pressured us to spend more money, additionally as a �donation.� At the end of the temple tour, the guide told us his services cost 200k rupiah.

After finishing the visit, we returned to our driver (a local resident) and told him about the whole situation. Together, we went to the temple staff to clarify things and found out that indeed, everything should have been included in the ticket price. The guide simply took advantage of tourists, making easy money by presenting them with a fait accompli. We managed to get half of the costs refunded.

I warn all tourists, no matter where you are from: beware of hidden costs that the guides don�t mention. Reading other reviews, I came to the conclusion that this is a common practice among the staff.

The temple itself is worth seeing � the scenery is beautiful � but unfortunately, human greed lurks behind it, hidden under a cloak. I strongly advise caution.

Le temple de Besakih est impressionnant, consid�r� comme le plus grand temple de Bali. L�ambiance est particuli�rement agr�able en fin de journ�e, juste avant la fermeture : on peut voir les familles locales venir prier, ce qui rend la visite plus authentique .

Les visiteurs peuvent acc�der jusqu�au dernier temple tout en haut, avec une superbe vue sur les environs. Une belle exp�rience, � privil�gier en fin de journ�e plut�t qu�en plein apr�s-midi.
Nice experience and landscape. Well organised and tour guide.

For the holiest of temples in Bali, it sure is a scammy money grab.  We paid 300000 for the two of us then the clerk put on our admission braclets.  Next, she led us to the sarong area. We already understood we had to wear sarong so that was actually nice.   Then someone asked for our receipt to scan.  I didn't know they were going to scan it since we already had bracelets, so I threw it in my backpack. Now, I had to dig for it but luckily I found it all scrunched up.

A gentleman walked up to us and said he would be our tour guide. I didn't know we needed a guide and it seemed mandatory so okay.  He said a shuttle would take us to the temple and we started walking towards the shuttle.  There was a table nearby and the lady handed us two offerings for blessing in the temple. We thought that would be great. Thinking it was included since it was in the reception area, we started walking toward the shuttle.  She stopped us and said it was 200000 for both offerings.  We already had them in our hands so felt obligated to pay.

Our guide led us to the temple where other guides were doing "mirror" photos at the gate. They asked if we wanted one and we declined. They were charging the others to do it but I didn't know how much.

There's also construction going on too where the crew was doing restorative work. No biggie, but some sections were screened off.

He seemed rushed but he was providing good info. We got to a temple where he was going to set our offerings.  Sad thing was that we didn't get to go into the temple to set our offering. He just set it on one of the ledges.  Maybe that's normal? I don't  know.

At the end, I gave him a 100000 tip, and he said one more. That caught me off guard and I was going to decline but gave him another 100000.  He then said we had to walk back but he took a shuttle.  There was no one on it so I didn't know why.  As we walked back, I found out why.  To go back to the entrance, we had to walk past all the stalls trying to sell food and souvenirs.

This was a really negative experience.  I'm absolutely sure Besakih Temple is a sacred place for locals but the money grab is a wierd paradox when our guide was taking to us about karma.  This place is wholly commercialized now and in my opinion, is a tourist trap.

The experience is completely worthless because of all the people trying to rip you off. Not really what you expect at a place of worshipping. Also the guide that is included in the ticket will ask for a tip in the end, and even if you give him something he will ask for more. Very rude people.

Besakih Temple is located on the slopes of Mount Agung, Bali�s highest and most sacred volcano. The complex consists of more than 80 smaller temples. Getting here from areas like Seminyak or Kuta can take up to 3 hours by car. Since you�re already in the area, it�s definitely worth combining your visit with Tirta Gangga.

The entrance fee is IDR 150k per person, while children under 6 enter for free. Our 7-year-old daughter was not charged either. The fee includes a sarong and a guide. Personally, I don�t think a guide is necessary�we don�t enjoy having someone walk with us all the time�but they said it was mandatory. The guide mostly repeated some memorized phrases in English, not very clear, but at least he helped us with photos.

At the entrance, some people will try to sell you things, claiming it�s compulsory, but you can just say no and continue. They are not too pushy. For the famous mirror-effect photo, they charge 30k. If you don�t want to pay, you can wait in line and take it yourself�we waited about 10 minutes, which wasn�t bad.

You cannot enter inside the temples themselves; only people praying are allowed. At the end, you can leave a tip for the guide if you wish.

Overall, Besakih is a must-see in Bali and one of the most important cultural and spiritual sites on the island.

Not worth going out of your way to it. It is a beautiful complex of 20 temples but tourists are allowed in none of them. We paid 150k rupia per person to see it. This supposed to cover the entrance, a sarong and a guide. The sarong is like any other temple we have been in, the guide was the worse bit. First of all, we got there and seemed nice enough. We had to wear a sarong as usual, after we were given a guide. Tourist Scam
1. Expensive 150K ticket (for foreign adult) which includes sarong, shuttle bus, and compulsory local tour guide
2. ?Shuttle bus only covers a mild 700 metres uphill and still need to climb upstairs after arrival of the entrance
3. ?Local tour guide is only available in English and the tour guide is not fluent in English. Minimal information provided only.

6. ?Only the peripheries can be visited; the central part is forbidden (except praying), the walk can be completed in 30 minutes even if you walk slowly
7. The temple is not well maintained and the temple dogs are not taken care of with skin diseases and skinniess
8. ?When you walk along the path children will try to sell you postcards and will scold you if you refuse
9. ?The biggest scam I suffered from is the �photography package� in front of the big Candi Bentar. Our team initially agreed for only 1 set of picture with 30K. Beberapa waktu lalu, saya akhirnya berkesempatan mengunjungi Pura Agung Besakih, pura terbesar dan paling suci di Bali. Letaknya di lereng Gunung Agung benar-benar menghadirkan suasana yang sejuk dan tenang. Begitu sampai, saya langsung merasakan aura sakralnya � sangat berbeda dengan tempat wisata biasa. Kompleks puranya luas, terdiri dari banyak bangunan dan pelataran bertingkat yang menghadap langsung ke gunung. Pemandangannya luar biasa indah, apalagi saat kabut tipis menyelimuti area pura, terasa sangat spiritual dan damai.

Saat masuk, kami diminta mengenakan kain dan selendang sebagai bentuk penghormatan. Suasana di dalam sangat tertib, para pengunjung juga terlihat saling menghormati. Saya sempat melihat persiapan upacara oleh warga lokal, dan itu membuat pengalaman jadi makin berkesan. Secara keseluruhan, Pura Besakih bukan hanya tempat ibadah, tapi juga cerminan budaya dan spiritualitas Bali yang begitu kuat. Wajib banget dikunjungi kalau kamu ingin melihat sisi Bali yang lebih dalam dan bermakna.

No puedes entrar a ver ning�n templo excepto el que queda m�s arriba, y para entrar, tienes que hacer una ofrenda (50.000 rupias x person) m�s una donaci�n obligatoria de 100.000 rupias por persona en el interior del templo superior (si no no te dejan entrar). They don't let you wander around alone. They force you to get a tour guide, but when you don't, they give you the wrong direction. Everything is tied to money. Coming here from a hospitable place like Ubud was a disappointment. Be careful and don't follow anyone.

Pros:
+ beautiful and interesting architecture
+ if you're like me, who is just kind of looking for the cultural experience to check off, and you have your own bike, would be worth it when the weather is clear.
+ employees near booth are very kind and helpful

Cons:
- high price 150k and guide who will demand tips and when you refuse, will leave you to do the tour alone although you paid for it. I asked for his name and his demeanor changed but I asked him to leave so I can go at my own pace because it made me feel uncomfortable.

-smell of the incense burning was giving me headache. If you're sensitive, wouldn't recommend it.

- ladies will immediately hassel you but dont buy anything because you dont have to.

-tourists can't enter anything, but can look in from the sidewalks

- finding gojek / grab from Mt Batur was difficult. Had to pay 100k to get to the temple because only cars accepted request.

-Getting a ride to Ubud was hard as well, and it would've been 400k. So I booked a ride to Klungkung City Park (~100k) and then to Ubud (~50k) since it's cheaper that way. It would've been cheaper and less of a hassel if I booked a tour... haha. Don't make the same backpacker mistake as me.

Pura umat Hindu terbesar di Bali, kalau mau kesini cek kesehatan kendaraan yang kalian pakai ya, soalnya Trek yang terjal naik terus kemudian belokan yang tajam, perlu ekstra hati-hati, tapi begitu sampai ditempat Rasa Lelah itu terbayarkan dengan pemandangan Dan udara yang sejuk, bangunan pure yang megah. Masuk kesini bayar tiket 80.000 untuk penduduk lokal, sudah termasuk biaya pemandu lokal, sewa sarung, dan naik shuttle untuk pergi ke Pura diatas ketinggian 1000 m mdpl. Recommended banget!!!

Beautiful place.
The entrance fee was IDR 150,000 which includes the sarong.
The temple offering was IDR 50k but it is optional and you don't have to buy it if you don't want to.
You then make a prayer at the temple and you will be asked to make a donation. The amount is up to you.
And when finished the guide will ask you for tips. I gave IDR 100k as I only had 20k in small notes . Even that he wanted more and asked if I had USD.
Best to prepare the tip in advance. In my opinion  IDR 50k is sufficient.

Beautiful temple. Unfortunately our guide was truly abysmal. We only learned around 2 or 3 facts, despite specifically asking him to focus on the temple's history and architecture (instead of my girlfriend's complexion and geopolitics, which he had mostly done up until that point).

Really disappointing - I would recommend avoiding, especially for British (and I would guess, European) tourists. I had worn full length trousers and a pashmina out of respect for the culture and holiness of the place; this is ironic, given respect was just about the last thing shown to my husband and I by all of the "workers" there.

From the moment you arrive, the temple appears as a cash grab, and not the sacred place which is is supposed to be. Tickets are expensive, and then you are ferried between various people, all of whom ask "where are you from?". At first I thought this was just out of curiosity, but it became very clear that this was so they could judge how much money they thought they could milk out of us. We were assigned a guide, which seemed absolutely mandatory (I've since read on other reviews that this isn't the case). We were then ferried over to women who forcefully wrapped us in cheap blue sarongs. But hey, we thought, maybe this is a nice cultural way in which we can show respect, so we went along with it. Quite the contrary: as we progressed, the big blue sarongs felt like a huge beacon shrieking "European tourists - milk them all you can!".

The women then forced offerings into our hands, staying that we needed them to enter. Then they said "50,000". We declined and stated we had no cash. After some argument they said we must go and get cash from one of the shops in the temple complex (yes, you read that right - there are shops littered throughout this holy place - how... Commercial?), and pay them on our return.

Immediately upon entering and waiting for the shuttle bus, we were approached by a child trying to sell us photos for "school" (once again, we gleeful eyes upon hearing we were British). Goodness knows what she needs school for when she will make her future living scamming foreigners at holy sights, but I digress. Needless to say, we didn't purchase them.

As our guide showed us up steps that we could've easily ascended of our own accord, and reeled information that we could've found on Wikipedia, he proceeded to divulge about his job as a farmer, his wife and children, and the accident that had left him toothless. Read: he tried to play the sympathy card for a large tip.

After being approached by another child trying to make her way in the world selling useless photographs, and an elderly woman with a never seen before persistence in selling peanuts, we were lead into a temple. "WHAT?", I hear you cry, "I thought non Hindus couldn't enter the temples? And especially not women on their periods?!". Well my friend, it turns out there's a very special temple where foreigners and any sort of infidel can enter, as long as they've paid extortionate amounts for their offerings and are then willing to shell out the equivalent of several weeks Balinese wages in "donations". Thankfully, I questioned whether the blessing was free when we entered. At the mention of donations, I said we didn't want a blessing, as we weren't Hindu - why would we? We were immediately hurried out of the temple, our offerings snatched from us, and told by our guide that he would "pray for us". Again, ironic, since we are not the ones scamming foreigners for cash. Soon after this awkward encounter, we were led back down. Our guide asked outright for a tip, while telling us that he only receives five percent of the ticket price (and again about his wife and kids and poor toothless mouth). We obviously declined. On our way down, we were harassed again for donations to use the toilet, and then the women from earlier who had forced the offerings on us harangued us for cash. We had a slight argument as they started asking for 100,000, and eventually they left when we gave them 60,000.

Honestly, this whole experience left such a sour taste in our mouths. There was not a single religious thing about it, it was simply a chance to milk foreigners for every bit of money they have. Such an unpleasant visit, and I highly advise you to avoid - it's just not worth it.
Lots of stairs and walking, but worth it, especially if your religious

Beautiful large temple complex with shrine for different hindu gods. The temple is very well maintained and has shuttle facilities to go from parking. Huge steps to access and photographers are available at 30,000 IDR for beautiful shots.
Highly recommended to visit and if you wear the bali traditional dress, you can go inside and perform pooja to gods.

We went dressed with the traditional Bali clothing and in theory they let us go to the top of the temple because of that to do the purification ritual, but the thing is I saw women with very inappropriate clothing at the top too and without a guide, but to us they said it was compulsory to have one.

After the ritual, He made us offer 100k each to the gods. We did and I would have done it even though, but I don�t like when they ask me for money so directly. The purification itself was the second we had on that day. The leader of the temple had a really strong aura, it was incredible to be blessed by him.

We�ve been told the guides in the the temple are already paid but everyone is following you and making up stuff to get your money. Unfortunately money goes above spirituality and that ruins the experience a lot.

Very nice temple

Kind of ironic how a sacred site is surrounded by so much scamming and exploitation.

I went there during one of their major holidays (Galungan), which I actually recommend you experience too. While the temple was beautiful and gave a glimpse into Hindu culture, it was the scammers that left the lasting impression.

The guide (1st photo � the one with sleeve tattoos) included in the ticket brought me to rent a Balinese outfit from someone he knew � it cost more than twice the price the staff at the registration counter had advised. The shop was about half a mile uphill from the registration area, right beside the main temple entrance. I refused to fall for the scheme, ditched my guide, and walked all the way back so the registration staff could assist me with the actual shop they were referring to.

The Balinese outfit was required to access deeper into the temple grounds. Not sure if that�s the case year-round or just during major ceremonies like Galungan.

And at the booth where sarongs are free to borrow, a bunch of women swarmed me trying to sell offerings, saying they were required to enter � they�re not! Not if you�re just looking around. They�re only needed if you plan to join the prayers inside the inner area with the Hindus.

And did I mention they first offered the tiny offering set for 200k?? When I came back after ditching my scammy guide, they dropped it to 50k � clearly desperate to make a sale.

They said dogs there are sacred then our driver drove over a dog that was laying on the street, You�re not allowed to go inside the small temples because you�re not Hindu what our tour guide that we didn�t even ask for said, he was asking for money at the end of the paid tour and transport only up, you have to walk down to check out the stores!!! Overpriced and too overrated, never again

Please don�t be a western sucker. This temple will take you for all you have. We saw it everywhere around us. Here are some tips.

- The registration desk will pressure you for money. Feel free to give zero. That�s perfectly acceptable. You are already paying the highest temple ticket price in the country. The locals give zero.
- No need to buy an offering.
- if someone takes you somewhere to pray they are going to ask you for money
- the ticket comes with a guide but we declined one at the registration desk as they have a strong reputation for demanding money. There were some guides taking great pictures so you choose.
- ticket comes with a sarong
- ticket comes with a trolley up the mountain. If you want to take it down it costs 20k because they want to make you walk past all the vendor stalls. This is common practice at Indonesian temples.
- we were there on a rainy day so we rented umbrellas for 10k each (60 cents American) at the base area
- bring toilet paper and hand sanitizer.
- A firm �no thank you� goes a long way. We literally saw people going to the ATM to get out more money to pay off all the scammers. Don�t be that guy. The more you get taken for a ride the more people come to pressure tourists for money and ruin the experience.
- don�t be surprised if you get called a name or a liar or a bad man when you say no. This is all in the scammer playbook and they�re preying on your soft feelings and social pressure. We happily said no and they stopped asking. The people who started giving were harassed by everyone.

Otherwise the temples were beautiful. Enjoy! We had a wonderful peaceful time.

Perched on the slopes of Mount Agung, Bali�s highest volcano, Besakih Temple isn�t just another pretty temple � it�s the grandest, most significant, and most spiritually profound temple complex on the island.
Often referred to as the �Mother Temple of Bali,� Besakih Temple (Pura Besakih) has been standing tall for over a thousand years. It has survived the harsh climate, volcanic eruptions, colonial rule, and probably more tourist photos that it would care to admit.

Tourist trap.

The temple is one of the oldest in Bali but I did not find it to be impressive for several reasons.

The ticket is too expensive at 160k idr.
Ticket costs the same for kids too. In total, this was almost the same price I paid for my taxi for the whole day.

The ticket price includes a guide who I found useful for photos but not as much for the history.
The ticket price includes a one way ev car transport up that mountain to the shrines but not the way back. This seems to be by design to force visitors to visit the souvenir shops on the way down.

SORRY TO SAY BUT ITS THE WORST UPGRADE THAT EVER BEEN FOR A TEMPLE IN BALI! Entry ticket naik jadi 80K/Orang for Lokal dan katanya sudah INCLUDE SARUNG, DAN GUIDE! kami fikir oke itu harga yang wajar karna upgrade ini, semua berjalan lancar dan kami senang pada awalnya! karna guide menjelaskan dan juga bantu untuk foto fotoin kita yang kita pikir memang sudah seharusnya karna mreka di awal bilang INCLUDE! sampai kami sampai di Pura paling tinggi nya untuk ikut berdoa... DULU sebelum ada fasilitas guide guide ini kami hanya di minta uang donasi setelah sembahyang SE IKLASNYA! dan dimasukan ke dalam KOTAK DONASI. tapi kali ini tiba tiba diminta untuk TARUH uang diatas sajen yg dipakai sembahyang tadi, guide awalnya bilang SEIKHLASNYA! Lalu saya minta istri saya 20rb an buat kami berdua, LALU APA? Guide membisikan ke telinga saya, ini untuk biaya perawatan pura dll baiknya taruh aja 200 RIBU?! SEJAK KAPAN DONASI TEMPAT IBADAH DI PATOK HARGA? Kami GEREJA pun tidak ada yg pernah mematok harga persembahan dan setau saya di MUSLIM pun jika Sholat Jumat/Ibadah lainnya pun TIDAK DIPATOK NOMINAL DAN SELALU ADA TEMPAT UANG KHUSUS YANG TIDAK TERLIHAT ORANG. Perasaan saya udah ga bener disini, saya coba buat buang perasaan itu dan mengikhlaskan uang donasi tsb toh kita niatnya donasi kok biar saja karma yg menjadi timbal balik. lalu perjalanan kami di Pura pun selesai kami turun menuju gerbang keluar dipandu guide sambil berbincang� lagi. sampai pada akhir perjalanan kami inisiatif memberikan TIP kepada guide kami, kami beri dia 100rb TAPI bukannya mendapat ucapan TERIMA KASIH yang saya dapat malah KALAU BISA 200RIBU PAK sambil dengan nada yg meremehkan, karna saya juga sudah terlanjur kesal, dan ingin cepat beres karna sudah gerimis kami turuti apa yg dia minta walau sedikit ngedumel. dari pintu keluar ke gerbang parkir itu jalan cukup jauh karna kita bawa 2 anak Balita kami nanya tadi katanya bisa ikut shuttle lagi untuk turun? dan guide ini bilang oh GABISA padahal kami bawa anak kecil dan posisi gerimis, kami yang sudah kesal langsung jalan kebawah dann ada shuttle lewat dari arah belakang dengan muatan 1 orang DAN ITU ADALAH GUIDE KAMI! Jujur itu emosi saya sudah sangat memuncak, apa gabisa bantu bilang karna posisi gerimis dan kita juga lumayan cape abis naik pura yang tangganya banyak sambil gendong anak karna stroller susah bawanya jadi kami titip di bawah. Overall pura ini LAYAK di kunjungi itu DULU saat masih pure dan tidak ada embel embel sperti sekarang. oknum seperti ini yang membuat wisata Bali menjadi sepi dan sangat membuat orang kecewa. kami lebih baik membayar lebih tetapi transparan di awal bukan yang secara tiba tiba di tembak kasih segini segitu di akhir. Jelas kami rasa ini SCAM yang ter organisir. dan tidak habis pikir mreka menjadikan tempat yang SUCI untuk DIJUAL secara TIDAK PANTAS!.

Wonderful experience. We visited the Mother Temple accompanied by a guide that showed us lots of spots and gave us lots of info about the place and it's history. We arrived in early morning and we were the only tourists around, we had the entire place for ourselves.

We enjoyed our visit as it was good to look around. Our guide didn't really tell us much more than we had already read and we would have preferred to look around ourselves but we were told we had to have a guide, who was with us for around 40 minutes.

The sarong I was made to wear was tied too long, near my ankles and  as it was windy and rainy. I nearly tripped on the steps, so make sure it is not left too long when they tie it.

At the end, we tipped 100000 from the two of us and he asked us if we had enjoyed ourselves. We said yes, so he said, "well if you enjoyed it, you can tip more" - really greedy and outrageous!

We had a private driver for the day, who drove us for 9 hours and we only tipped him 100000 for the whole day. That's why I thought the tip for the guide was already way too high, so when he asked for more, it really took the shine off the visit.
You will be asked to pay literally for anything

From the moment we entered it was a bad feeling of money grabbing, from school children asking for money to women selling �offerings�  at &100,000 k each. Guide told us all included no extra charges. It is  such a big place so I think a guide is good but when he asked for a tip at the end, which I had in my hand and was already going to do, I handed him $100,000 but he asked for more? My partner was angry and walked away so as not to be confrontational. All I had left in my purse was small notes so I just handed to him and left. Very bad experience all round. Takes away from the actual experience. Can�t even get good photos as it�s so crowded with locals selling everything on every single corner and so in your face, tourists with guides not sure it was worth a visit.

Beautiful,big and modern hindu temple complex built on the ancient historic site of puram or village on the hilltop seen through the horns of cow or entrance gate called as gopuram.Dedicated to shiva,vishnu and Brahma complex is very big like township having colorful sanctum towers surrounded by open courtyard or corridors flanked by impressive entrance gates with excellent designs and carvings.Architectures are similar to 14th century Nha Trang or po nagar hindu temples of vietnam having unique style of stucco images or stone carvings supported by imaginary guardians and scary astadikpalas built on high stairs symbolically reflecting Kailasha or meru mountain depending on diety makes it nice place to visit the same. The chariot style towers,huge and irrelevant lamp designs,expressions of several guardians is noteworthy.

I can�t believe people behave this way at a TEMPLE!!! A holy, sacred place!

The guide that is assigned with your ticket was so RUDE! They also forced me to buy an offering at the front and told me I �NEED IT�! I found out later from others that you don�t need it. Also, why are you smoking in temples? Women can�t go when menstruating due to impurity, what is pure about smoking???

I would never be back or recommend it to anyone. Hopefully there are better temples in Indonesia that actually honour the sacredness of holy places.

Lungo tragitto per raggiungere questo Tempio dove all' ingresso vi verr� chiesto di pagare il ticket e vi verr� associata una guida locale obbligatoria , il che fa si che voi non possiate essere liberi di girare e visitare in autonomia il tempio stesso. Per alcuni pu� essere una cosa positiva per altri vincolante nelle tempistiche di visita.

Nascosto tra le pendici fertili del Monte Agung, il vulcano sacro di Bali, il Tempio Madre di Besakih non � solo un monumento architettonico: � il cuore pulsante della spiritualit� balinese, un luogo dove mito, fede e natura convivono in perfetta armonia.
Conosciuto come il �Pura Besakih�, questo complesso non � un singolo tempio, ma un�intera citt� sacra composta da pi� di 80 santuari, distribuiti su terrazze e scalinate che sembrano rincorrere il cielo.
 Un Luogo Sacro da Vivere
�	Spiritualit� autentica: Besakih � il tempio pi� importante dell�isola, dedicato alla trinit� induista balinese: Brahma, Vishnu e Shiva. Ogni visita � un�immersione profonda nella religione e nella cultura dell�isola.
�	Architettura straordinaria: Con i suoi meru (torri a pagoda), cortili aperti e sculture in pietra vulcanica, il tempio si fonde perfettamente con la natura che lo circonda.
�	Atmosfera solenne: Il silenzio, interrotto solo dal suono dei gamelan in lontananza e dal fruscio del vento tra gli alberi, dona al luogo un senso di pace profonda.

Anche se meno �instagrammabile� rispetto ad altri templi come Lempuyang o Tanah Lot, Besakih regala qualcosa di pi� profondo: un senso di connessione con l�antico spirito dell�isola. � il tipo di luogo che non solo si vede, ma si sente.

 Conclusione
Visitare il Tempio Madre di Besakih � un�esperienza che va oltre il turismo. � un incontro con la Bali pi� autentica, un luogo dove il tempo sembra sospeso e la spiritualit� si respira in ogni gradino. Che tu sia in cerca di bellezza, cultura o raccoglimento, qui troverai una Bali diversa, pi� profonda. E, forse, anche una parte di te che stavi cercando.

Beware! Once we paid the 150k entrance price (which includes a local guide and a sarong), we were asked to buy an offering for 30k each, which seemed reasonable to us. The offering will get you access to the upper most temple to make prayer, give the offering and take a blessing, but beware, the guide will more or less demand a donation to the temple of minimim 200k each. review_text: Nice temple set atop a hill would recommend.

Major let-down is the bunch of woman, who try to scam you into having to buy some offerings for 100k/person. They tell you that you HAVE to buy these but when you say you'll check with the main reception, they say you can go without... 
Also you have to come up with a reason to visit the temple without a guide.
Just increase the entry fee, include an offering and a guide and everything's fine but having an entry fee of 150k and trying to trick you into HAVING to buy something else for 100k feels not worthy for a 'mother temple'

Disappointing Experience � Too Commercialised

I�ve just visited the temple and feel compelled to leave a review. While the temple itself is visually impressive, the overall experience was disappointing and felt overly focused on money rather than spiritual or cultural value.

From the moment I arrived at the ticket office, it was clear this was more of a business than a sacred site. The entrance fee is 150,000 IDR � quite steep for what�s on offer. You�re strongly encouraged to take a guide, even though one really isn�t necessary. Once the tour begins, the guide shifts focus from the temple to sharing personal stories that seem aimed at prompting tips rather than enhancing the visit.

On the way back down, the warmth and hospitality vanish � it�s clear they�re no longer interested once you�ve paid. I�ve been coming to Bali for over 12 years, and I was genuinely shocked at how commercialised this particular temple visit felt. The magic and authenticity are fading fast under the pressure of marketing and profit.

In my opinion, it�s not worth the journey. There are many other temples in Bali where you can still feel a sense of sacredness and connection without being treated like a wallet on legs.

Biasanya ramai di pintu masuk sampai bikin jalan macet, sekarang antriannya sudah lebih teratur. Disini juga banyak tamu asing yg datang berkunjung. Suasananya sejuk, parkirnya sekarang lebih luas.

Agak sedih memberi ulasan seperti ini kepada pura yang kami hormati, tapi memang layak diberikan ke pengelola disana. Kalau memang sedang ada upacara lebih baik ditutup saja sementara. Saya tadi pagi bawa tamu kesini, kemudian membeli tiket 150/orang sudah include guide dan suthle harusnya. Lalu diarahkan kalau tidak bisa suthle dibawah 55 tahun oke tidak apa apa karna karna ada upacara. Kemudian saya diam di parkir tapi ketika datang tamu saya dengan wajah yang merah dia bilang diarahkan untuk sembahyangg kemudian setelah sembahyang disuruh untuk bayar 200k per orang oleh guide disana dimana 2 orang 400k menurut penuturan tamunya Ini betul2 sebuah penipuan. Kalau memang harus bayar sebesar itu alangkah lebih baiknya diarahkan dahulu kalau mau sembahyang akan ada tahapan tahapan seperti beli canang donasi dan lain sebagainya sehingga tidak akan menimbulkan kekcewaan selanjutnya sehingga semua orang merasa bahagia ketika kepura. Seakan akan pura dijadikan ladanv bisnis. Lebih parahnya lagi saya yang tidak tahu apa apa ikut terkena imbas dikarenakan saya dikira tau akan penipuan dan turis trap ini. Tour kami menjadi berantakan semua yang sudah terjadwal dan diatur sedemikian rupa hancur karena ulah satu orang guide disana. Ini adalah tempat suci alangkah baiknya tetap dijadikan tempat suci bukan untuk bisnis, terlebih lagi ini sangat melenceng dari apa yang menjadi citra kita sebagai orang ramah, baik dan murah hati. Semua ini hancur karna ulah satu orang. Mohon maaf jika saya salah alangkah baiknya benahi diri dan Bali agar semakin baik dan semua merasa bahagia setelah mengunjungi ataupun sembahyang dipura ini terima kasih

Common Info � Location of Besakih Temple:

Besakih Temple, also known as Pura Agung Besakih, is located on the southwestern slopes of Mount Agung in Karangasem Regency, Bali, Indonesia. It�s about 1,000 meters above sea level and is considered the largest and holiest temple complex in Bali, often referred to as the �Mother Temple� of the island. The temple complex comprises over 80 temples, with Pura Penataran Agung being the main and most important one.

5 Unique Historical Facts about Besakih Temple:
1.	Ancient Origins (Pre-Hindu Era):
The site of Besakih Temple is believed to have been a sacred place since prehistoric times, even before Hinduism arrived in Bali. It was once a worship site for local animistic beliefs.
2.	Built in the 8th Century:
The first temple structure was believed to be founded by a Hindu sage named Rsi Markandeya in the 8th century, who planted the first foundations and a holy pot (Pancadatu) as a spiritual center.
3.	Survived Mount Agung Eruption (1963):
In 1963, the eruption of Mount Agung killed over 1,000 people, but lava flows miraculously missed the temple, stopping just meters away. This was seen as a spiritual sign of divine protection.
4.	Symbol of Tri Hita Karana:
The layout of the temple complex reflects the Balinese philosophy of Tri Hita Karana�the three causes of well-being: harmony with God, people, and nature.
5.	Center of Hindu Rituals Across Dynasties:
Besakih has been a royal temple for centuries, where kings and nobles from different Balinese dynasties conducted ceremonies, solidifying it as both a spiritual and political center.

5 Forbidden Rules (What NOT to Do at Besakih Temple):
1.	Do Not Enter During Menstruation:
Women who are menstruating are not allowed to enter temple grounds, as it�s considered ritually impure in Balinese Hindu beliefs.
2.	Do Not Wear Revealing Clothing:
Visitors must wear a sarong and sash, and should not wear shorts, tank tops, or clothing that shows too much skin.
3.	Do Not Climb or Step on Sacred Structures:
Many parts of the temple are holy spaces, and climbing on or touching shrines or offerings is considered disrespectful and forbidden.
4.	Do Not Use Flash Photography During Ceremonies:
Flash photography or intrusive behavior is strictly prohibited during religious rituals.
5.	Do Not Disrupt Prayers or Ceremonies:
Tourists are welcome to observe, but interrupting ceremonies, walking in front of praying devotees, or making noise is a serious offense.

Really special place to visit.
While it is a really photogenic location, it has a fascinating culture and history and that's what you should go there to experience.
Vendors were not as pushy with me as other reviewers have experienced. They did ask but respectfully backed off when I said no.
I actually did go back after and bought a few things later because I did want to support them.

A spectacular crown jewel of temples in Bali dedicated to Trimurti. 23 shrines in all, there is a nice walkway around the perimeter which allows for a distant tour of the complex. A guide in my opinion is not needed as the one we got didn't add anything great in terms of information but kept directing towards stores and art shops. Ticketing wise this is a bit of an expensive proposition even if the ride up in a buggy is included. There is no return trip offered even though the buggies are coming down empty. Quite a few tourist traps and expensive souvenir stores all along the way.

What redeems everything is the Temple premises itself and the deep heritage on display.
tempat yang luar biasa

It is an okay experience, the temple is pretty nice although I was expecting a more majestic experience considering it's the biggest Hindu temple on Bali. I was offput, though by people trying to constantly sell you something at this holy place. Upon arrival you are chased by women trying to sell you overpriced offerings, saying you won't be able to enter the temple without it. After confirming with the guide who "waited for them to do their job" and only confirmed that you should have the offering for the one praying place of the temple we bought it.
I guess we could have been informed about this when the tickets are sold for a more trustworthy experience. You need an offering and an extra donation to be able to enter the praying (top level place) of the temple where you take part in Hindu praying ritual.

Also, the guides were directly asking for extra tips, something we have not observed elsewhere.

We came early at 9am to avoid crowds, which turned out to be good.
