Ini yg kesekian kali saya bawa tamu ke Pura Besakih. Sungguh2 malu rasanya sebagai driver. Tamu saya 2 orang asli Jakarta tiba2 turun komplain " KITA DI TIPU BLI"
Semenjak renovasi besar2an area Pura Besakih harapanya semua akan jauh lebih baik dari sebelum2nya.
Parkir,penataa areal pura yg rapi, tiket yg sudah sesuai besaran nominal. Pun dengan semua fasilitas yg di dapat pengunjung.
Berapa banyak biaya yg di keluarkan oleh pemerintah untuk membuat kawasan Pura Besakih semakin indah dan tentunya nyaman jika di kunjungi.
Tentunya akan berdampak baik bagi masyarakat sekitar dan perputaran ekonomi juga akan semakin bagus dengan kedatangan turis2.
Namun apa daya karena kerakusan manusia2 saya sebut manusia karena makluk ini layaknya kita bisa berbicara mendengar dan punya pikiran. Manusia ini bekerja sebagai guide atau pemandu yg merupakan kewajiban kita untuk memakai jasa mereka jika berkunjung ke Pura Besakih. Guide yg seharusnya menjadi tuan rumah bagi tamu2nya malah memainkan peran sebagai tokoh yg antagonis.
Mulai dari menyarankan membeli canang seharga 150rb, dimana pedagang canang ini juga menawarkan dengan memaksa. Guide juga menawarkan tamu untuk menyewa pakaian adat Bali seharga 200rb perorang. Manusia  ini sepertinya urat malunya sudah hilang berbagai peran yg memalukan sebagai tuan rumah dan tak memiliki rasa bahwa perbuatan mereka bisa saja menodai keagungan Pura Besakih.
Pura yg sejatinya kita sucikan kita agungkan sebagai sama2 masyrakat hindu Bali.
Apakah hal ini akan berlangsung terus menerus. Apakah tidak ada aturan tegas untuk tidak menggunakan manusia2 seperti ini sebagai guide, dalam bahasa kerenya OKNUM.

Saya kira dari sekian banyaknya guide di Pura Besakih pasti ada guide yg bener2 baik dan bekerja sepenuh hati.  Masalah tamu nanti memberi tips adalah sebuah rejeki yg kita tidak tau.
Note akhirnya semua uang yg sudah di bayarkan oleh tamu saya kepada manusia2 penipu di areal pura di kembalikan setelah tamu komplain dan guide yg menghandel tamu saya meminta maaf. Manusia ini setelah minta maaf masalah akan selesai...??
Sampai2 bilang jangan melapor ke bawah nanti takut kehilangan pekerjaannya sebagai guide. Dimanakah rasa malu anda sebagai seorang manusia..??
Akhirnya ada 2 guide yg mencoba merayu tamu saya untuk naik lagi dengan semua jaminan dan penjelasan dari guide tersebut dan setelah saya meyakinkan bahwa hal yg tadi tidak terjadi lagi, tamu sudah sangat2 kecewa.
Apa yg anda rasakan sebaga warga Bali asli, atas kejadian ini.
Memalukan bukan....!!!
Sungguh2 memalukan sampai saya kehabisan kata2 menjelaskan panjang lebar ke tamu untuk meyakinkan tamu tidak berpikiran negatif terhadap objek2 wisata yg lain di Pulau Bali.
Dari beribu2 tamu yg mungkin pernah berkunjung ke Pure Besakih saya harap tidak memiliki pengalaman seperti ini.

Bagi saya tempat ini adalah tempat yg agung suci dan sangat2 indah. tapi tidak akan saya rekomendasikan untuk mengunjunginya jika anda berlibur ke Bali.
Jika pun anda berkunjung sebaiknya banyak2 baca reviue dan pengalaman2 yg mungkin kurang baik di hati. Untuk memastikan pada saat pembelian tiket yakinkan guide bahwa tidak ada biaya2 lain selain pembayaran tiket, juga foto identitas guide atau name tag yg pasti mereka bawa.
Semua ulasan ini saya tuliskan berdasarkan dari pengalaman tamu yg saya bawa.
Semoga hal2 seperti ini tidak terjadi lagi kepada tamu2 lain dan tetap berhati2 di manapun kita berada.

The oldest temple in Bali. Not only are there temples of Gods, but also many for family clans. It�s said 60 ones in total in this place.

If time is sufficient, it�s okay to come here for a visit. Ticket price has included one way shuttle bus to go to the temple site, as well as a tour guide. Prepare to tip him after his service.

Whilst this temple is a beautiful place, there are some points that you should note before you visit.

- if you want to have a nice experience, I recommend arriving EARLY (before 8am). This will allow you to be amongst the first to enter the temples and avoid the worst of the pushy salesmen and other tour groups. There are plenty of cheap and nice homestays in the area, around 1hr scooter ride from Ubud.
- tickets are 150k including a guide and sarong rental, as well as a shuttle up the hill. Staff at the entrance were friendly and helpful. You do not need to take a guide but they will ask you to write down why - many reviews on here have mentioned guides being not very knowledgeable or helpful and demanding ridiculous tips, so we declined a guide and had a good time. It can be easy to get lost without, however, and there is very little information about the area without, so considering the guide is included (and under pressure to tip, you do NOT have to) it may have been worth getting one. If you do, do remember to tip IF the experience was worth it.
- there are many people who will try to get you to buy offerings etc and convince you they are a requirement for entry - they are not. Politely decline and they will leave you alone, in my experience.
- if you want to enter inside the temple areas, you must be a practicing Balinese Hindu. However, we did see some guides bringing their guests in if they paid for offerings. Make of that what you will.

Overall, it was a nice experience to see the temples as they are unique and beautiful, and on a nice day the views up to Mount Agung and towards the south are stunning.

The location itself is beautiful, offering stunning views and a unique atmosphere. However, the experience is somewhat spoiled by the overly aggressive marketing from the locals. Many vendors try to pressure tourists into buying things they don�t need, sometimes resorting to pushy or misleading tactics. While it's worth visiting for the scenery, be prepared to navigate persistent sales pitches.
Really love this biggest temple in Bali. You can also see mount Agung here

On arrival you purchase your ticket and are assigned a private guide, then escorted to the shuttle bus.  We had to wait a few minutes for a couple more groups to fill the bus and then we were on our way.  Our guide explained to us about the history of the different temples, but also how the site is now too commercialised and there appears to be a great resentment by the locals of this change.  The various temples are spectacular to behold, but the impact of commercialisation is in conflict with the beauty and spirituality of this location.

The most holy temple for Bali Hindus. For tourists like us, with a bent of mind for architecture,  history or hindu culture of Bali, it is the place to visit. For tourists interested in spectacular mirror effect photos, the Lempuyang temple is the place. For
Fortunately for us, we took a tour and our guide Mr Dwepa was heaven sent. His flair and English pronunciation was picked up by a stint in Singapore hotels. Right from our hotel in Kuta Bali,he not only gave us a discourse on the history and culture of Bali, but also drove our SUV himself. He explained the importance of 'Vastu' directions in Bali homes, the making of bamboo demons, the Balinese names of people.
Coming to the temple, it has ample parking, (enclosed and covered) for tourists of course, on payment. Tickets include sarong on loan and a motorized shuttle from the base to the main temple which is a climb of about a km. One needs to go around the temple. Only Balinese Hindus can pray inside the main temple. For, Indian Hindus, we could go around the temple. There was one gate from where we could see the statues of Lord Brahma Vishnu and Shiva. Made a silent prayer there. Dwepa took us to an open hall where large cooured photos of their yearly celebrations were displayed. He took pains to explain why some animals are sacrificed at the temple and how it protects Bali from the bad spirits.
We decided to walk down hill rather than taking a paid two-wheeler as shuttle was not provided for return to parking. The route was dotted with shops and restaurants.
Fantasztikus!

Perjalanan kerohanian bersama dengan sekolah. Karena datang dihari biasa (bukan hari suci) jadi disini sangat sepi. Tempatnya bersih dan tertata. Ada fasilitas shuttle bus yang dapat digunakan untuk memudahkan perjalanan dari parkiran hingga kedepan pura Besakih dengan membayar 20rb. Ada pula obsi lain berupa ojek, penawaran saat itu saya dan teman teman diberikan harga 10rb/orang saat perjalanan naik dan 5rb/orang untuk perjalanan turun. Pentingnya untuk mengunakan alas kaki yang nyaman selama berkunjung karena anda akan banyak berjalan kaki di dalam area pura. Jika tersesat jangan ragu untuk bertanya.

Goa Gajah, conocido como la Cueva del Elefante, es un sitio arqueol�gico en Bali que ofrece una ventana fascinante a la rica historia espiritual de la isla. Situado cerca de Ubud, este templo es un testimonio de la coexistencia de las tradiciones hind�es y budistas en Bali, reflejando la diversidad cultural y religiosa que caracteriza a la regi�n.

Al llegar, lo primero que llama la atenci�n es la entrada de la cueva, adornada con intrincadas tallas de demonios y figuras m�sticas. La cara tallada en la roca, a menudo interpretada como un demonio o Bhoma, parece vigilar la entrada, creando una atm�sfera de misterio y reverencia. Este portal es solo el comienzo de la experiencia espiritual que ofrece Goa Gajah.

Dentro de la cueva, el ambiente es fresco y sereno. Las paredes de piedra albergan nichos donde los monjes budistas y sacerdotes hind�es practicaban la meditaci�n. Aqu�, las estatuas de Ganesha y el lingam de Shiva simbolizan la energ�a y el poder divino, invitando a los visitantes a reflexionar sobre la espiritualidad y la conexi�n con lo divino.

El complejo no se limita a la cueva. Al explorar los alrededores, se descubren ba�os de purificaci�n con estatuas que vierten agua, utilizados hist�ricamente para rituales de limpieza espiritual. Estos ba�os, rodeados de una exuberante vegetaci�n y un arroyo tranquilo, a�aden un elemento de paz y contemplaci�n al lugar.

Goa Gajah es m�s que un sitio tur�stico; es un lugar de profunda significaci�n espiritual. Su mezcla de influencias hind�es y budistas, junto con su entorno natural, lo convierten en un destino imperdible para quienes buscan comprender la rica tapeza cultural de Bali. Visitar Goa Gajah es una oportunidad para sumergirse en la historia y la espiritualidad de la isla, dejando una impresi�n duradera en el coraz�n de cada visitante.

Non farsi mancare questa tappa, la guida spiega molte cose riguardo la cultura, i templi e del perch� � cos� importante e ti aiuta a conoscere tanti aspetti di Bali che magari non notiamo (colori dei templi, giornate importanti a Bali, ecc.). Insomma, lo consiglio per farsi un po� di cultura, soprattutto! I templi sono altrettanto belli!

Do yourself a favor and read the other 1 star reviews. The beauty of this place was completely ruined by intensity of which the people are trying to get money from you�including your �local guide/extortionist� that comes with your entry ticket.

If you don�t mind being treated like you are a walking atm and can deal with the pressure to fork over money every turn of a corner then have at it.
Nice temple. Entrance, sarong and tour guide are included into the price.  You don't have to buy any offerings or anything else if you are not hindu. A lot of people were offering many things to buy.

I arrived as a solo traveller. The temple in itself is absolutely beautiful & the views are breathtaking. However I agree with everyone here, this temple is just a to pull money out of tourists.
I was assigned a tour guide & he told me that the price includes his service. However at the end, I gave him $200k and he was wanting more. I thought it was greedy.
I did buy the flower offering for 100k, it was expensive but I did enjoy the ceremony at the final temple.
Women would constantly hassle you to buy things, my tour guide did nothing to stop it & encouraged me to spend 100k on 3 pieces of fruit. I did the offering at the final temple & I made an offering of 100k & my tour guide wanted me to make a donation for him aswell so I offered 200k. You will also pay $5k to use the toilets & people will push you to take photos for $60k. The temple is absolutely exquisite but I would absolutely ignore the vendors as they only care about money & nothing else.

Kalau ada yang belom pernah datang pura besakih ini ada baiknya jangan datang, karna tempat ini akan mengubah mood anda menjadi buruk. Tempat ini penuh scam.
Biaya masuknya 160k untuk 2 orang, udah termasuk sarong, golf car (one way), serta guide. Perjalanan dari sini ke pura lumayan jauh, dengan jalan yang menanjak tapi mereka hanya menyediakan golf car one way.
Turun dari golf car saat kita berjalan ke pura banyak pedagang yang menawarkan dagangan secara memaksa. Sebelomnya guide sudah mengingatkan saya untuk tidak membeli dagangan mereka. Dan saya berpikir guide ini sangat baik, ternyata tidak, dia lah buaya sesungguhnya. Dia tidak ingin uang saya terbagi, dia hanya menginginkannya untuk dirinya sendiri.
Tidak ada apa yang menarik di pura, guide hanya mengantar kita berkeliling sambil bercerita tentang sejarah pura dan sesekali foto.
Sampai di pura utama kita di arahkan untuk berdoa, hanya duduk dengan 1 canang di depan kita, tidak lama hanya sebentar saja. Selesai berdoa, guide meminta menaruh sumbangan di atas canang. 1 orang 1 canang. Saya menaruh 50k, dan guide meminta kami menaruh 200k untuk masing masing canang .
Selesai mengitari pura, saya mengembalikan sarong ke pada guide, dan memberikan tips sebesar 50k kepada guide. Dia bukannya berterima kasih, justru tanpa melihat tips yang saya berikan dia  menetapkan harga tips 200k  berapa sih UMP di bali. Ini hanya 1 jam loh karna kita jalannya perlahan aja.
Kondisi puranya sendiri tidak bersih yah. Untuk foto lebih indah dari aslinya.
Dan untuk pulangnya ada ojek motor di sekitaran sana. Yang awalnya saya tanyakan guide tarifnya 20k, akhirnya menjadi 10k. Bahkan saat kita tawar menawar driver ojek hanya menatap guide  taulah yah.

Nestled on the misty slopes of Mount Agung, Bali�s sacred volcano, Besakih Temple�known as the �Mother Temple��is a breathtaking testament to the island�s rich culture, spirituality, and architectural brilliance. Visiting this iconic sanctuary feels like stepping into a timeless world where nature, tradition, and devotion weave together in perfect harmony. With its ancient stone structures, vibrant ceremonies, and serene ambiance, Besakih offers an unforgettable experience that lingers long after you leave.

The temple�s location alone is awe-inspiring. Perched on terraced slopes, it gazes out over lush greenery and distant peaks, with Mount Agung towering protectively in the background. The air is cool and fragrant, carrying hints of frangipani and incense that blend with the earthy scent of moss-covered stone. The architecture is a feast for the eyes�dark volcanic rock rises in multi-tiered pagodas, their intricate carvings telling stories of mythology and devotion. Golden accents gleam against the weathered stone, while the moss and lichen that cling to the structures lend an ancient, mystical charm. Each tiered tower, or *meru*, feels like an offering to the heavens, reflecting the skill and artistry of Balinese craftsmen over centuries.

The temple complex sprawls across multiple levels, connected by weathered stone steps that invite exploration. The natural surroundings�vibrant tropical plants and cascading vines�merge seamlessly with the man-made marvels, creating a sense of unity between the earth and the divine. Even on a cloudy day, the soft light filtering through the mist casts an ethereal glow over the scene, making it feel like a place untouched by time.

Besakih is far more than a static monument; it�s a living, breathing center of Balinese Hinduism. During my visit, I was captivated by the sight of locals dressed in traditional attire�crisp white shirts, colorful sarongs, and elegant *udeng* headbands�gathering for ceremonies. The air buzzed with the murmur of prayers, the chime of bells, and the rustle of offerings being carried in woven baskets. Blossoms, rice, and incense filled the space with color and scent, while priests like Mangku Jati, with his warm presence and steady guidance, led rituals that felt both sacred and welcoming.

The sense of community here is palpable. Families, pilgrims, and visitors alike come together in a shared reverence, their respect for the temple evident in every gesture. Whether it�s the sprinkling of holy water or the soft chant of mantras, each moment pulses with spiritual energy. It�s a privilege to witness such traditions, preserved and celebrated for over a thousand years, unfolding before your eyes.

What sets Besakih apart is the way it touches the soul. There�s a profound stillness here, even amid the lively ceremonies�a quiet that invites reflection and peace. Walking the grounds, I felt a deep connection to something greater, as if the mountain�s spirit flowed through the temple itself. The high priest�s blessings and the sight of devotees in prayer left me with a sense of clarity and calm that�s hard to describe. It�s a place where you don�t just see beauty�you feel it.

Besakih Temple is a must-see for anyone seeking to experience the heart of Bali. Its stunning architecture, cultural richness, and spiritual depth make it a standout destination. The climb up its steps is rewarded with panoramic views and a profound sense of wonder. Whether you�re drawn by history, faith, or simply the allure of beauty, Besakih delivers an experience that�s nothing short of magical. Five stars don�t do it justice�this is a journey that stays with you, a glimpse into the eternal spirit of Bali. Come prepared to be moved, and let Besakih�s timeless charm sweep you away.

Visiting the Mother Temple was one of the most frustrating experiences I�ve had in Bali. First, you�re charged 150k IDR just to enter, and that doesn�t even grant you proper access to the temples. Tourists are only allowed in designated areas, and if you want a more immersive experience, they will demand additional payments at every step.
The environment itself was underwhelming. The paths were unkempt, and the buildings looked like they hadn�t been maintained in years. It was disheartening to see such an important cultural site in this condition
To make matters worse, aggressive sellers swarm you from the moment you arrive. Women try to force unnecessary offerings on you, and at the highest temple, someone will guide you through a prayer ceremony�only to guilt-trip you into a "donation" afterward. I was asked for 300k IDR!
I came to the temple seeking a peaceful and spiritual experience, but all I found was a relentless push for money at every turn. This place no longer feels like a sacred site�it�s a full-blown tourist trap. If you�re in Bali looking for an authentic temple experience, I strongly suggest going elsewhere.

Instead of feeling any kind of spiritual energy, I left feeling scammed. This is no longer a sacred experience�it�s just a money-making operation that takes advantage of tourists. Unless you�re already in the area, save yourself the trouble and visit a temple where your presence is actually respected.

Besakih Temple, known as Pura Besakih, is Bali's largest and holiest Hindu temple complex, situated approximately 1,000 meters high on the southwestern slopes of Mount Agung. The complex comprises 22 temples, with Pura Penataran Agung being the central and most significant. Visitors can explore the intricate architecture and experience the spiritual atmosphere of this revered site. The entrance fee includes a sarong rental and a guide. However, some visitors have reported aggressive behavior from guides seeking additional tips. It's advisable to be prepared for this and to negotiate any extra services beforehand. Despite these challenges, the temple's historical significance and cultural richness make it a worthwhile visit.

Besakih Temple�locally known as�Pura Agung Besakih�is the largest Hindu temple complex in Bali.

That comprises at least 86 temples which include the main Pura Penataran Agung (the Great Temple of State) and 18 others.

Known as Bali's 'Mother Temple', for more than 1,000 years, has sat 1,000m up on Mount Agung�s southwestern slopes in the eastern part of Bali.

This complex of Hindu temples is the largest, holiest and most important on the island and miraculously survived the catastrophic volcanic eruption of 1963.

Surrounded by breathtaking scenery,�Besakih Temple�is nestled amid sweeping rice paddies, mountains, hills and streams.

The high set location of Mount Agung gives the temple complex a mystical quality and for the local Balinese, visiting this temple sanctuary is a truly special pilgrimage.

A huge staircase leads you up the sacred mountain to many different temples that represent all different types, functions and status.

Today, it serves as a popular destination for visitors to Bali and as a place of prayer for local Hindu people.

review_text: Sangat nyaman dan sudah dipermudah aksesnya
Great temple

The temple itself is a breathtaking sight with powerful energy.
But unfortunately, local workers have turned the temple into a market, where they try to sell you everything, and sometime in a very aggressive manner.
150 thousand rupees is the entrance fee, which includes a buggy, guide services and a sarong. Already on the way up, the guide said that I �have to� give him a tip of $ 6, despite the fact that I even refused the excursion, since I only needed to meet with Mangu Jati.
When I left the buggy, local women surrounded me and began to push offerings into my hands, saying that "you need this", I refused, but the guide confirmed that I needed it for prayer in the temple. I paid 150 thousand rupees. As it turned out, higher up I could buy the same offerings for 20 thousand rupees.
Also, when I refused to pay for a photo against the backdrop of the temple, the local photographer said: "if you don't have money, go to your country." Also donation is not donation there, but there is a minimum amount of "donation" that was announced to me. On the way back the buggy is gone, and they offered to take me to the parking lot for 100 thousand rupees. This is how things are in Bali's largest and oldest temple
Very annoying market. Dont look for enlightenment there, just business

Kind of a scam as it's way too commercialised.

The entrance fee is 150k, which they tell you includes a sarong, the drive uphill with an electric golf cart and a guide. However, the guide isn't actually included, as he's demanding quite aggressively for tips at the end. Wanted to give him 50k and he shamelessly pointed towards the 100k one. I kept asking him lots of things during the "tour" and he seemed knowledgeable, so there's that.

Once you reach the top by golf cart, multiple women swarm you and try to make you buy an offering from them, as it's "required" to visit the temple. Actually it isn't, maybe only if you plan on praying, but they're very pushy about it, while the "guide" suggests you ge the offering.

There are some "instagramable" spots where some will show you sample pictures in their phones and offer to take you similar ones, for a fee of course. Also quite pushy.
Keine Wartezeit,  aber das war morgens,  sp�ter mehr Leute angekommen,  wahrscheinlich m�ssen die warten

The Temple itself is nice and very big, as it's the most important in Bali.

Entrance fee: 150 k per person
Motorbike parking: 5 k per scooter
Guide "included with the purchase of the ticket"

We have walked all the way to the top with the guide, where the last temple is and we were asked to participate in a ceremony. We said "yes, sure". We entered the temple, did the praying, got the blessing from the priest and the magic time of the ofrend came... We firstly put around 20 k but the guide said "no no, you have to put the red one for each of you (100k note, and we were 3) and he kept looking and pointing where I had the money. In addition, the priest was waiting for us to follow the guide instructions. Very uncomfortable situation and we were never told about the amount before that moment.

They tell you that the guide is included with the ticket but they won't miss the chance to ask for more money at the end of the walk.

Anyway, be prepared for situations like this, this is my experience.

Pura Agung Besakih sangat keren, jika kalian mau ke Bali. Jadikan pura ini tujuan destinasi kalian. Karena pura ini adalah pusat seluruh pura di Bali, untuk domestik saat ini tiket masuk 80 rb, nantinya akan diberi kain untuk menutupi pinggang ke bawah, dan juga pemandu. Pemandangan sangat bagus jika saat cuaca cerah bukan saat mendung, sangat rekomendasi.

Great and beautiful place to visit but the guides are making it pathetic by telling the tourists that donation is compulsory. It's like they try to gauge how loaded the visitors are and then try to upsell right from the attire to the pooja stuff to the donation at the temple and ending with asking for a fat tip. At the entrance it's said that the entry fees includes the shuttle service and the guide but they will expect or shall I say demand for a tip.

This is the Mother Temple of Bali. Every household visits here once a year at least, and on occasion, there are massive Odalan (ceremonies) here where the entire island is here and the music and the air is full of prayer, the ringing of prayer bells and gamelan and dance.
The construction is sublime, and there are hidden temple spaces all around the larger compound.
Come make an offering of some money and become a part of the legacy of this sacred island.

I had a lot of expectations before going to the Besakih temple as it is the biggest of all the temples in Bali. However, after visiting this temple, I would say it is definitely worth visiting once but not worth the hype that it gets.

You are not allowed inside the sanctum (as is the case with most of the temples in Bali). So, you pay 150,000 IDR (roughly 10$) for moving around the temple premises along with the guide alloted to you. The entrance ticket includes: 1) the price for Sarong (a cloth mandatory for entering the temple) and you have to return it at the exit, 2) tour guide, 3) parking fee and 4) one-way  electric vehicle facility to drip you at the temple gate.

The temple complex is so huge and it reflects the 8th century Balinese architecture. There are around 23 temples in this massive complex. The temple feast is celebrated every April. You also get to see the majestic view of Mount Agung from this temple.

Nonetheless, if your tour guide speaks proper English and he is friendly, you can get to know the spiritual importance, the history of the temple, the unity of Trimurthi's (The Brahma, The Vishnu, The Shiva). Three coloured umbrellas in the picture attached represent three different forms of the God.

It takes more than 1 and half hour to visit the temple and there is no ramp/wheel-chair facility. You also have to return to the exit by foot.

We were lucky to be aligned with the full moon when we visited the sacred Mother Temple, as Balinese people pray and meditate all day during a full moon and new moon. Our guide was amazing, and it helped that we were already familiar with Hinduism, which made the experience even deeper. We got to pray and learn about how to make offerings to the Mother and Father, and how to have a heartfelt appreciation for Mother Nature. Our guide taught us how to set up the offering and how to use incense to bring in the energy.

Being at the temple on a full moon, we learned what the chants mean because they were happening in all the temples. The entire experience was so enlightening and a profoundly spiritual one. We took away so much and even now use the offerings in our morning meditation and prayer.

The facilities are great, it looks like they have just renovated almost everything.
But lack of cleaners. There are rubbish scattered around and the toilets are not clean either.
Unfortunately the price ticket is very steep, 150k for foreigners and 80 for locals. The thing is that there's nothing so special about it. It's just a massive complex with more than 50 small and big temples. If you have seen some temples in Bali, it's essentially 50 of them in one place. After a while they all look the same.
Plus tourists are not meant to go inside the temple unless you want to pray, so you end up walking around the temples only.
It is still worth it to come over once if you are so curious about it but I believe many people skip this place because of the price point, there are no local tourists when I was there, it's either foreigners or local people who go there to pray.
Also they let sellers at the compound of the temples which make the temple looks like a market and lost it's charm. They already have many dedicated spots for sellers, so having that many along the temple look very unsightly. I honestly think there are other places that are better, more bang for buck in Bali. It's too commercialized.
Expect 1h+ to go around the area. It's not wheelchair nor pram friendly, although they have a electric buggy that bring you up closer to the temple area.

Tips - Ticket entry *includes* everything you need, including a guide. So do not believe the people at the gate who will try and trick you into buying an offering (no you don't need one to get in, yes they will definitely still let you in without one). Also be careful of any guide or person who wants to take a photo of you, they will ask for tips after. And yes, your guide WILL expect a tip of at least 200k at the end. If you don't give "enough" they will laugh and ask for more... At the main temple there is a place to take a fake photo with a mirror (for extra charge). And be careful with the shops and sellers who will tell you they have no change to try and make you pay more... They almost certainly do have change.

If you ignore all the people trying to trick you into giving them more money than the already expensive tourist entrance fee, then it's a very nice temple, with amazing views of the ocean and South Bali. Also despite all the people hustling, it's still an authentic temple. We were here on a day where there was a ceremony, and the locals attending were super friendly and kind. It's such a shame that a minority of tricksters and hustlers are ruining this sacred place...

Pura Agung Besakih, also known as the "Mother Temple" of Bali, is an awe-inspiring destination that every visitor to the island should definitely see. Here are a few reasons why this temple is so special:

1. **Spiritual significance**: As the largest and most important temple in Bali, Pura Agung Besakih plays a central role in the religious life of the Balinese people. Numerous ceremonies and festivals are held here, reflecting the island's deep-rooted culture and spirituality.

2. **Spectacular location**: The temple is located in the foothills of the majestic Gunung Agung, Bali's highest volcano.  This impressive backdrop gives the place a special grandeur and attracts both pilgrims and tourists.

3. **Architecture and beauty**: The Pura Besakih comprises several temple complexes that are artfully designed and feature a variety of pagodas. The attention to detail in the architecture and the beautiful statues and carvings make it a visual highlight.

4. **Breathtaking views**: From the various terraces within the temple you have breathtaking views of the surrounding rice fields and the mountain landscape. It is worth taking time to enjoy this beautiful view.

5. **Cultural experiences**: When visiting the temple you often have the opportunity to talk to locals or take part in cultural activities. Interacting with the Balinese can be very enriching and offer a deeper insight into their traditions.

6. **Accessibility**: Although the path to the temple can be a bit challenging (especially due to the altitude), the effort is definitely worth it!  There are guided tours that can help you learn more about the temple as well as its history.

7. **Important Note**: Make sure to wear appropriate clothing (sarong and scarf) as this is an important religious site.

Overall, my visit to Pura Agung Besakih was an enriching experience full of spirituality, beautiful landscapes and cultural depth. This place will surely hold a special place in my heart! ??

Il **tempio di Besakih** � il pi� grande e importante complesso di templi ind� a Bali, Indonesia, noto anche come il "Tempio Madre". Situato sul versante sud-occidentale del monte Agung, il vulcano pi� alto dell'isola, questo complesso sacro si trova a un'altitudine di circa 1000 metri, immerso in un ambiente naturale spettacolare.

Il tempio risale a oltre 1000 anni fa ed � dedicato a **Shiva**, una delle principali divinit� del pantheon ind�. Il complesso � composto da **23 templi separati** distribuiti su sei livelli terrazzati che salgono lungo il pendio del monte. Il pi� importante tra questi � il **Pura Penataran Agung**, che funge da centro spirituale.

L'architettura del tempio riflette lo stile balinese tradizionale, con ampi cortili, padiglioni cerimoniali e santuari, decorati con sculture raffinate e dettagli intricati. Molte delle strutture presentano i caratteristici **meru**, torri multilivello con tetti di paglia, che simboleggiano la dimora degli d�i.

Il tempio di Besakih � un importante centro di pellegrinaggio per gli ind� balinesi e ospita numerose cerimonie religiose durante l'anno, attirando migliaia di devoti. Nonostante la sua sacralit�, il complesso � anche una popolare meta turistica, apprezzata per la sua bellezza architettonica e l'atmosfera spirituale.

Short: your Besakih experience will fully depend on a guide assigned to you at the tickets desk.

Details:
Thanks to the recent reviews here, we were ready to meet scammers when visiting Besakih. We bought entrance tickets IDR 150k per person, then got our sarongs and then were assigned a guide. From the very beginning the guide (man in his 60s or 70s) told he is known as �Scooby Doo� because he is �a very poor man�. Then we got into an electric car and it took us slightly uphill to the main gates of Besakih. As for us (we are average fit), we could walk that distance just by foot, but okay.

Back to the guide, when we were walking with him on the territory between temples, he told us not a word about the complex, or its history, or history of hindu or whatever else one can expect to hear from a guide. He only answered our questions like: �We read this temple is Mother of temples, is it the very first temple on Bali?� - �Yes, very old ancient temple, 8 century..� and so on.

His level of English was really bad. Half of the tour he told us that we shouldn�t hit dogs (why would we want to do that?) and tried to make stupid jokes which were barely understandable probably because of bad English again, not funny.

In the end of the �tour� he asked for a tip (for what?) so that he �could eat nasi goreng�. We knew a guide is included in ticket price, and also we believe a tip is what is given when service is very good, but still we gave him around 35k (again, for nothing) and he tried to ask for more, but we said �that is enough�.

Before us, our friends visited Besakih and they were assigned a guide they liked very much and they tipped him IDR 100k by their own wish. Also, when we were walking, we heard other guides telling something meaningful to other guests.

So, your experience of visiting Besakih fully depends on a guide assiged to you. Before the visit we were ready to give IDR 100k or more if we liked our experience there, but it was just not worth it, it was more annoying rather than interesting or impressive.

So be aware.

As long as you pay attention to these things it is a great temple to visit.

Besakih Temple, is known as the "Mother Temple" of Bali, is the island's largest and most sacred Hindu temple. Situated on the slopes of �Mount Agung�, it features stunning tiered architecture with multiple courtyards and intricately carved gateways. Over 1,000 years old, it serves as a major spiritual center, hosting important religious ceremonies. Its serene location and rich history make it a must-visit for those interested in Balinese culture and architecture.

Amazing place, very holy and beautiful in front of the most iconic place mount Agung. The reason why 1* is because of being harassed every minute by locals who want something.

They propose the same and when you say I'm just here to pray they get ugly and angry. A holy place shouldn't be about money but unfortunately this is that place. It just ruins tourism but also the fact of how they represent their religion. They want you to dress and act polite but, when it's up to them they can act against all of the Hinduism norms and beliefs. Sad that there is actually not much respect from locals where there is tourism. Just go out and explore the villages there you have clean energetic beautiful temples with beautiful locals who have the most beautiful heart and souls.

Visiting Besakih Great Temple was truly a memorable experience. The temple complex is a stunning example of old Balinese architecture, nestled on the slopes of Mount Agung. The intricate carvings and majestic structures are not only beautiful but also deeply steeped in cultural significance. Walking through the temple grounds, I was in awe of the serene atmosphere and the breathtaking views of the surrounding landscape.

The historical and spiritual importance of Besakih is palpable, and it�s a place where you can feel the rich heritage of the Balinese people. The architecture reflects a harmonious blend of nature and spirituality, making it a perfect spot for reflection and appreciation of Bali's cultural roots.

However, one downside to my visit was the persistence of the vendors. While I understand that they are trying to make a living, the constant pressure to buy souvenirs or offerings can be a bit overwhelming at times. It detracted slightly from the peaceful experience of exploring such a sacred site.

Overall, Besakih Great Temple is a must-visit for anyone interested in Balinese culture and history. Just be prepared for the hustle of the vendors, and you�ll have an enriching experience surrounded by beautiful architecture and spirituality.

The place is enormous and can be seen from a distance.
Wearing a sarong is mandatory to access the temple.
There are several stairways leading to the temples, and their entrances are adorned with sculptures.
Several temples are closed to the general public.
There are stalls inside the temple where locals sell snacks, drinks, fruits, and other items.
It's a good idea to learn about the culture and religion before visiting the temple. If possible, join a local to make offerings, pray, and truly immerse yourself in the culture.
Overall, the place is quite large, and I would estimate at least two hours for the visit from the moment you arrive. The temple is beautiful, and the visit is ideal for those seeking a spiritual experience.

Mooie grote tempel. Gelukkig hadden we een leuke en goede gids en waren de meeste kraampjes dicht. Als je met de shuttle aankomt staan er inderdaad veel vrouwen die je plastic tasjes met offers in je handen drukken. Gelukkig wisten we dit door alle reviews,  dus konden we die meteen afwimpelen.

Besakih Temple is amazing. Really, the experience is based on how well you prepare the trip.

1. If you can, find your own guide! I was very fortunate to have met some amazing people in Ubud, one who recommended I go with a local priest. (Her friend) I was very lucky to have this connection, and it was one of the reasons my trip was so special. I was welcomed into the temple courtyard to get blessed + pray with the local balinese. There were a lot of guides; some seemed invested, some not.

2. Wear the correct clothing! Even though I was with the local priest, if I wasn't in full traditional attire, then I would be denied of going inside the temple and praying with the locals. Be smart and respectful. At the very least, bring your own sarong and cover your shoulders. It goes a long way.

3. Get there early!!! I arrived at 8am and for almost 1.5 hours we had the whole place to ourselves. A lot of the stalls weren't open yet so that added to the experience. Some sellers did sell unique things, I bought a bracelet with volcano rocks and tiger eye. Some can be overbearing and annoying at times, but please have perspective, this is how they earn money to live. Be kind.

If this is high on your list, plan it right, and you will have a great time!

Wir hatten einen super Guide erwischt, der uns alles in Ruhe gezeigt. Hier hatten wir oft was anderes gelesen. Nichtsdestotrotz bin ich froh einmal dort gewesen zu sein.

Very beautiful but you are paired with a guide and have to take the shuttle up.

The shuttle drops you off at the top and you are harassed by beggars to buy their prayer offerings. Very uncomfortable, almost threatening. I asked our guide afterwards and he wouldn't even acknowledge and so I was suspicious of him the entire tour. We got to the top and went through some prayer ceremonies. After, we were pressured to "donate" 100K IDR. Was going to give less to get rid of change, I didn't have all that much cash, but that didn't seem satisfactory.

The tour is then almost over and then our guide takes us off to a side street of sorts and asks for some tips again. I obliged with just the small bills and then you descend solo (no shuttle) through a ring of shops selling trinkets. If you want to barter just play hardball, you'll get things half off what they try to sell you. They're desperate and even drove me down via scooter just so I could use the credit card, only to find they tried to upcharge me a huge amount (10x), so just make sure you always read the card reader and count the zeros.

Again the temple is super beautiful, and in total we only spent $18 for two tickets with another $10 or so in cash tips. It cost us nothing, but for me it really ruined the experience to be viewed by the locals like a food bowl, ingratiating themselves like house pets. We haven't experienced the same at any of the other tourist attractions in Bali where frankly we are happily more generous.

Go when it's less cloudy and I'm sure the temples would have been even more stunning. To the locals here, have a bit of pride.

Pura Besakih, oft als der �Muttertempel� von Bali bezeichnet, ist ein beeindruckendes spirituelles Zentrum, das sich majest�tisch am Hang des Gunung Agung erhebt. Dieser Tempelkomplex, der aus �ber 80 einzelnen Tempeln besteht, bietet nicht nur eine tiefgehende kulturelle Erfahrung, sondern auch atemberaubende Ausblicke auf die umliegende Landschaft.

Die Architektur von Pura Besakih ist ein wahres Meisterwerk balinesischer Baukunst. Die kunstvoll gestalteten Schreine und Stufen, die sich harmonisch in die nat�rliche Umgebung einf�gen, laden dazu ein, die spirituelle Atmosph�re zu genie�en. Besucher k�nnen die verschiedenen Tempel erkunden, die jeweils eine eigene Bedeutung und Geschichte haben. Besonders beeindruckend ist der Haupttempel, Pura Penataran Agung, der f�r seine majest�tischen Stufen und die eindrucksvollen Schreine bekannt ist.

Die Umgebung von Pura Besakih ist ebenso faszinierend. Die �ppigen Reisfelder und die beeindruckende Berglandschaft schaffen eine friedliche Kulisse, die zum Verweilen einl�dt. Es ist ein idealer Ort, um die Sch�nheit der balinesischen Natur zu erleben und sich von der spirituellen Energie des Ortes inspirieren zu lassen.

Ein Besuch von Pura Besakih ist nicht nur eine Reise in die balinesische Kultur, sondern auch eine Gelegenheit, die Ruhe und den Frieden der Umgebung zu genie�en. Die herzliche Gastfreundschaft der Einheimischen und die M�glichkeit, an traditionellen Zeremonien teilzunehmen, machen diesen Ort zu einem unvergesslichen Erlebnis. Egal, ob man sich f�r die Geschichte, die Architektur oder die Natur interessiert, Pura Besakih bietet f�r jeden etwas und bleibt lange im Ged�chtnis.

The temples are magnificent. The ticket will include a guide, one way shuttle, and a sarong.
However be careful as guides might try to scam tourists. At first we were happy with our guide who was very friendly, explaining the temple and warning us about people trying to sell us offering. Their attitude is sadly against the good karma they keep talking about during the visit.

The temple itself is serene and very spiritual. The admission fee has obviously gone up (we paid 150k Rp/person), which includes a local guide. The assigned guide however was very knowledgeable and eager to explain everything to us, so in the end we happily tipped him 100k.

- The largest Hindu temple in Bali. And I heard from a local people, there are 4 most important temples in Bali which Balinese Hinduism should come to pray and worship and this temple is one of them. Ancient and very beautiful! Like other Hindu temples in Bali, inside the temple only for prayer, so if you are a traveler and just come to take a look, you only can walk around the temple, nt allowed to go inside. If you want to go inside to pray, you can do it, but must follow Balinese prayer rituals. It mean you need to wear properly and need a local people guide you how to do it. It feels like they sell everything but still keep the most important thing. And it keep their temples are still a sacred place. I had nothing to do inside, so i satisfied with standing outside and observed.
- The entrance ticket is 150k rp, including a tour guide accompany you, but if you want to explore this place by yourself, you can tell them you dont want a tour guide. In my opinion, you should go with a tour guide, they will give you useful information abt the history of the temple, culture, ect. Very intetesting. You dont need to tip if you nt satisfy with your tour guide.
- There are many other temples around, no fee, so you should take time to explore. My tour guide finished the tour for 30 mins, and I took 2 hours to explore by myself.
- Things I dont like: 1, customers are disturded by many vendors around the temple. 2, too crowded. 3, everything is commercialized. 4, ticket was quite expensive. I think these things maybe happen in most of tourist attractions in Bali, but generally, this temple is still worth a visit.

They charged us 50k per person which was obviously overpriced. Again, feel free to refuse (especially if you don�t want to join the prayers, accompanied by the local guides).

Pura terbesar Dan termegah di Bali.

Visited Besakih Great Temple on 6th July. The temple was amazing and huge. I loved the layout and culture of the temple. A MUST VISIT INDEED. However, I was greatly disappointed in the lack of information of the price of the temple. When I checked Google Reviews, they were people talking about all kinds of prices to visit the temple. This made me confused and I did not know what price to expect when I visited the Temple. It was only after passing through the information board on the way out of the temple that I found that the official price for foreigners is 150k rupiah. This price includes free rental of sarong, a guide and a buggy ride up to the temple grounds.

If you choose to visit the temple, BEWARE of the scams near the temple. The people selling you a sarong for 100-120k and temple offerings for money at the temple surroundings are mostly scams. BE CAREFUL when visiting the temple.

This is the most BEAUTIFUL temple in Bali, however the most CORRUPT place in all temples.

I paid 150,000 IDR for the entrance, sarong and TOUR GUIDE. So the tour guide was boasting that he was a temple expert and gave me an advice not to buy any offerings at the top of the temple. Yet, he introduced his friend who will take my picture in the temple.

So the photographer took shots of me in three different locations and after that he explained it to me that each location will cost me 3 and offered me more locations. Me expecting it 3k IDR per location, I agreed about it. After the session, he was charging me 450,000 IDR for 9 locations. In my surprise, I asked him that he told me it will cost me 3k IDR per location, and he replied it was 3 USD per location.

The TOUR GUIDE in which didn�t explain a lot of history and traditions about the temple, I tipped him 100k IDR in which I know it was more than enough, however, he was asking for more.

I just left giving them what they want since I felt I was harassed by both of them.

This is my personal experience and may or may not applicable to other tourist guides or photographers.

My fault was I didn�t confirmed how much the pictures will cost me.

However, knowing that the tour guide is included in the ticket price, they should have not asked the tourist for a tip. Tips are discretion by the visitors.

I can be generous in giving or what, but being pressured in giving is a different story.

Visiting Pura Besakih, especially during religious ceremonies, is a deeply enriching experience that offers insights into Balinese culture.

Om Swastiastu 

If you're seeking blessings for your health, relationships, or family, a visit to Mangku Jati at the highest point of Besakih Temple (called Pura Gelap) is recommended for those on a journey of healing and self-discovery.

Pura Gelap has a mystical and protective focus. It is often sought out by those specifically looking for its unique blessings related to darkness and protection.

When you speak with Mangku Jati, whether you have a specific request or are unsure what to ask for, he will provide a sincere blessing tailored to your needs. He will know what you need. His healing powers have benefited thousands.

The energy at the top temple is exceptionally potent, bring a flower offering with incense sticks. Many local ladies sell these offerings along the way. Place any amount of money you are comfortable with inside your offering basket as a gesture of you are ready to receive blessings.

This tradition of offering has been observed for thousands of years, not only at Pura Besakih but at any temples worldwide. When you sincerely seek divine help, it is natural to give first. The act of giving opens up space within you to receive. Those who give with a pure heart often find themselves receiving abundantly in return because they feel more deserving of receiving.

Also, the average monthly income in this town ranges from $150 to $250, with working seven days a week. Spending a few dollars can significantly help local families.

Buying offerings near the top would be better to avoid carrying them for too long. When you ask for directions, locals will point to the top temple. It's a straight walk. It's easy to find.

How to Pray at Pura Gelap in Besakih Temple Complex

Once you are seated, the prayer will be led by a monk or your guide. It follows 5 steps:

Step 1: Pray without flowers (Greeting to God)
Steps 2-4: Pray with flowers
Step 5: Pray without flowers (Gratitude)

During the prayer, the monk will sprinkle holy water on your head. Don't worry, they will demonstrate and pray with you. It's easy to follow their lead. Even if you miss some details, you will still be blessed as long as your heart is open to receiving divine wisdom, love, and guidance during the process.

At the end, the monk will sprinkle holy water on your head and hands, and bless you with rice on your forehead. You can remain seated and meditate more or do whatever your heart desires.

Om Shanti, Shanti, Shanti Om

Het is een zeer mooie en interessante plaats, maar de ziel van de plek wordt buitensporig gecommercialiseerd. Je betaalt als buitenlander 150K IDR, wat naar Indonesische normen erg veel is. In ruil krijg je een verplichte sarong - ook al heb je er zelf al een - en een overbodig busritje van een kilometer naar boven.

Ook komt er een gids met je mee. Daar moet je geluk mee hebben. Ik zag sommige bezoekers met een gedreven gids die hen ook waarschuwde voor allerlei soorten geldklopperij bij de tempels, waar het krioelt van de opdringerige verkopers. Met onze gids hadden we geen geluk. Hij was niet enthousiast, antwoordde vaak 'ja' of 'nee' of 'weet ik niet' op mijn vragen om er snel van af te zijn en probeerde ons bezoek al na 40 minuten stop te zetten, terwijl het een uur zou moeten zijn. Daarna vroeg hij bovendien rechtuit om een fooi, wat blijkbaar alle gidsen hier doen.

Maak voor jezelf de afweging of het de moeite waard is voor jou. Het is op zich een bijzondere plek, maar je loopt er niet echt op je gemak rond en dat is dit tempelcomplex onwaardig.

Pros: the temple itself is very nice and it's possible to pay by card.

Cons: the price of 150k for foreigners does not make sense considering that:
- You cannot actually enter inside of the temple (which I respect, but why paying that much then?)
- They say a guide is included but truth is he will only take you to the entrance of the temple, give you little information which you could easily read on Wikipedia and then say that, if you want him to tell you more while walking in the temple area, you will have to give him an additional "tip". Just don't say it is included then.
- Shuttle should be included but it is true only on the way to the temple, you will have to walk to come back.
- They transformed a holy place in a sort of market to sell you clothes, food and souvenirs, which is quite hypocritical considering they wouldn't let menstruating women enter the temple... Is it really worse than having people trying to sell you stuff at every corner?
- You would have to pay to take a picture on the main photo spot of the temple... After 150k for entering? Really?

ARRIVE WHEN IT OPENS. We arrived at 8:10am and saw only a handful of other people.

VERY IMPORTANT TO KNOW:

�You receive a personal tour guide in the ticket price (300,000IDR for 2 people) BUT YOU DO NOT NEED TO BUY OFFERINGS. Some corrupt tour guides will tell you you must buy offerings to pray which is true but you must also wear the traditional Balinese praying uniform in order to enter the centre courtyard. The chances are you want to just visit the temple and unless you want to specifically partake in giving 5X over priced offerings at the entrance shines then do not fall for the scam.

�These same corrupt tour guides will take you to "the best cafe", "the cheapest gift shop", or any other "best" recommendation just be cautious as these same tour guides will get commission on your purchases. This hidden commission doesn't stop just at this temple, in fact most private drivers/taxis that "recommend" a attraction will most certainly be getting a 30-60% commission on your purchases.

DISCLAIMER:
These sellers need money, like we all do. But some of us have an easier time making money so although this hidden scam is annoying try to stay empathetic. I had a guide who exposed all of these 'insider' tricks to me. Although he exposed these hidden tricks to me he did still ask for a tip, I gifted 100,000 which might be overkill, at the end of the tour but because of his knowledge, respect for me and my partner as tourists, and security amongst the horde of cheap sellers this was a small price to pay for a "good" tour guide!

Pura Agung Besakih merupakan pura terbesar yang ada di bali, dan disebut juga mother of temple, semenjak dibangunnya parkiran motor dan mobil sekarang setiap kesana macet sudah jauh berkurang, kecuali pada saat odalan macet masih sering terjadi, karena para pemedek rame dan membeludak, jika ingin berkujung ke pura agung besakih ada baiknya setelah odalan selesai, tapi jika ingin menikmati adat, budaya dan tradisi, bisa datang saat odalan yang berlangsung kurang lebih selama satu bulan terhitung dari sebelum puncak odalan yang jatuh pada purnama sasih kedasa ( biasanya di bulan april )

**Besakih Temple Review**

Besakih Temple, known as the "Mother Temple" of Bali, is an awe-inspiring and culturally rich destination that every visitor to the island should experience. Nestled on the slopes of Mount Agung, this temple complex offers breathtaking views and a profound sense of spirituality.

Upon arrival, the sheer size of Besakih Temple is striking. It is the largest and holiest temple of the Hindu religion in Bali, with over 80 individual temples sprawling across its vast grounds. The architecture is intricate and beautiful, with each shrine, pagoda, and gateway showcasing traditional Balinese design and craftsmanship.

The temple is a functioning place of worship, so you can witness local devotees performing rituals and ceremonies. This provides a unique glimpse into Balinese culture and religious practices. However, it�s important to dress modestly and wear a sarong, which can be rented at the entrance if you don't have one.

The journey to the temple involves a scenic drive through lush landscapes, adding to the overall experience. Once there, be prepared for a bit of a hike, as the temple is built on a hillside and involves some climbing. The panoramic views from various points in the temple complex are absolutely worth the effort, offering stunning vistas of the surrounding countryside and the majestic Mount Agung.

One downside to note is that the temple can be quite crowded, especially during peak tourist seasons. Additionally, some visitors have reported encountering aggressive touts and guides, so it�s wise to be firm and clear about your intentions if you prefer to explore on your own.

In summary, Besakih Temple is a must-visit for its historical significance, spiritual ambiance, and impressive architecture. Despite the occasional hustle and bustle, it remains a deeply enriching experience that captures the essence of Bali�s cultural heritage.

Avoid this place at all costs. It was the worst part of our time in our 2 week Bali trip. Scams and upselling at every turn. Built on the slopes of Mount Agung, Bali's highest volcano, Besakih Temple is revered in Balinese Hinduism as the most important temple on the island. Over the years, it has survived natural disasters and undergone numerous renovations, yet it remains�a symbol of resilience and devotion for the Balinese.  The precise origins of the temple are unclear but its importance as a holy site almost certainly dates from prehistoric times. The stone bases of Pura Penataran Agung and several other temples resemble megalithic stepped pyramids, which date back at least 2,000 years. It was certainly used as a Hindu place of worship from 1284 when the first Javanese conquerors settled in Bali. By the 15th century, Besakih had become a state temple of the powerful

Also pay attention to people/scammers telling you that you need to buy offers to enter the temple, or a sarong (which is included in the price). Count 1-1.5h to visit it.

It is this kind of place, where everyone wants to take your money. The Temple is beautiful, but not better than any other in Bali. Just bigger. We paid 150 000 IDR!!! per person: sarong and guide is supposedly included in the price of the ticket. We got sarongs, but the guide told us that he wants a tip after the tour because he does not get any money from the 150 000 we paid... And also left us when a group of women wanted to force us to buy some offerings for 200 000 IDR!!! Finally we have visited the temple alone, because we felt scammed and weren't wiling to pay thousands of rupias every step we took.. Really depressing experience.

Entrance ticket price of 150K IDR includes the guide and sarong. However at the end of the tour the guide will ask you for a tip. Our asked us 10� tip for a bloody walk around the temple and few pictures taken with our cell phones. We barely leave such amount of tip in Europe!!!!! After we told him that our driver said to leave maximum 20K he shut up and went away.
Explicitly ask not to have a guide!

The place itself is really beautiful, however my visit ended up being the most expensive activity in Bali, with a total of 400k per person spent. The entrance is already quite expensive (150k pp) but it includes the bus shuttle, which is great. Once, gotten off the shuttle, I literally got assaulted by people asking money for the flowers (offers) (200k pp) and who told me that it was mandatory to buy those otherwise I couldn�t visit the temple. Once visited the temple and did our prayer, the guide made us make an offer of 100k pp and at the end of the visit asked us a tip of additional 100k and I had to show him my empty wallet with the last 2000 rupiah inside (which he obviously took).
Magical place but terrible terrible terrible experience.

Pura Agung Besakih memukau dengan kebesarannya dan nilai sejarahnya yang tinggi sebagai tempat ibadah utama umat Hindu. Dengan lingkungan yang luas, pura ini menawarkan pengalaman spiritual yang mendalam bagi para pengunjung. Area parkir yang luas memudahkan aksesibilitas. Pura ini sangat direkomendasikan bagi siapa pun yang ingin merasakan keagungan arsitektur Hindu Bali dan merasakan aura spiritual yang khas. Mengunjungi Pura Agung Besakih adalah pengalaman yang tak terlupakan, yang tidak hanya memperkaya pengetahuan tentang kepercayaan Hindu, tetapi juga memberikan kesempatan untuk merenungkan keindahan dan kebesaran alam semesta.

Pura Besakih is by far the largest and most sacred temple complex on the island of Bali.  And is also the religious and spiritual center of Bali.  Some parts of the temple�have existed since the beginning of the common era.  The nice thing about the temple complex is that it is built against the active volcano Gunung Agung.  The temples are reached by a long staircase that goes higher and higher up the mountain as shown in the photo...

Pura yg cukup iconic & historical namun harga tiket masuk tidak worth it dengan experience yg di dapatkan. Saya expect dengan harga 50rb/orang, apalagi pada saat itu sedang berlangsung upacara agama, bisa mendapat banyak informasi yg bisa menambah wawasan saya. Harga tsb utk tiket masuk, pinjam kain sarung, guide & shuttle bus one way. Pulangnya jalan kaki sekitar 1km ke parkiran. Dan di akhir sesi, guide meminta tips tambahan berupa uang lagi. Like whaatt?! Guide nya bahkan hanya fokus ke "jualan foto" dengan biaya tambahan lagi pastinya bukan ke penjelasan sejarah pura, kegiatan upacara, budaya & agama yg sedang berlangsung. Harapan saya karena ini adalah pura terbesar di Bali, pasti ada dukungan dana pengelolaan dari Pemerintah, sebaiknya dikaji kembali untuk harga tiket masuk & experience yg diberikan, agar di sesuaikan lagi supaya wisatawan domestik tertarik untuk berkunjung & mengenal lebih dalam tentang budaya Bali itu sendiri khususnya agama Hindu.

Nice temple ruined by con artists who made me so angry and ruined the experience. When we arrived, many women were all rudely yelling at once trying to sell me a sarong (to hire to wear inside). I also paid for a tour which supposedly included all entry fees, yet as I entered, I was lead to some type of office by my chauffeur. Here I was asked to make a donation to pay for a guide and they me showed me the guest book showing all the donations people made including someone who made a very large donation of $50 (or maybe much more maybe even $500). In disgust and anger, I told my chauffeur to take me straight back to the hotel, and then they let in me without making any donation. Bali can be nice but way too many scammers and con men. Just be careful. Just ignore them and keep walking usually works best.

Guys! I don�t know where to start! Just had my 1st worst experience in Bali! The Besakih Temple is very beautiful infront because it is very well decorated thus you can have the best pictures! The worst thing is when we arrived every seller force you to buy something. We were forced to rent skirt (saru) Rs100,000 and that�s okay because we know it�s a sacred place and that we have to respect it! But then we were forced to buy offerings (Rs100,000). They said we need to have this since it was a ceremony day and we cannot go inside without this! So we bought it but when we tried to enter the temple to place our offering that we bought, nobody allowed us to approach the temple! i mean everyone denied our access in the temple!  So what�s the use of paying a driver to bring you there and what�s the use of forcing us to buy offerings when we do not have  access in the temple?! We paid offering in vain this is a scam!! You will  pay your driver only to see the beautiful entrance and that�s all you will never have access behind this. You will take picture on the stairs but they will not allow you to climb the stairs to access the temple despite other people will do it! I know lots of temples in bali are not open for tourist but here they will ripped your money!! This place is the only place in Bali where we were asked to pay many things. I forgot to add the tourist guide who force us to take him because as per what he said, it�s a sacred place and we need to pay a guide. Luckily, i had an idea of telling him that last year i already came here and that i already know the place then he smiled and told his colleagues �these two i couldn�t have them�. The temple is beautiful outside but you will never have access inside or even not near the temple, you will never climb up the stairs. So be careful when you are paying big amount to a driver for a place that you will not even visit! Entrance access is rs90,000 per person (it�s okay we didn�t mind since we paid more for other places) but at the end when you realised you paid rs90,000 for less than 30min it�s a scam!!! Please go an visit other places in bali and not this temple!

An absolutely amazing Hindu temple complex that is worth the visit for anyone who has even a remote interest in architecture, history or religion. You can wonder over 20 temples on the premises, all dedicated to a different Hindu deity and/or purpose and all maintained by the local community. Some of the temples are still built with volcanic stone, whereas others were more recently rebuilt with sandstone. The touristic side of the Pura Besakih is what detracts from the overall experience unfortunately; there are intruding salespeople and photographers everywhere in and around the temple, the guides you get assigned by default at the start of your visit expect a certain tip at the end (and are NOT happy with less, which is ridiculous) and some tourists, even outside the season, tend to hug some photo spots which is just plain annoying. I realise the local people should be able to profit from tourism, but there are better (less obtrusive) ways to do so. Still, the Mother Temple of Bali is an absolute must-visit for everyone!

Incredible complex and well worth the visit. Go with a local Balinese and pray with the Balinese.  Why?  Because it's a powerful place. Everyone is welcome and did you know Besakih means protection.  A visit here helped me get over my very sad divorce.  After, visit the Eidelweiss farm. It's magic there .

De tempel zelf is mooi, niet ontzettend prachtig maar wel indrukwekkend. Entree en verplichte gids is inbegrepen bij de entreeprijs. De verkopers zijn erg agressief en doen als je eenmaal boven bent een sjaal om je middel heen (bij mij als vrouw) en geven offerbakjes, deze moet je gewoon terug in hun handen duwen / nee zeggen anders moet je betalen. De gids vroeg na afloop geld en vroeg hierna zelfs; kan je dit niet verhogen. De verkopers en gids hebben voor mij het plezier van de tour ontnomen. Ik voelde me niet op mijn gemak (ik was alleen).

Found to be the best biggest temple in Bali and most impressive. Though as a Cambodian, I am not much into that as we have so many big and grand temples here back home such as Angkor Wat, Bayon, Ta Prohm (photo attached).
However, Besakih temple is best to combine with Mount Batur and Bali Swing, Rice Terrace for small group.
Besakih Pura sangat bagus dan indah. Banyak kenangan disana.

Kemarin datang bersama rombongan SMA dalam rangka Tirtayatra setelah ujian praktek (7 bus). Akses parkiran mudah dan banyak ruang kosong. Dari parkiran untuk akses jaba sisi pura harus jalan naik yang lumayan jauh (latihan kaki). Sampai disana lanjut ke Pedharman masing masing. Saya ke Pedharman Ratu Pasek, masuk kedalam sedang ada renovasi tapi masih bisa sembahyang.

Selanjutnya ke Penataran Agung dan Kawitan dan setelah selesai keluar ke jaba sisi (turun tangga) kemudian naik kembali  ke paling puncak untuk ke Pura Gelap. Di pura gelap sepi hanya ditemani mangku dan selesai sembahyang turun kembali lanjut ke area kuliner dan oleh oleh. Untuk di area kuliner tempat sampah ada tapi sampah masih berserakan dan keluar dari area kuliner banyak ojek yang menawarkan jasa (terkesan memaksa). Selesai dari sana kembali ke bus dan pulang

Biggest Hindu temple in Bali. The atmosphere is calming and tourists need to dress properly. Many locals would insist on offering guidance during the visit and usually they will charge a lot at the end. Some would even lie that going with a guide is mandatory, while it�s not. Everyone is free to walk there, but please remain respectful.

The most sacred temple in Bali, they call it Mother of Temples.. the breathtaking view will definitely spoil your eyes. The ticket actually includes entrance fee, tour guide, sarong hire and one time shuttle ride, it�s 50k for locals and 90k for foreigners. The tour guides speak in various languages, just mention it where you�re from at the entrance area, you�ll be explained about the temple and Balinese culture. Unfortunately, there are lot of scams, from selling flowers (they will just directly give it to you or even put it on your ear and ask for money), the price is incredibly expensive. They will ask two or three times from the ticket cost! Around 100k-150k. As visitors, you aren�t required to bring flowers or anything to the temple and only locals who have ceremony allowed to enter the main area of the temple. And be careful to those who persuade you to take pictures using your own phone camera, one spot costs 30k rupiah, but they will take it two or three or even 5 spots, just multiply it by 30k.
100% worth visiting

We paid the 90k entrance fee, and what's included is written everywhere: entrance fee, one way shuttle up the hill, a guide and a sarong rental. The price is the same whether you use all or none of those services.

Our guide was courteous and informative. He asked if we would be making any offerings, and we said no. No one bothered us for offerings. We did have some persistent kids selling postcards, but it's 10k for 2, for their school, so we got 1. We also visited some fruit vendors and the prices were like the street stands, no mark up.

It wasn't that crowded and we had a very pleasant experience. Non-worshippers are only allowed in the main public temple (and only if there are no ceremonies), and all other areas are family or private temples. So for people complaining about not being able to go inside those temples, please respect the rules.

I didn�t enjoy it and i felt scammed.
Seeing the temples was good in itself.
But i felt like the guides took advantage of us.

There was a sign for a photo for 30K IDR. but after giving our money, we didn�t get enough change. I asked why the sign said 30k but he just said he wasn�t lying. Ended up paying 50k idr.

The guide asked us to buy balinese offerings (50k idr). I was initially ok with this to give respect. But upon leaving the offerings, he said normally everyone gives donation after prayer. Fine. Then while we were getting money. He said we should give 2 red money (200k). I was getting annoyed at this point and asked why is he telling us how much to donate. He then said it is up to us how much to give.

We already paid an entrance fee at the beginning. I feel like if they needed more, just include that in the fee.

Also wanted to say that this is my only bad experience in Bali and this �trap� didn�t happen to us when we visited another temple.

Really beautiful place on the hill top. After ticket, you can opt for free buddy to the temple entrance. Walking can take up to 15 mins though. They don't bring you down via buggy but many private riders there offering bike down at 10k rupiah. The buggy down is available for old people though. There are going to be a lot of haggling to ask you buy things. Up to you if you like to help them a bit. The photographer in the temple Will ask 30k for mirror photograph. Note that if you add new members into the photography, they will ask additional 30k.

Mesmerizing complex filled with beautiful temples, gardens and scenery. Hiring a guide is well worth it and leave a generous tip as your karma will be rewarded. I learned quite a lot about Balinese Hinduism. It's best to leave early as we had the place to ourselves for over an hour. As always dress appropriately as you are entering a sacred space not a beach.

Prachtige tempel, maar overal van kassa tot en met de gids zelf pusht men om geld te geven. Overal zijn oplichters die bijvoorbeeld zeggen dat het kopen van offerandes verplicht is. En dan ook nog voor veel te hoge prijzen.
Rondlopende verkopers laten je nergens met rust. Erg erg hinderlijk.

Ik gaf zowaar de - verplichte (?) - gids een fooi en die zei letterlijk: "ping ping; can I get double?"

This place has some aura of its own beautiful temple overlooking Mountain you will find less tourist

It is a shame when we brought our guests to learn more about the hindhu balinese culture, they got a really bad experience which I witnessed with my own eyes. I feel sorry for my guests who have to experience all of that. Even though I accompanied them all together from the bottom until the top, they still had bad experiences. For me, I prefer to take my own guests to visit another temple who can give the best experience for them to learn.

Please for the management, you need to treat the tourists better than now. They paid 90K/person, and from what I understand is the shuttle is to help the elderly people who can't walk down by themselves. But in fact, we need a letter etc to use the shuttle to going down for elderly people, and this isn't good. How can you push an elderly person to walk down without mercy, until half way I need to stop the shuttle car, and begging them to carry two of my guests to go down, because they aren't in a good condition to walk down for 800 meters. And the answer is, they just want to take 1 person only, which I have two of them. So I need to beg so they are willing to carry two.

I do understand that we need to support the local economy, I am also a local person, and I always teach my guests to support the local economy in a good way. Not by pushing them, swearing, yelling, and saying bad words to them. If you are offering your things in a good way, I believe the tourists will come and buy if they really like it. God has arranged each person's fortune. Don't be greedy or be a bad person just for money.

About the guide which is included in the ticket price. We as a tour company also want to share income with them by using them to guide our guests. We also understand the tipping etc, we already prepared the tipping money for the guide. But don't ask the guests again for the tipping when we already give it to you, because we know if our guest doesn't give the tipping, then we will give you something to appreciate your work also to share some income to you. Not all tour companies understand this, but we always do this to all places we visit.

You need to understand, tipping will be given by the tourists when they are satisfied with your services, so do your best to make them happy during the visits by explaining everything they need to know about the temple itself. I'm really sure if they are happy, they will appreciate your work.

I hope next time, people in Besakih temple will learn something and can change their mind to be better in the future. This is not about money. You need to make the tourists comfortable during the visits, if they are happy, so the tour company is also happy to take other tourists to come again, then money flows and comes to you in a good way. Tourists are happy, and your incomes will flow.

I hope Besakih people read all the reviews here. So they can start to learn from their mistakes. How can we help each other, when we are always feel dissapointed when we bring our guests to visit Besakih. If just one or two people did that, it's ok, we still can explain to our guests, but the problem is all people in besakih do the same thing .

Thank you, but I choose to go to another temple, who can give a good experience for my guests. I have tried so many times, I thought they were changed. But I think it's not gonna happen.

The temple is beautiful, but cant access to the real thing, rituals and ceremonies are not for general public. The entrance is expensive, and inside It is full of scammers that lie to you to get your money, they sell you the offerings (x10 price if you are foreigner) and when is time to do the offering the bramhan ask you to leave more money. I was looking for knowing more about the religion and culture of the place, this is the picture I will take back.

Visiting Besakih Temple was truly a once-in-a-lifetime experience. From the moment I stepped through the gates, I felt a deep sense of awe and reverence wash over me. The temple's grandeur, nestled against the backdrop of Mount Agung, took my breath away.

As I wandered through the temple complex, I was mesmerized by the intricate carvings, vibrant decorations, and the serene atmosphere that surrounded me. Each corner seemed to hold a hidden treasure, a testament to the rich cultural heritage of Bali.

One of the most memorable moments of my visit was witnessing a traditional Balinese Hindu ceremony. The colorful processions, the melodious chants, and the heartfelt prayers left me feeling deeply moved and inspired.

Despite the crowds of fellow tourists, I found moments of quiet contemplation within the temple grounds. Sitting amidst the lush gardens, with the majestic mountain towering overhead, I felt a profound sense of peace and connection to something greater than myself.

And the views! Oh, the views were simply breathtaking. Looking out over the verdant rice terraces and valleys below, I was reminded of the sheer beauty and diversity of Bali's landscapes.

In all, my visit to Besakih Temple was an unforgettable journey into the heart and soul of Bali. It's a place where ancient traditions come to life, where spirituality fills the air, and where every moment is infused with a sense of wonder and magic.
