Pura terbesar di Bali, sangat bagus tapi sayang saya kesini mendapatkan pengalaman tidak menyenangkan. Baru saja turun dari shuttle sudah kerubuni membuat saya merasa dikeroyok oleh orang orang yang menjual canang & dupa. Dipaksa membeli bunga padahal saya sudah bilang saya tidak sembahyang,  buat permisi permisi diatas katanya (padahal di atas pun kita tidak bisa memasuki pura). Langsung dipakaikan selendang (untuk perempuan) dan ikat kepala (anak laki dan dewasa lelaki), padahal anak saya sudah bilang tidak usah tidak perlu masih dipaksa pakai. Saat ditanya di awal harga berapa tidak dijawab lalu setelah memaksa dan dipakaikan semua harga sangat mengejutkan. Diminta 200an untuk 3 orang. Saya bilang tidak ada uang segitu klo mau di transfer. Saya cek di dompet hanya ada total 170rb (kurang lebih karena recehan uangnya) akhirnya di ambil semua uangnya. Benar benar tidak pegang uang sampai pulang hahaha. Kalau tau di awal harganya semahal itu saya jelas jelas akan menolak.karena diawal saya cuma denger 20rb untuk bunga , nyatanya mahal sekali. Itu dengan sikon akhirnya saya membawa bunga canang + dupa beserta selendang + 2 ikat kepala. Saat pulang ternyata guide meminta tip (saya mendenger di awal tiket 100k 2dewasa sudah free guide). Saya jadi bingung , di awal saya dibuat kaget seperti dikeroyok orang banyak yg membuat saya tidak bisa menolak. Karena ini tempat sakral saya menahan rasa kesal dan marah. The temple itself is great, but everything else is a tourist trap. It's 90k for an entrance ticket that includes a guide and a bus ride to the entrance. When u get off the bus, there will be a bunch of women that sell offerings, practically forcing you to buy them for the temple (you don't need to, they cost 150k), then if u go to pray at the topmost temple, your guide will ask for a donation, 100k, it has to be the red bill or more, that pissed me off, and, to top it off, at the end, your guide will ask for a tip as well. For me, not worth it.

Besakih Temple is a must see. Visited with my family despite reading some negative reviews here and it was well worth it.

We arrived early (8:30 AM) on a weekday morning in the low season, and it felt like we had the place to ourselves. Having read reviews we were prepared for aggressive vendors and tip-seeking guides. In reality these elements were a minor distraction, on par with other big Indonesian temples like Borobudur. Go knowing what to expect, be polite but firm with your "no" and enjoy the spectacular sights, and sacred feeling of this place.

I am generous with guides and drivers who do a great job (it can make or break an experience, so I try to reward for great service), so I had no problem tipping our guide, who did a great job of leading us through the series of temples, took great photos, and connected us with the priest at the top to receive a blessing.

On it's own, Besakih is surely one of the most grand and impressive expressions of Balinese temple architecture, but the mountain location and views of the volcano take it to the next level. Also Besakih seems more open to tourists than many other Balinese temples whose inner courtyards are closed to visitors.

We were invited to give an offering at the main temple, and sit for a couple of minutes in silence, which was a special experience for us and our kids.

It's the most important temple in Bali at the base of Agung mountain.
You buy tickets at the base - includes sarong hire, one way electric cart ride up to the temple and guide. The cart drop off place, avoid the hawkers selling offerings. You are handed over to a guide. Who is also your photographer :-) some great views, with Agung towering in the background. It's a temple complex with multiple temples - each one specialises in a particular trade, eg. Farmers, businessmen etc. Like every other temple, visitors are not allowed inside. The guide will offer to enter the Maheswara temple at the top for a prayer experience. You may be pressured to donate some money to the temple, 30k IDR is fine. You are expected to tip the guide at the end, I paid 100k. There are plenty of shops around the temples selling the usual fare. Free clean toilets near the ticketing complex.

Besakih Great Temple stands majestically as Bali's holiest and largest temple complex, a spiritual pinnacle on the slopes of Mount Agung. The sprawling grounds host a mesmerizing array of shrines, each a testament to Balinese Hindu architecture and devotion. The panoramic vistas of lush landscapes and volcanic beauty make the journey profound. The temple's significance in Balinese culture resonates with every step, creating a sacred ambiance. While occasional crowds may affect the tranquility, witnessing ceremonies and rituals enhances the visit. Besakih, with its cultural grandeur and spiritual aura, remains an unmissable destination, offering a profound glimpse into Bali's rich heritage.

I had the most awe-inspiring experience visiting Besakih Great Temple in Bali! This sacred place is an absolute must-see for anyone exploring this beautiful island. From the moment I stepped foot inside, I was enchanted by the ancient architecture, lush surroundings, and the spiritual atmosphere that permeates every corner.

The towering pagodas, intricately carved stone structures, and the breathtaking view of Mount Agung in the background make Besakih Temple an architectural marvel and a photographer's dream. The energy here is truly special, and it's impossible not to feel a sense of peace and serenity while wandering through its sacred grounds.

The temple's history and significance are fascinating, and the knowledgeable guides on-site can provide you with a deeper understanding of the cultural and spiritual importance of this place. Whether you're a history buff, a spiritual seeker, or simply someone looking for a unique and enriching experience, Besakih Temple has something to offer everyone.

I highly recommend visiting during sunrise or sunset when the temple takes on a magical glow. Make sure to dress respectfully and explore the various shrines and courtyards. And don't forget to bring your camera to capture the beauty of this ancient wonder.

Besakih Temple is a true gem of Bali, and I can't wait to return. Don't miss the opportunity to immerse yourself in the rich culture and history of this remarkable place. It's an experience you'll cherish forever!

Visited Besakih Temple recently, drawn by its historical allure. While the temple's grandeur is undeniable, there's an aspect of the visit that needs to be called out.

Upon paying for the entrance fee, I was assigned a tour guide, despite clearly stating I didn't want one. I decided to roll with it, expecting at least some valuable insights, but the tour was terrible and useless to say the least.

The real kicker came at the end. The guide had the audacity to demand 400,000 IDR for a service I initially declined. I courteously offered 100,000 IDR, but he wasn't having it. Even after reluctantly handing over 300,000 IDR, he kept ushering me towards various stalls, obviously nudging me to spend more.

This kind of hard sell, especially in a place as sacred as Besakih Temple, is disgusting. It undermines the temple's spiritual essence and turns a potentially enlightening experience into a commercial transaction.

To those planning a visit, Besakih Temple is a must-see, but be wary of the tour guide situation. Don�t let this dampen your experience of what is otherwise a majestic and culturally rich site.

The funny part was when after the tour guide received the 300,000 IDR, a couple minutes later he talks about karma and I just stared and laughed at him and asked if he really knows about karma. What a joke.

Honestly, it's a bit of a downer, considering it's the biggest hindu temple in SEA. Cost is IDR90K, and should include sarong, one way shuttle and a  "guide". You are not allowed to go with your own guide, and the ones they provide are useless, they don't explain  anything, just tell you go up here, go there, which you could easily figure out yourself. At the end, they have the guts to ask you for tips. No shuttle on the way down as they want you to walk through the shops (all the same) to buy souvenirs. As a side note, the food place at the entrance is horrible. They served us rotten coconut and charged 30k for water.

As soon as we alighted from the buggy car, they swarmed us and placed head band, flowers, saying that it is a must worn ornament while visiting the temple. In the wnd they asked for money, luckily we managed to returned them except one pack of flower which we gave tonthe guide so that he could placed it in the shrine.
Overall, it is one of many temples in Bali, but good for those who wants to know a bit of history and Balinese culture. If you plan to visit, make sure don't accept anything from the vendors. The only thing which is mandatory is to wear the "sarong" but it is included in your entrance fee.
Also, I need to mention that the restrooms are new and clean at the time of our visit.

This is the biggest temple, actually there are 50 temples in this location, in Bali. The views at the top are stunning. The temples are beautiful.
The admission ticket includes a tour guide and a borrowed sarong so you can enter the temple.
There is plenty of paid parking structures for cars and scooters. Pictures will follow.

If you want to feel like walking wallet then it�s a perfect place to be! As soon as you hop on the shuttle bus you become a target for local sellers, the shuttle bus won�t even stop and they will already try to put some goods for sale on your lap (eg. temple offerings, scarfs, etc) We refused to buy it and they said �No offering, no temple.� Entrance ticket is the most expensive ticket of all the temples we�ve been to in Bali and it�s the worst place to visit! If you are not Hindu, don�t bother yourself to go there since you are not allowed to enter most of the places and all you can do is try to sneak a peek from outside the fence. Entrance ticket includes a local guide service but we had an impression he was there more for telling us where not to go than talking about the temple. At the end we were asked to tip him!! Also there�s one place in front of temple with high stairs - if you want to take a picture there be prepared you either have to pay 30k for it or you wont be able to take a picture because locals will let go their customers first so you will never get a chance to take your free photo :-)

Besakih temple is a pura (Balinese word for temple) complex found in Karingasem Regency.

If you are a Hindu or want to explore the unique Balinese Hinduism, come and visit this place. Entrance fee is 80,000 Rupiah which includes a sarong, a shuttle service to the entrance of the main temple, and a tour around the complex with a local guide.

This temple is said to be the oldest, biggest, and the holiest in Bali Hinduism. There are different worship areas for each of the Hindu trinity, Brahma, Shiva, and Vishnu.
